Today, police said four Phantom F-4 fighter-bombers rocketed Hezbollah bases two miles north of Sunday's targets. A source close to the command of the Syrian troops in Beirut said if the release does occur, it is unlikely to be before the middle of the week. The Syrians were instrumental in working out the releases in April of two American hostages, Frank Reed and Robert Polhill. ``We haven't been contacted yet about arrangements of the release. It usually takes two to three days after such contact to have the hostage out,'' the source said Sunday, speaking on condition of anonymity. Syria is Lebanon's main power broker. It has 40,000 troops in the country, controlling 70 percent of its territory. On Sunday, a source close to Hezbollah said Iran had decided to use its influence with the kidnappers to free one of the hostages, and a scenario for the release was being worked out. ``The decision was made in Tehran to release the hostage. The details on where, when and how are now under consideration in Lebanon,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The source would not speculate on who would be released, or answer any other questions. ``We have to wait for a communique (from the kidnappers),'' he said. Moslem fundamentalists accuse Western governments, especially the United States, of bias toward Israel and hold them responsible for Israel's actions against the Arabs. The hostages include six Americans and 10 Europeans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Earlier, a source close to the Syrian army command said that if any hostage were released, it would probably be Brian Keenan, a Belfast man who was traveling on an Irish passport when abducted. The Irish Red Cross flew the first Western relief plane into Tehran after the June 21 earthquake in northern Iran that killed about 40,000 people. Shortly before the quake, three Irish parliamentarians visited Tehran and held talks about Keenan with Iranian Foreign Ministry officials. On their return to Dublin, the parliamentarians condemned the imprisonment of more than 300 Lebanese Shiites in the Khiam jail in Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in south Lebanon. Release of these prisoners has been a major demand by the kidnappers of Western hostages in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Pounded, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was down in European trading this morning while the British pound showed new strength. Gold prices were lower. The British pound moved above $1.80 on the strength of a statement this weekend by John Major, the chancellor of the exchequer, that the British currency could be allowed to rise above 3.0000 Deutsche marks preparation for entry to the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System. The British pound was quoted at $1.8097, down from $1.8115 at the opening but up strongly from late Friday's $1.7865. The pound had not been above $1.8000 since Jan. 4, 1989. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.70 yen, down 0.25 yen from Friday's close. The yen-dollar rate was unchanged in late-morning trading in London. Dealers said the dollar was stronger in early trading in Tokyo because U.S. employment data released on Friday was better than expected. ``But it moved lower, with many traders expecting U.S. interest rates to ease, after it was reported that U.S. Treasury Undersecretary (David) Mulford has welcomed the yen's recent recovery,'' said Kohei Kuroda of Sumitomo Bank. Other dollar rates compared with Friday: _1.6470 German marks, down from 1.6540 _1.3922 Swiss francs, down from 1.4005 _5.5270 French francs, down from 5.5515 _1,207.30 Italian lire, down from 1,213.25 _1.1585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1630 The dollar rate for the Dutch guilder was not available. London's gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $359.90 per troy ounce this morning, down from $361.25 late Friday. Gold in Zurich was quoted at $360.20, down from $361.25 late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at $360.62 per troy ounce, up 14 cents from Saturday's close. Silver bullion was quoted in London at $4.87 a troy ounce, down from $4.88 per ounce from late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Lutheran Congregations Show Support Of Gay Ministers
DOC.TEXT: Members of two Lutheran congregations sang hymns and prayed to show their support of three homosexual ministers whose ordination led to an unprecedented church trial. A disciplinary committee of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, expected to complete a three-day hearing today, could expel the local churches for defying denomination rules by ordaining a lesbian couple and gay man. The panel has until July 17 to issue its decision. At Sunday services, the Rev. John Frykman, pastor of First United Lutheran Church, told his congregation that tolerance was the Lord's way. Members of St. Francis Lutheran Church heard and expressed a similar message. ``Jesus accepted everyone, and we should accept everyone,'' said Erna Dennert outside St. Francis. The church, with 5.3 million members, is the largest Lutheran body in the United States. Like other mainstream churches, it forbids the ordination of sexually active homosexuals, arguing that sex should be practiced only within marriage. Despite the ban, the two local churches in January ordained three seminary graduates who were open about their homosexuality and refused to take a vow a celibacy. Jeff Johnson, 28, was named assistant pastor of United Lutheran, a predominantly heterosexual congregation of about 100 in the city's Richmond district. Ruth Frost, 42, and Phyllis Zillhart, 32, a couple together for five years, are at St. Francis, a largely gay congregation in the Castro district. ``We have many gay and lesbian pastors in the church right now, and there is no reason they should stay in the closet,'' Zillhart said Sunday. But Sierra Pacific Synod Bishop Lyle Miller, who heads the church in Northern California, filed charges against the two local congregation and their pastors. ``We are not convinced ... that living in homosexual relationships is what ought to be,'' Miller said Sunday. The ecclesiastical hearing, which began Friday, marks the first time the church has sought to discipline a pastor or congregation since it was formed in a merger of three major Lutheran groups in January 1988. The 14-member committee could censure First United and St. Francis, suspend or expel them. But Frykman and the Rev. James DeLange, pastor of St. Francis, say they and their congregations are willing to be ousted to prove their support of the civil and religious rights of gay people. All 13 other ELCA churches in San Francisco have said they support the two defiant congregations and will maintain relations with them even if they are expelled, Frykman said.

DOC.HEAD: Innocent Plea Entered In Slaying Of Seven Arab Workers
DOC.TEXT: The 21-year-old Israeli charged with the premeditated murder of seven Palestinian laborers in a burst of automatic rifle fire refused to speak as his trial opened today. Judge Chaim Steinberg ruled that Ami Popper's silence amounted to a plea of innocent to charges he gunned down the seven Arabs and wounded 10 others on May 20 outside Tel Aviv. The massacre led to widespread riots in the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank, and 13 other Palestinians were killed by army gunfire in the three days after the mass slaying as soldiers tried to put down the violence. Before the plea was accepted, Popper's lawyer, David Ofek, asked to be relieved of the job of defense attorney. He cited in part the young man's refusal to communicate. Steinberg rejected Okek's request and set the next court session for September 5. Ofek later said he would appeal the Tel Aviv District Court judge's decision to the Supreme Court. Popper, dressed in a white T-shirt and black shorts, remained silent throughout the one-hour opening session. The victims of the massacre were among about 50 unarmed Arab workers waiting for day labor jobs in the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Letzion. The charges say Popper was armed with a Galil assault rifle and forced the workers to sit in rows, then stopped a passing vehicle and ordered its occupants to join the others. ``All of a sudden, the accused aimed his weapon in the direction of the workers and started firing incessantly,'' the charges say. Popper, who is from Rishon Letzion, was arrested shortly after the slayings. At the time, authorities described Popper as ``deranged'' and distraught over an unhappy love affair. Ofek later maintained Popper was trying to kill one man among the 50 laborers. He said the intended victim was one of five Arabs who sexually assaulted Popper when he was 12. Popper's family first said they had never heard of such an assault, but later said the suspect began to act strangely at the time of the alleged molestation. Ofek had argued that Popper was unfit to stand trial, but a panel of five psychiatrists found he was able to understand the charges. In court today, Popper spent most of his time staring at the ceiling during the proceedings before a three-judge panel consisting of Steinberg, David Ben-Ofir and Edmond Levy. Ofek, who was appointed by the court, said he could not defend Popper because of the youth's silence and because he was unable to find a psychiatrist willing to perform the further examination of his client he feels is needed. In rejecting Ofek's request to be removed from the case, Steinberg promised the court's aid in finding a psychiatrist willing to examine Popper.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa's Infamous Rolls Auctioned for $90,000
DOC.TEXT: The 1979 Rolls Royce Zsa Zsa Gabor was driving when she had her infamous cop-slapping confrontation with a Beverly Hills policeman was auctioned for $90,000. Miss Gabor, 72, sat in the Corniche convertible and patted the door affectionately as auctioneers drove up the price at an auto sale Sunday. ``I don't like giving it up,'' Miss Gabor said after the auctioneer announced that Leo Dutran of Boston was the high bidder. The actress was convicted of slapping the policeman during a July 14 traffic stop in Beverly Hills. She was sentenced to serve 72 hours in jail after failing to complete community service work as ordered. Dutran collects cars of celebrities for a museum in a Boston suburb. Auctioneer Mitchell Kruse of Kruse International, Auburn, Ind., said 500 cars were sold during the two-day event at Bally's Hotel and Casino. Another celebrity car sold Sunday was a 1957 Ford with a retractable roof, owned by actor Larry Hagman. It was purchased by Richard Crane of Dallas for $37,500. Hagman said he bought the car five years ago and kept it in storage. ``I've got nine cars and my wife told me I had to sell one of them,'' Hagman said.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Raid Hezbollah For Second Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with casualties. Picks up 3rd pvs, `It was ...' ^By FAROUK NASSAR
DOC.TEXT: Israeli jets rocketed guerrilla bases of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah militia today in their second raid in 22 hours on south Lebanon bases of the Shiite Moslem fundamentalist fighters. One Hezbollah fighter was killed and 11 people _ five combatants and six civilians _ were wounded in the raid, said a police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing rules. In two runs spaced over 10 minutes, four F-4 fighter-bombers rocked the bases in the villages of Loweizeh and Melita _ which are two miles north of Sunday's targets. It was Israel's third raid on targets in Lebanon in four days and 15th this year. Police said leaping flames and palls of black smoke hung over the targets in Iqlim al-Tuffah, or the apple region, southeast of the port city of Sidon. In Jerusalem, the Israeli military said the targets, 15 miles north of the border, were bases for ``organizing and launching attacks'' against Israel. It said all its planes had returned safely, but gave no other details. Both Loweizeh and Melita are traditional strongholds of Hezbollah, or Party of God, and overlook the northern flank of Israel's self-declared security zone. Hezbollah confirmed the new strikes in a statement issued in Beirut and said they were followed by massive artillery bombardment of the two villages from Israeli positions in the security zone. After Sunday's raid, Hezbollah fighters fired three surface-to-surface missiles toward northern Israel. Early today, Israeli artillery hammered suspected guerrilla hideouts in the foothills of Mount Hermon. Military helicopters illuminated the rugged mountain slopes with parachute flares as long-range guns on the Israeli border pounded the villages of Ein Atta and Kfeir in southeastern Lebanon before dawn, police said. In Sunday's raid, Israeli warplanes destroyed a Hezbollah snipers' nest and ammunition depot on a hilltop between the villages of Jarjou and Ein Bouswar. Police said at least three people were killed and 12 wounded in Sunday's raid. That raised the overall toll of Israeli air strikes this year to 19 dead and 51 injured, excluding today's raid. The raids followed word from Iran's official news agency Saturday that one of the 16 Western hostages in Lebanon, probably a European, might soon be freed. Hezbollah is the umbrella group for factions believed holding most of the hostages. ``Let us pray the Israeli attacks will not scuttle efforts to free one of the hostages,'' said a Shiite source close to Hezbollah's Iranian-backed leadership. ``The hostage-holders are definitely restless, but I personally believe Iran's pressure will probably override the impact of the attacks,'' the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Shiite fundamentalists accuse Western governments of bias toward Israel and hold them responsible for its actions against the Arabs. Jarjou and Ein Bouswar are two to three miles north of Israel's security zone. Hezbollah has long been engaged in guerrilla attacks on Israeli troops and allied Lebanese Christian militiamen policing the zone. The zone's population is predominantly Shiite Moslem. Israel carved out the buffer area in 1985, saying it was needed to guard against cross-border raids. Israeli jets on Friday attacked bases of radical Palestinian guerrillas in Syrian-policed northern and eastern Lebanon. Eight fighters were wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Former Prague Communist Boss Sentenced To Four Years In Prison
DOC.TEXT: Prague's former Communist Party boss was found guilty today of abuse of power and sentenced to four years in jail in the first conviction of a member of the country's former hard-line leadership. The official, Miroslav Stepan, had ordered use of water cannon and tear gas against demonstrators in Prague in the fall of 1988. A year later, a popular uprising toppled the authoritarian Communist government. Dozens of Czechoslovak citizens crowded in front of the small room where the district court verdict was handed down, and some expressed satisfaction. ``That serves him right _ that's exactly what he deserved,'' an elderly woman said. Under Czechoslovak law, sentencing comes at the time of conviction. Stepan appealed the verdict but was to remain in custody. No date was set for the appeal, which was to be heard by a municipal court. The court ruled he had ``unjustifiably'' overstepped the bounds of his office when, as chairman of the Prague Defense Council, he ordered the action against the demonstrators on Oct. 28, 1988. He was also accused of having demonstrators transported outside Prague in January 1989 after they failed to disperse as ordered by police. Stepan, 44, was arrested on Dec. 23, 1989, less than a month after stepping down as Prague party boss. He was the first member of the country's Communist leadership to be brought to trial. The trial, which began June 25, was initially held behind closed doors but was opened to the public four days later after strong complaints in the Czechoslovak media. Stepan had pleaded innocent and said it was a political trial. He appealed to President Vaclav Havel to hold no more such trials. Five other former high-ranking officials, including Communist Party leader Milos Jakes and chief ideologue Vasil Bilak, were detained last month and accused of ``serious criminal activity.'' But all were released within 48 hours. Stepan, who joined the party's ruling Politburo in December 1987, had a reputation as a ruthless hard-liner. He was instrumental in suppressing a wave of street protests in Prague beginning in August 1988. The Communists ruled Czechoslovakia for four decades until they were toppled by a peaceful revolution in November. Czechoslovakia's new non-Communist-controlled government took over in December.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Urges Aid from West as Economic Summit Opens
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said today that Western aid to the Soviet Union would benefit his country and the donor nations. Leaders of the world's seven richest countries convened in Houston today with the question of aid to Moscow at the top of their agenda. Shevardnadze, asked by reporters at a Communist Party Congress in the Kremlin whether he thought the Soviet Union needed Western aid, said: ``I feel it would be advantageous, for us and the West.'' But he said he disliked the term ``aid,'' preferring ``credit, technical cooperation, personnel training, joint ventures and joint projects.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is worried his country cannot make the painful leap to a market system without Western credits and wants help from the industrial powers to stop the Soviet Union's economic decline. Gorbachev recently sent President Bush a communique that is believed to repeat an appeal for aid he made in a letter to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Western opponents of aid to the Soviet Union say that no help should be given until the Kremlin drops its economic and military support to Cuba and withdraws from the Kurile Islands north of Japan. Asked whether the Soviet Union would cut aid to Cuba, Shevardnadze said that was strictly ``a question of bilateral relations,'' and did not indicate the government's plans. Soviet troops occupied the Japanese islands in the last days of World War II and have refused to leave. The leaders of West Germany and France advocate helping the Soviet Union despite disagreements over Cuba and Japan, and have called for aid worth $15 billion to bolster reform plans. The credits also would help Soviet businesses meet payments due to Western firms. The Soviet Union traditionally has been punctual in making such payments and recent delays have eroded confidence among foreign investors. West Germany already has granted an unconditional loan of $3.1 billion, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl is apparently growing impatient with opposition from other industrial powers to the aid plan. Moscow's balance-of-payment deficit now tops $2 billion, nearly half of it owed to West German companies. Part of the West German credit is expected to be used to pay overdue bills. Bush has balked at a massive aid program until Soviet authorities move more decisely from a planned to a market economy. The Soviet Union could use Western cash, but there are questions over how much is needed and what impact it would have. Inability to keep food stores stocked has already forced Moscow to spend an extra 3 billion roubles _ $500 million _ on food imports. Even more aid is believed necessary if the Soviet Union is going to leap to a market economy. Without an infusion of Western cash, the move to the market could cause greater hardship for the population and put more social pressure on Gorbachev. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov told the Supreme Soviet parliament in late May that the consumer market was ``destitute.'' Ryzhkov, presenting a plan for what he called a ``regulated market economy,'' warned that if trends continued, ``many crucial decisions, unpopular as they are, will meet an even more embittered response.'' The Soviet economy suffers from inflation and a huge budget deficit. In the first four months of this year, ethnic unrest and strikes caused the loss of an estimated 10 million man-hours. Pro-market reforms are likely to cause a further drop in production as unprofitable businesses go bankrupt. Figures on how much money would begin to stabilize the economy range from $5 to $20 billion _ colossal compared to what Eastern European countries received to restructure their economies, but modest given the size of the Soviet economy and its relatively low level of foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: Multiple Fatality Traffic Accident Ends Flight Of Murder Suspect
DOC.TEXT: A man just paroled from state prison apparently murdered a teen-age boy and then died in a fiery head-on collision as he attempted to take the body somewhere to dispose of it, authorities said. The investigation of a highway accident in southeastern Kansas on Sunday turned into a murder probe when an autopsy showed one of the four people thought to have died in the wreck already was dead of a stab wound before the accident. ``It's a strange, fantastic case,'' said Dr. William Eckert, the veteran pathologist who autopsied all four bodies. ``I've never had one like it. This guy was already dead in the car and the man was going to stick him somewhere.'' Names hadn't been released this morning pending positive identifications and notification of relatives. But authorities believe they included a 16-year-old Wichita boy who was dead before the accident happened and a 34-year-old parolee. Wichita police said the parolee was released Tuesday from a state prison in Norton where he had been serving a 10-year term for kidnapping and sodomy. A statement from Chatauqua County Sheriff Butch Lewis said a car driven by the parolee struck a pickup truck Sunday morning on U.S. 166 southeast of Sedan in far southeastern Kansas. Both vehicles burned and the four bodies were burned beyond recognition. Meanwhile, 125 miles away, the parolee's mother returned to Wichita from a trip Sunday morning and found blood inside and outside her home, according to a police report. She told police her son had been staying with her. Investigators theorize the parolee was driving to Oklahoma to dispose of the body. He reportedly borrowed the car involved in the accident from a friend in Derby early Saturday evening. The missing Wichita 16-year-old was last heard from Saturday evening when he went cruising in downtown Wichita in a pickup borrowed from his uncle, police said. That truck was found abandoned at a convenience store. An autopsy showed the boy died of a stab wound in the heart, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Age Hunter Held In Fatal Highway Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A 14-year-old boy who officials say grew tired of hunting and decided to start shooting at passing cars was arrested in the death of a taxi driver. The boy, whose name was not released because of his age, was jailed without bond Sunday on charges of first-degree murder and attempted murder. Police say he was among three youngsters who were hunting in the area. Raymond Montanino, 53, of Melbourne was fatally shot by gunfire that also hit two other cars late Saturday afternoon. ``The three subjects had been hunting in the area and decided to start shooting at passing motorists,'' said detective Emmanuel Jenkins. ``I guess they were just kids with nothing better to do on a Saturday afternoon.'' Occupants of the other two cars escaped injury, but Montanino was hit in the right chest by a bullet that passed through an open passenger window. He was later pronounced dead at Holms Regional Medical Center in Melbourne. The others youths, age 14 and 15, were questioned by police and released, although they still could face charges, Jenkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Companion Outlines Funeral Plans
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf, Nonetheless, she... to CORRECT remember to reminder
DOC.TEXT: When homeless activist Mitch Snyder was near death several times during hunger strikes for the homeless, he and co-worker Carol Fennelly talked about his possible death and planned his funeral, she says. But Ms. Fennelly said she never expected to be planning her longtime companion's memorial this way _ after Snyder hanged himself in his room at the shelter they both fought the Reagan administration to create and maintain. Snyder, who fought for the homeless for 17 years, apparently was making no political statements last week when he hanged himself by an electrical cord. Police found a note near his body describing problems in his 15-year relationship with Fennelly. Nonetheless, she said his funeral Tuesday will be a reminder of his sacrifices to unite and secure cooperation for his cause and the Community for Creative Non-Violence, which he founded. ``Everything Mitch did was political, where he lived, what he did, where he ate,'' Ms. Fennelly said in a telephone interview. ``That is who Mitch is. He wanted his funeral to be not just an event for the sake of the event, he wanted it to have some political impact, and we intend to make it so.'' The mourners are expected to include the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Washington Mayor Marion Barry, actor Martin Sheen and entertainer-nutritionist Dick Gregory. Snyder did most of his work in the streets and that is where his funeral will be held. After a service by Jackson in front of the homeless shelter where Snyder lived, a horse-drawn cortege will carry his body to a rally at city hall before his body is cremated. Ms. Fennelly declined to speculate on what Snyder's death might mean to the causes he espoused. ``All I know is that Mitch is dead and I'm trying to put together a funeral that would make him happy,'' she said. ``And that is all I care about.'' ``He was a very good teacher. He taught us many good things and skills we need to have to carry on,'' Ms. Fennelly said. She was briefly hospitalized late Saturday after fainting during a CCNV strategy meeting. ``I'm feeling a little better,'' she said Sunday. ``It's a moment by moment thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Groups Say Group of Seven Long on Talk, Short on Action
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 7th graf pvs, bgng, France was xxx etc., to UPDATE with Sununu quotes.
DOC.TEXT: A worldwide coalition of environmental groups is hoping to spotlight what it claims is a big-talk, little-action record of the major industial nations meeting today at the economic summit. The ``Envirosummit'' group of 150 organizations says the world's seven wealthiest countries have done little since ending their 1989 meeting with a proclamation that ``decisive action is urgently needed to understand and protect the earth's ecological balance.'' President Bush and his six summit guests have the global environment on their agenda Tuesday and are expected to come up with a 1990 communique outlining how the seven nations will cooperate on international controls. But U.S. officials said in advance the summit was unlikely to produce any bold moves on environmental protection. The ``Envirosummit'' group ranks West Germany highest on performance during the past year, with a 65 score out of a possible 100. It tallied the score by examining policies on climate change, protection of biological diversity, preserving tropical forests, combatting pollution of the oceans, population control policy, aid for the cleanup of Eastern Europe, and aid to Third World countries to preserve the environment during economic development. France was second, 48 out of 100, and the United States, Japan, Britain, Italy and Canada were clustered close with scores ranging from 39 to 42.5. White House chief of staff John Sununu scoffed at the environmental survey results. ``I think most of that grading was on environmental rhetoric rather than on environmental performance,'' he said during an appearance today on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' ``I think West Germany got a lot of good grades for rhetoric,'' Sununu added. ``If you take a good look at what the United States has actually done in terms of cleaning up our environment, reducing emissions into the atmosphere, cleaning up the quality of our water and now, with the added benefit that will come from the clean air bill that the president put forward, i don't think the United States has to take a back seat to anyone in terms of reality of performance on the environment.'' Although most countries agreed earlier this year to end production of chemicals that destroy the earth's protective ozone layer by the year 2000, George T. Frampton, president of The Wilderness Society, said: ``The reality is that our forests are being cut just as fast as they were a year ago. Carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are being emitted into the atmosphere at just the same high volume, or even greater, than that of a year ago. Population growth and ocean pollution have continued unabated.'' Jay Hair, executive vice president of the National Wildlife Federation, told a news conference Sunday that ``the most shining achievement of the past year'' was West Germany's announcement that it would try to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the most important ``greenhouse gas'' responsible for what many scientists believe is a gradual warming of the globe, by 25 percent. No other country has made such a commitment. Calling the scores ``generous by any standard,'' Conrad von Moltke, a German environmentalist on the staff of the World Wildlife Fund said, ``It's hard to see how Germany is going to maintain this kind of ranking, devoted as it is to ever-bigger cars, ever-faster cars on ever more roads.'' ``This is not a one-shot deal,'' Frampton said. Members of the coalition will refine their scorecard to make it what Frampton called a better ``objective template'' for measuring national policies, and mobilize pressure against the governments concerned. The group said one item of environmental news out of the summit had no effect on the national rankings. That was the announcement by President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney that Canada and the United States would negotiate an air pollution agreement, with preliminary talks this month. Bush said a year ago that he expected to proceed along those lines once revisions to the Clean Air Act to enact new controls on the sources of acid rain were nailed down. Both the House and Senate versions of the bill include requirements for large reductions in acid rain precursors, and the White House is optimistic Bush will get a bill from the House-Senate conference committee that he can sign. Half the acid rain falling in eastern Canada originates in sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions from power plant smokestacks and other sources in the United States, and Mulroney and his predecessor, Pierre Trudeau, sought a U.S. control program in vain for more than a decade. ``I think this day will be long remembered in the history of our relationship for the significant departure it constitutes from past positions,'' Mulroney said in his joint appearance with Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Say They Will Go Ahead With Strike
DOC.TEXT: Miners said today they were going ahead with a one-day protest strike this week despite an appeal for labor peace from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Communist leaders. ``We no longer consider the Communist Party of the Soviet Union our party,'' said Vasily Grinev, a member of the strike committee in the country's second largest coal field, the Kuznetsk Basin in the Western Ukraine. Miners in the largest coal region, the Don River Basin of the Ukraine, met for 12 hours Sunday and resolved to go ahead with the strike on Wednesday. Workers at the Zhiguli Automotive Works in Togliatti plan to hold a sympathy meeting during their lunch break, but will not stop production, said Ivan A. Baryshnykov, a workers' spokesman. The miners are angry over shortages of housing, food and other consumer goods, and concerned that Gorbachev's reforms will raise prices without giving them any benefits. The 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party last week urged miners not to strike. Gorbachev repeated that appeal in a televised interview Sunday night, warning workers not to take what he called ``an illegal path.'' ``Everybody should understand that this is not the time for ultimatums,'' Gorbachev said in a Soviet television interview taped in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses, where the party congress is meeting. After a nationwide coal strike last summer, the government passed new rules requiring workers to complete a complicated procedure before they can legally strike. But miners in Vorkuta have been striking periodically over the past year. Despite the appeals, feelings of anger and independence were growing among miners in the Donbass, Western Siberia and Vorkuta in the Arctic. They plan to send only skeleton shifts into the shafts Wednesday morning and stage demonstrations. The protests are designed to warn party leaders that they can no longer assume the support of the working class they claim to represent. Asked whether the strike was a sign of flagging ties between the party and workers, Gorbachev acknowledged that ``the party is guilty before the working class, because (the workers') role is weak now.'' At a preliminary conference last month, miners from around the nation scheduled a congress to found the union and called for a mass exodus of party workers and the nationalization of party assets. Although the party relinquished its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly of power last winter, no nationwide political group has emerged to challenge it. But a free nationwide miners' union could do just that. The party congress opened last Monday with a demand from Donbass miner Vladimir Bludov for the resignation of the Communist Party leadership. The miners, who work in shafts owned by the Ministry of the Coal Mining Industry, struck last July to demand that the government increase supplies of meat, soap, laundry detergent and other consumer goods. They also wanted safer working conditions in the mines, where about 600 people are killed by accidents yearly, and they wanted the ministry to surrender control of the coal fields to local authorities. Faced with the worst Soviet strike in 72 years, the Council of Ministers capitulated. But the miners say the government has not kept its promises.

DOC.HEAD: Police Suspect Serial Killer in Couple Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Police in eastern Virginia believe the slayings of six young people and the disappearance of two others in recent years may be the work of a serial killer. The unsolved cases involve four couples traveling by car in isolated areas. One crime has occurred annually between April and October since 1986. None has occurred this year, but police fear the killer may strike again by October. Police ``have been working jointly together for some years now and they have come to some possible conclusions,'' said Cpl. Bob Haynes, spokesman for a joint FBI-Virginia State Police task force investigating the crimes with local police. The killer may have dressed as an authority figure, such as a police officer, to win the victims' cooperation and lure them to their deaths, a newspaper reported Sunday. The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star, the combined Sunday paper, quoted an unidentified source as saying the killer could be someone disguised as a police officer. When asked whether the killer might be an officer, the source said, ``we cannot rule that out.'' Police plan to announce give detail on their findings at a news conference later this month, Haynes said. ``They're pretty much convinced it's a serial killer,'' said Mark Johnson, a College of William and Mary police detective. Johnson investigated the first crime, the 1986 slayings one of the college's students and her friend. ``They felt it was all connected,'' said Margie Lauer, whose son, Daniel, was one of the slaying victims. Mrs. Lauer said FBI and state police agents recently told her of the serial killer theory. ``We were expecting something like this,'' Kathy Knobling, stepmother of another slaying victim, said Sunday. She is a spokeswoman for a group of the victims' relatives and friends. Irvin B. Wells III, special agent in charge of the FBI's Norfolk office, said the randomness of the crimes and certain similarities lend credence to the serial killer theory. But he also noted the crimes lack a definite ``signature'' because different types of weapons were used. Here are details of the four cases: _In October 1986, Rebecca A. Dowski, 21, a William and Mary student from Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Cathleen M. Thomas, 27, a Virginia Beach stockbroker, were found strangled and stabbed in Miss Thomas's car along a scenic drive that connects historic sites at Jamestown and Yorktown. _In September 1987, Robin M. Edwards, 14, of Newport News and David L. Knobling, 20, of Hampton were found shot to death on their first date at Ragged Island Wildlife Refuge in Isle of Wight County. _In April 1988, Keith Call, 20, and Cassandra Hailey, 19, two Christopher Newport College students, disappeared on their first date. Call's pickup truck was found abandoned on the Colonial Parkway. The two have not been found. _In September 1989, Lauer, 21, and Annamaria Phelps, 18, both of Amelia County, disappeared on their way to Virginia Beach. Lauer's car was found at a rest stop in New Kent County. Their bodies were discovered in woods nearby six weeks later. Miss Phelps died of a knife wound but the cause of Lauer's death was not determined.

DOC.HEAD: Embassies Struggle to Take Care of Thousands of Albanian Asylum-Seekers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with Hungarian, Czechoslovak missions saying Albanians want to go to U.S., other details, quotes; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak diplomats said the first of the more than 5,000 Albanians who took refuge in a dozen foreign embassies in Tirana would leave their Communist homeland tonight for Prague. The announcement by the Foreign Ministry in Prague followed accusations by Albanian officials that foreign diplomats in the Albanian capital were deliberately slowing the emigration process to cause instability. In the Czechoslovak capital, Deputy Foreign Minister Vojtech Wagner said 51 refugees would arrive in Prague this evening from Tirana aboard an aircraft normally used by President Vaclav Havel, the state news agency CTK reported. The Czechoslovak diplomat said only one or two asylum-seekers wanted to remain in Czechoslovakia and the rest wanted to go to the United States or Australia. Other missions said that although the Albanians would travel through their countries, they did not yet know where they would settle. The French Foreign Ministry in Paris said the formalities of obtaining passports for the 550 refugees at its embassy in Tirana were moving along rapidly, and ``we hope they will be finished by the end of the day.'' The asylum-seekers, some dodging police bullets, began taking refuge on June 28. Albanian authorities pledged Saturday that they would receive travel papers and be accompanied out by diplomatic personnel. But referring to the decree that guaranteed the asylum-seekers would not be punished, the Albanian state ATA news agency on Sunday accused diplomats of not moving quickly enough to seek documents for the refugees. ``This is a stand with premeditation and certain aims to artificially create tensions and problems,'' the statement said. ``It also arouses embarrassment and indignation in the public opinion.'' In Bonn, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that any of the 3,000 Albanians crowding his country's embassy in Tirana who wish to travel to West Germany will be allowed to do so. But the official would not say whether the Albanians would be allowed to settle in West Germany. He said that ``so far no one has manifested a desire to come here. They just want to leave Albania.'' A spokesman at the Foreign ministry in Budapest, Gyoergy Lukacs, said six of the 40 Albanians at the Tirana embassy expressed a desire to settle in Hungary. Most others wanted to go to the United States, he said. Diplomats trying to arrange exit for the Albanians have accused the government of disrupting efforts to feed and provide medical care for the refugees, many of whom were injured scrambling into embassy compounds. The West German, Italian and French embassies were among those reporting difficulties taking care of the refugees. A Hungarian diplomat said the embassies were told they had to arrange transportation for any Albanians they accepted. Police sealed off Tirana's embassy row on Sunday to prevent more Albanians from joining those who had taken refuge inside foreign missions. There were no reports of unrest on Sunday. On Saturday, thousands gathered near embassy row for silent rallies against Europe's last remaining hard-line Communist rulers in Albania, a country of 3.2 million on the Adriatic Sea. The turmoil appeared to contribute to a shake-up Saturday of the ruling Politburo and government. One Politburo member was dismissed, three officials were retired and the police minister and minister of war were fired. Some foreign missions lack sufficient food and water for the refugees and sanitary conditions were poor, officials said Sunday. They said Albanian authorities were not allowing foreign governments to send supplies. ``The situation in our embassy, but in other embassies as well, has become intolerable,'' West Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told West German television. The French Foreign Ministry described the situation at its embassy as increasingly difficult, with inadequate sanitary facilities and a lack of medicine for the more than 500 refugees. A French doctor was seeing 60 patients a day, many of whom were injured while scaling the compound's fence, said the ministry. In Rome, Italian Sen. Franco Salvi said after returning from a private visit to Tirana that 900 Albanian asylum-seekers wanted to come to his country. The Italian ambassador's wife was forced to buy food at the local market to feed those in the mission, Salvi said. Two prefabricated huts were hastily erected on embassy grounds to house some of the Albanians. Communist leader Ramiz Alia has begun this year to institute some cautious economic reforms in an attempt to alleviate shortages and raise the standard of living by creating incentives for workers and farmers. For 45 years, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible. But Albanian leaders have sought better ties abroad since 1985, and they recently began to implement reforms. A package of new regulations that took effect Tuesday entitled all Albanians over age 16 to own a passport.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Poll: Americans Oppose Financial Assistance to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Americans' views of the Soviet Union and leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev are positive, but they strongly oppose providing them with financial assistance, according to a newspaper poll published today. Financial aid to the Soviets is one of the major issues to be discussed at the International Economic Summit that officially began today, but Americans apparently have already made up their minds. The Houston Chronicle's copyright poll showed that 58 percent of the respondents oppose direct economic assistance to the Soviet Union, while 24 percent support it and 16 percent are unsure. Seventy-nine percent favored more open trading, 69 percent supported providing the Soviets with technical assistance and 50 percent were for favorable credit terms. The national survey, taken June 25 through July 2, was conducted through telephone interviews with 773 U.S. residents 18 or older. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The environment was named by poll respondents more than any other issue as the probable greatest threat to the United States in the next century. It was named by 30 percent of those interviewed. ``We're worrying less and less about the Soviet military threat and more and more about issues that have for years been on the back burner'' such as the environment and international terrorism, said Richard Murray, the University of Houston political science professor who conducted the survey for the Chronicle. The poll also shows that 64 percent believe that Japan is the country that poses the greatest long-term economic threat to the United States. Forty percent believe the U.S. trade deficit results from unfair trade practices by the Japanese.

DOC.HEAD: Inquest Faulted Christian Science Officials In Child's Death
DOC.TEXT: Christian Science officials contributed to the death of Robyn Twitchell by discouraging his parents from calling a doctor, an inquest concluded three years ago. David and Ginger Twitchell, lifelong Christian Scientists, were convicted Wednesday of manslaughter in the April 1986 death of 2{-year-old Robyn, by relying solely on prayer to treat the boy during a five-day illness. They were sentenced to 10 years' probation on Friday and ordered to take their three remaining children for regular medical exams. In a 1987 report, West Roxbury District Court Judge Lawrence D. Shubow found that the church's chief spokesman, Nathan Talbot; a Christian Science nurse; and a church practitioner ``contributed'' to Robyn's death by acting ``recklessly and without legal excuse.'' The three were never indicted by the grand jury investigating the case. Shubow's 35-page report was impounded since its completion in 1987 but was released Friday by Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin, who presided at the Twitchells' manslaughter trial. Talbot was faulted for telling the Twitchells to call a funeral home rather than the police or the medical examiner when the couple called Talbot to say Robyn had died. Talbot said today that the church no longer told followers to call a funeral home in such circumstances. An autopsy showed the boy suffered from a congenital defect that had caused a bowel obstruction. Calling police or the medical examiner ``would have in normal course initiated a lifesaving response,'' Shubow wrote. ``The delays in reporting Robyn's plight erased his remaining chance to survive.'' Linda Blaisdell, a church nurse recommended to the couple by Talbot, had earlier ``wrongfully prescribed food for Robyn which probably worsened'' his illness, Shubow wrote. Nancy Calkins, a Christian Science practitioner, apparently discouraged the parents ``from seeking to follow any alternative medically oriented choice,'' Shubow wrote. Talbot said this morning that the church had a longstanding policy of telling Christian Scientists to call a funeral home instead of calling police, but that has changed since the Twitchell case. ``There has never been criticism of Christian Scientists handling it this way,'' Talbot said. The policy has changed in part because funeral homes themselves now direct people to call 911, Talbot said. Calkins said today that she did not want to discuss the matter. But her attorney, Peter Samek, disputed the report of the inquest. ``That's false and I don't think that is the finding of the inquest,'' Samek said. ``She has no ability to render anything besides Christian Science spiritual treatment.'' Blaisdell refused to comment on the report. Shubow concluded the Twitchells should be prosecuted for manslaughter and that the church officials might be prosecuted as accessories to manslaughter. Suffolk District Attorney Newman A. Flanagan called for the inquest to determine the circumstances surrounding the boy's death. Shubow's findings were adopted by prosecutors and presented to a grand jury in 1988, but only the Twitchells were indicted.

DOC.HEAD: It's the Year of the Germans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with violence; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hooligans attacked police and foreigners and looted stores in both German states during raucous, violent celebrations marking West Germany's World Cup victory, police said today. More than 100 people were hurt and four people were killed during countless melees across the nations. Hundreds of thousands of Germans poured into the streets in scores of cities to savor the emotional victory Sunday night, but roving bands of rowdies and neo-Nazi skinheads used the celebrations for violent rampages. The violence lasted into this morning, and widespread vandalism and looting were reported in numerous cities. In the West German city of Hamburg, about 400 hooligans armed with rock and bottles clashed with police. Fifty-four police officers were injured and 88 people were arrested, authoritie said. Windows of more than 20 stores were smashed, one bar was destroyed and several police and private autos were damaged by the mob, police said. Police used truncheons and water cannons to break up the crowd. West Germany's 1-0 victory over Argentina in the World Cup soccer final had strong political overtones for the nation, which is about to unite with East Germany. East Germans also took part in the celebrations and the violence. In East Berlin, neo-Nazi skinheads rampaged on the city's main square and smashed the windows of a bar frequented by homosexuals and attacked passers-by. Three people were seriously injured, authorities said. The skinheads reportedly chased Vietnamese living and working in the country. Twelve people were arrested, police said. Despite the violence, many soccer fans who poured into the streets were elated over the victory, and they proclaimed that it was the year of the Germans. According to some Germans, there were many reasons to celebrate: _ Unification is just around the corner and is likely to be completed before Christmas. _ West Germany pumped billions of marks into East Germany for this month's currency union, and the mighty mark remained just as strong as ever. _ Chancellor Helmut Kohl is playing an increasingly important role in guiding European affairs and world events. _ German language instruction is on the increase in the United States. _ German sports officials recently announced they will soon have a single Olympic team after years of separation. _ Berlin is a top contender for summer Olympic games in the year 2000. ``Deutschland, Super Deutschland,'' thousands of fans from East Berlin and West Berlin shouted. Thousands of flags waved in the cool night air amid the victory celebrations in a massive outpouring of pride that rivaled the wild scenes after the Berlin Wall fell last November. With nearly 80 million people and a powerhouse economy, the reunified nation to be formed later this year will be the dominant force in Europe. East Germans, despite predictions of massive problems during a transition to a capitalist economy, have already embarked on what is likely to be the second Economic Miracle. It could become almost as dramatic as the first one that brought prosperity to postwar West Germany. ``After eight years of uninterrupted expansion, the West German economy does not give any sign of running out of steam,'' said the respected French newspaper Le Monde. All this comes at a time when Germans are working less and enjoying life more. One powerful labor union in May won a landmark contract that provides for phasing in a 35-hour work week.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Chemical Plant Still Out of Operation, But Some Workers Returning
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half of the Arco Chemical Co. plant employees were returning to work today but the plant remained out of operation as investigators tried to determine what caused an explosion that killed 17 workers last week. About 150 of the plant's 350 workers were told to return to work, said Gerald Davis, Arco Chemical spokesman. ``We'll just bring some administrators in,'' Davis said. ``Other employees will be out until a judgment is made about the safety at the plant and we will continue to pay their salaries and try to keep them informed about what's happening in the plant.'' The sprawling plant complex will be brought back into operation in phases that could span several months, Davis said. Company officials and representatives from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration toured the crumbled remains of a block-long area of the 564-acre chemical plant on Sunday. Seventeen workers from Arco and contractors Austin Industrial Inc. and Waste Processers Industries Inc. were killed Thursday night when a wastewater tank exploded in a fireball. Investigators have been unable to determine the cause of the blast. The widow of a millwright killed Thursday said her husband called her a half hour before the plant blew up, saying workers restarting equipment there were afraid it might explode. Lori Davis said her husband, Michael Davis, said they were afraid to restart a compressor that they had fixed. ``They thought it might blow,'' Mrs. Davis said. Harold Sorgenti, president and chief executive officer of Arco Chemical, earlier said workers were repairing an electric compressor near a 900,000-gallon wastewater treatment tank when the explosion occurred. The tank separates hydrocarbons from water and then a compressor pumps the sometimes volatile vapors into a pipeline where impurities can be removed before releasing the gases to the atmosphere, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Pioneer Treated For Chest Pains
DOC.TEXT: Pioneering transplant surgeon Dr. Thomas E. Starzl was in fair condition today at Presbyterian-University Hospital after complaining of chest pains, said a hospital spokesman. Starzl, 64, was admitted Sunday afternoon to the hospital's cardiac unit, where the surgeon underwent tests on his heart function, said hospital spokesman Frank Raczkiewicz. Starzl had a heart catheterization, said hospital spokeswoman Lisa Rossi. In the procedure, a tube is passed through blood vessels to the heart to withdraw blood samples or measure pressures in veins, arteries and the heart's main chambers. Starzl, who has no history of heart problems, was alert and resting, Raczkiewicz said. Starzl helped create one of the world's leading transplant centers at Presbyterian-University, which is affiliated with the University of Pittsburgh. In 1967, Starzl performed the world's first successful liver transplant. In 1984, he and another surgeon performed the world's first successful liver-heart transplant on Stormie Jones, a Texas girl who since has undergone a second liver transplant.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Supporters Barricade Streets to Support Strike
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Nicaraguans armed with clubs and machetes built street barricades with paving stones early today in support of a week-old strike against the government's economic policies. A warning was broadcast every half-hour on state Radio Nicaragua, saying police would act harshly against those causing disorder, but there were no signs of intervention by security forces. Some of Managua's main streets were blocked, bringing the capital to a virtual standstill. In the low-income eastern neighborhoods, protesters passed paving stones from hand to hand to build barricades and burned huge bonfires of old tires. A cloud of malodorous smoke hung low over Managua at dawn. Associated Press reporters touring trouble spots overnight were unable to return to their homes. ``Everyone must return to work today and those who do not will be fired,'' President Violetta Barrios de Chamorro warned in the radio broadcasts. The scene was reminiscent of Managua 11 years ago when the former Sandinista government built similar barricades at the height of their revolution against former dictator Gen. Anastasio Somoza. It was in the eastern neighborhoods that some of the most intense fighting took place during the 1979 revolution and where Sandinista support is still the strongest. The Sandinistas remain the largest political grouping in Nicaragua. Strike leaders say 80,000 workers are taking part in the walkouts called in part to protest massive firings by the Chamorro government. Workers also want a greater voice in setting economic policy. Unions threatened to interrupt electrical service and international flights if the government did not agree to their demands by today. The strikes are directed against government offices, public transportation, telephone and mail services and state-run agriculture, construction and textile businesses. Talks to end the walkouts collapsed Friday and the government declared them illegal. The government has said the strikes are politically motivated. Hope that ran high when Mrs. Chamorro took office 10 weeks ago has faded as Nicaraguans realized the econmomic crisis and bitter political divisions would not disappear quickly. The government has said tough measures are needed to rescue the crumbling economy, including cuts in government subsidies, higher utility rates, privatizing state enterprises and the return of land confiscated under the Sandinistas. A similar strike by Nicaragua's top-heavy public sector brought the country to a standstill in May. Strikers won major concessions, including pay raises of 100 percent. Nicaragua's economy has been battered by almost a decade of war between the former Sandinistas and the now disbanded U.S.-backed Contra rebels. At least 50,000 people died in that conflict. Mrs. Chamorro defeated Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega in the Feb. 25 elections. She is trying to reverse his party's centralized government policy and replace it with free-market strategy.

DOC.HEAD: Memorial Planned For Oft-Forgotten Virginian
DOC.TEXT: Admirers of George Mason say he gets no respect, despite serving alongside Thomas Jefferson, George Washington and James Madison as architects of the Constitution. Unlike his fellow Virginians, Mason never became president, and no national monument was ever raised to his memory. Mason fans are working to redress what they say is a nearly 200-year-old wrong by erecting a memorial to him, perhaps fittingly in the shadow of the Jefferson Memorial in Washington, D.C. It seems Mason's refusal to sign the Constitution he helped create vexed his contemporaries enough that he was nearly written out of the history books. ``George Mason has been the forgotten patriot all along,'' said Donald R. Taylor, director of Gunston Hall, Mason's meticulously restored plantation on the Potomac River, near Washington's Mount Vernon home. ``It seems that although Mason played a very central role in creating what resulted in our federal form of government, he has gotten bad press because he refused to sign the completed document,'' Taylor said. Mason's main beef with the Constitution? It contained no bill of rights. Mason believed a rib of the new nation's government must be protection for its citizens should that government turn hostile, Taylor said. He also raised a few hackles in a losing battle to ban further imports of slaves. ``He really was ahead of his time in many respects,'' Taylor said. An anti-federalist, Mason tangled frequently with Madison and Jefferson over the key issue of local control versus centralized power. On most points, Mason lost. In the end he was one of only three delegates to the 1787 constitutional convention who refused to sign. Mason died in 1792, one year after the Bill of Rights was added to the Constitution. The 10 amendments closely resemble a bill of rights for Virginia that Mason drafted in 1776. Taylor would like to install the modest sculpture honoring Mason next year, the bicentennial of the Bill of Rights. The site selected by Taylor's group is a somewhat remote plot near the Tidal Basin. A bed of flowers and small stone fountain now occupy it. State Sen. Joseph V. Gartlan Jr. prodded the legislature to contribute $100,000 to build the memorial. Another $150,000 is being raised by the Gunston Hall Board of Regents. A Virginia sculptor's blueprints call for a pair of 15-foot bronze pyramids mounted inside the fountain. Quotes from Mason and a carving of him would surround the pool. ``It is low-key, but very symbolic,'' Taylor said. One pyramid would have 16 striations, representing the 16 articles of the Virginia Declaration of Rights. The other would have 10 for the 10 amendments in the Bill of Rights, he said. A previous effort to honor Mason did little to rescue him from obscurity. In the 1950s, a span of the 14th Street Bridge over the Potomac was renamed for Mason. An unofficial survey of Virginia commuters who use the bridge daily shows the nomenclature is almost universally ignored. ``It's named for who?'' asked one woman. Taylor has heard this before. ``There are plenty of people in Virginia and elsewhere who have never heard of him,'' Taylor said. That's despite the growing presence of George Mason University, a state university in Fairfax County. The memorial project has cleared most official hurdles, although Congress still must approve the plan. Sen. Charles S. Robb, D-Va., is leading that effort, which has attracted no opposition. If Congress misses next year's date, the installation could be keyed to the 200th anniversary of Mason's death in 1992, Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Warship Calls in Portsmouth
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet destroyer Bezuprechny fired a 21-gun salute Monday to herald its arrival in Portsmouth, where it was the first Soviet warship to call in 14 years. ``Even recently, I could hardly imagine myself conducting a press conference in Portsmouth, the main naval base of the Royal Navy, but time changes everything,'' Rear Admiral Vasily Yeremin, northern fleet squadron commander, told reporters. The destroyer's visit follows last year's visit by the British destroyer HMS Bristol to Leningrad. During the Bezuprechny's five-day visit, the squadron's band will give two concerts and crew members will compete with Royal Navy teams in soccer, volleyball and target shooting, the Royal Navy said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Official Paul Laurent Dies
DOC.TEXT: Paul Laurent, a senior official of the French Communist Party, has died of cancer, the party announced. He was 65. Laurent, who died Sunday, was secretary of the party's Central Committee, a member of its Political Bureau and a close ally of party leader Georges Marchais. He also was one of three Communists on the Paris City Council. Last year, he led the Communists in negotiations with the governing Socialists to coordinate leftist candidacies in municipal elections. Born May 1, 1925, Laurent joined the Communist Party at age 20. He led the party's youth movement from 1954 to 1962, and joined the Central Committee along with Marchais in 1956. He was considered a relative liberal within the party and was credited with expanding members' freedom of expression. The party did not announce funeral arrangements and gave no information about survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Criticized For Predicting Future Quake in Tehran
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper criticized an earthquake expert Monday for predicting that a strong temblor will rock the Iranian capital, and said such reports only create panic. The newspaper, Abrar, lamented that ``this rumor is being spread at a time when people are still deeply saddened by the recent earthquake in Gilan and Zanjan provinces.'' The report was quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus. More than 40,000 people died in the June 21 earthquake in northeastern Iran, centered about 125 miles from the capital. In an interview with another newspaper, Kayhan, the head of the seismological institute at Tehran University said there was a strong possibility of an earthquake in Tehran. The official, Bahram Akkasheh, did not say when the earthquake might strike. Tehran is in a seismologically active area, and the official's prediction was in line with what other experts have said both inside and outside Iran. Abrar said the news media should inform the people, not create anxiety and panic among them, IRNA reported.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Spreads to Three Cities; Five Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with second death, government protesting U.S. action; EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT:
Anti-government violence fueled by an aborted pro-democracy rally spread across the nation today and police used gunfire and tear gas in clashes with protesters. Two people were reported killed. The death brought to at least five the number of people reported killed since the disturbances began Saturday when police used gunfire and tear gas to stop thousands from rallying. Protesters tried to rally after the government detained at least 12 pro-democracy activists last week. The U.S. Embassy confirmed today that it had given asylum to one activist who went into hiding. The government made its first comment on the rioting in a statement that condemned the United State's decision to give refuge to Kuria and U.S. suggestions that Kenya consider political pluralism. ``The government of Kenya wishes to protest in the strongest terms against this unwarranted interference in Kenya's international affaris by the embassy of a friendly country,'' the statement said. ``The choice of what kind of political system Kenyans want ... cannot be forced upon the people of this country by anybody and neither can it be brought by the kind of violence, hooliganism and lawlessness which was witnessed in certain parts of Nairobi last weekend,'' it said. A spokesman said the U.S. Embassy had no immediate comment on the protest. Today marked the first time the violence spread outside Nairobi. Clashes between demonstrators and police were reported in Nakuru, Muranga and Nyeri, all north of the capital. In Ndenderu, about 10 miles north of Nairobi, police opened fire on demonstrators and shot dead an elementary school student, according to a Daily Nation newspaper photographer who witnessed the incident. The other death occurred in one of more than half a dozen low-income neighborhoods ringing the capital, where stone-throwing mobs clashed with police. Police confirmed the death but would not give details. Riot police used clubs and gunfire to break up gangs and clear open-air markets where rioters burned a bus and used boulders and burning tires to build roadblocks. Security forces and bands of demonstrators also clashed on Sunday. President Daniel arap Moi left today for Ethiopia to attend the annual Organization of African Unity summit.
He repeatedly has rejected any move toward a multiparty system, saying the existence of about 40 tribes in Kenya would invite tribal-based parties, leading to ethnic divisions and even tribal warfare. The government has reacted angrily to U.S. suggestions that it consider allowing competing political parties. At one point, the government threatened to curtail the movements of the U.S. ambassador, Smith Hempstone. Hempstone was the target of a bitter attack on Sunday in the Kenya Times, the ruling party's newspaper. In an editorial titled ``Shut Up, Mr. Ambassador,'' it threatened his expulsion. Hempstone called the editorial ``an outrageous piece of work.'' Nairobi was tense today. Shops closed and businesses shut down as people fled the city to escape further violence. Thousands left on foot because public transportation appeared to have stopped. The English-language Daily Nation newspaper said three people were killed in Sunday's disturbances. Ten people, five with gunshot wounds, were hospitalized in serious condition, and dozens of others had been wounded since the violence began Saturday, the newspaper said. Hospitals provided no official casualty figures. Shots were heard near the U.S. Embassy in downtown Nairobi. However, the gunfire did not appear directed at the American mission, which has given temporary asylum to Gibson Kamau Kuria, a prominent human rights lawyer under threat of arrest for his criticism of Kenya's one-party rule. Kuria, a former detainee who in 1988 won the Robert F. Kennedy human rights award, sought refuge at the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi early Saturday, according to a statement released by the embassy today. ``He came on his own and asked for temporary refuge,'' the statement said. ``He expressed a desire to leave the country. We are discussing this matter with the government of Kenya.'' Kuria, 43, went into hiding Thursday following a wave of arrests in which Kenya's most prominent proponents of multiparty democracy were seized. The United States is a major donor to Kenya, whose economy is heavily dependent on foreign aid. Last year the U.S. gave $61 million in economic aid and $15 million in military assistance, according to a study prepared by The Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Titanic Inquiry after 78 Years
DOC.TEXT: An inquiry will be held into the conduct of a steamship captain who was criticized for not coming to the aid of the Titanic when it sank 78 years ago, the government said Monday. The Titanic sank after striking an iceberg in the North Atlantic on April 14, 1912. More than 1,500 of the 2,200 people aboard the ship perished. The Marine Accident Investigation Branch will examine testimony at the 1912 inquiry into the loss of the great liner to throw light on the role of the late Capt. Stanley Lord, said a Department of Transport spokeswoman. The inquiry comes in response to a campaign by Lord's relatives, who have been trying to clear his name, said the spokeswoman. She spoke on condition of anonymity. The inquiry was first reported in Monday's editions of The Daily Telegraph, which said a crucial piece of evidence would be the position of the wreck as determined in 1985 by U.S. oceanographer Robert Ballard. Lord was master of the Boston-bound Californian, believed to have been the ship nearest to the Titanic when it struck the iceberg. The Carpathia and other ships which were farther away than the Californian did reach the scene in answer to the stricken liner's distress calls. Lord's ship was stopped by ice at the time. The original inquiry censured him for not responding to distress rockets from the Titanic and ruled that as he was 8 to 10 miles from the liner he could have gone to its aid and saved lives. Lord died in 1962, claiming to the end that the Titanic was in an icefield 20 miles or more from his ship and that he was unable to help. A campaign to clear his name has been carried on by his son and other supporters, and an earlier petition to reopen the inquiry was rejected in 1965. Lord insisted that a ship seen from the Californian was not the Titanic. The ship was only identified in 1962 as the Samson, a seal-hunter. ``Supporters of Capt. Lord claimed he was a scapegoat for the failire of the Titanic's owners and the Board of Trade to make sure there were enough lifeboats,'' The Daily Telegraph said. It quoted Capt. James de Coverley, deputy chief of marine accidents, as saying the 1912 inquiry would not be reopened as that had been into the Titanic's loss, not Lord's conduct. ``We are not in the business of rewriting history but in this particular case it was considered desirable to have a re-evaluation,'' de Coverley was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Government Names Team To Negotiate With Lithuania
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Monday took its first concrete step toward negotiating the independence of Lithuania by naming a team of top representatives for the talks. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov to head the 22-member Soviet team, according to the official Tass news agency. The delegation was ordered to negotiate with the Baltic republic in connection with its 100-day moratorium on a March 11 declaration of independence. The freeze takes effect only at the start of negotiaions. Ceslovas Jursenas, a spokesman for Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, said he thought preliminary talks could start within 10 days. Most of the Soviet officials named to the delegation are currently involved in the 28th Soviet Communist Party Congress, scheduled to end this week. The Lithuanian parliament will vote as soon as Tuesday on its team, from a list of nominees put forward by its Presidium, said another aide to Mrs. Prunskiene. The high-powered Soviet team includes First Deputy Minister Yuri Maslyukov, head of the central planning agency Gosplan; Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin; army chief of staff Mikhail Moiseyev; and deputy KGB chief Filipp Bobkov, Tass reported. The Soviet delegation also includes top officials dealing with aviation, nationalities, communications and finance _ an indication of how complicated a process it will be to unravel relations between Lithuania and the Soviet Union. On June 29, Lithuania decided on the 100-day moratorium on its declaration of independence in return for an immediate end to an economic blockade and the start of negotiations on its demands. Moscow had cut off almost all oil, most natural gas and numerous other items on April 18 to try to force Lithuania to rescind its declaration. Lithuania, an independent republic between the two world wars, was forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940 along with the other two Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia. The Lithuanian government is preparing documents asking Moscow to suspend its mandatory military draft of Lithuanian youth, Jursenas said. It also wants Moscow to pledge that it will not interfere with efforts to establish direct economic contacts with other Soviet republics.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Helps Alaska Firefighters, Main Fire Slows Rampage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE on higher acreage count, ADDS quotes. Picks up 6th graf, `The Tok ...' SUBS last graf to UPDATE with higher acreage count.
DOC.TEXT: Scattered rain and cooler temperatures helped slow the spread of wildfires that have charred more than 550,000 acres of timber, but 2,100 firefighters remained on the job. No lives or homes have been lost to the more than 200 fires across the state, most sparked by lightning strikes. There have been no reports of arson, authorities said. Firefighters from all over the United States were attacking the 43 worst fires, aided by 34 helicopters and 11 air tankers dropping fire retardant. The cooling trend allowed firefighters to get close enough to flames to begin taking the offensive, said Bureau of Land Management spokesman Rob McWhorter. By early today, more than 550,000 acres of forest and tundra had been consumed by wildfires, an increase of more than 200,000 acres from Saturday, when 23 new fires were started after 2,600 recorded lightning strikes, officials said. ``There's so many fires and Alaska's so big, there's still a day and a half to two-day lag in mapping fires and coming up with acreages,'' said Frank Carroll, with the Fire Information Center in Fairbanks. ``Alaska makes Texas look like a very small place.'' The Tok fire remained a top priority, because it still was considered a potential threat to people and buildings if winds changed and hot summer temperatures returned. The Tok airport reopened to civilian air traffic Sunday as the fire that swept near the town moved toward the village of Tetlin, 20 miles away, McWhorter said. The village of 60 residents wasn't immediately threatened by the blaze, but firefighters were monitoring winds to see which way flames would blow, he said. Crews using bulldozers nearly finished digging a fire line around Tok, a southeastern Alaska town of 1,200 residents located at the junction of the Alaska and Glenn highways that have been closed off and on since last week. Thirty smokejumpers on Sunday parachuted near a fire threatening cabins on the Yukon River about 15 miles from the crossing of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline. Cabins were threatened by the 3,000-acre Cassiar Creek Fire about 50 miles from Fairbanks. The Beaver fire, named after a village within 10 miles of the flames, was estimated to have charred almost 200,000 acres by today, Carroll said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Census Workers Lose Unemployment Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Many of the temporary workers taking the nation's census may be ineligible for unemployment compensation when their jobs end because of a recent money-saving change in the law. The actual number of people affected is hard to estimate because rules for unemployment compensation eligibility vary from state to state. Neither congressional or census spokesmen would estimate the number affected. In the past, temporary census jobs have counted toward eligibility for unemployment compensation just as any other job. However, this year an appropriations bill signed by President Bush on May 25 set an April 20 cutoff on census workers getting credit toward unemployment. Temporary census work done after that date doesn't count when they are eventually laid off and apply for unemployment benefits. How that cutoff affects individual workers depends on the unemployment eligibility rules in their states. Some states, for example, require 26 weeks of work before someone becomes eligible. People who haven't accumulated that before April 20 would not be able to collect benefits. April 20 was the deadline for people sending in their mailed census forms, meaning the credit cutoff applies primarily to the thousands of temporary field workers who were sent door-to-door to track down people who did not apply. Much of that work has now been finished, although follow-up operations are expected to continue at least through fall in some areas. Warren Kane of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which inserted the provision into a financial bill, said the action made $70 million available for completing the national head count. The low response rate to the mailed portion of the census meant more staff had to be hired to go door to door, and the committee had to find money to cover that hiring. In looking at census finances, he said, the committee found that when the bureau hired temporary workers it was setting money aside to cover their later unemployment costs when the jobs ended. By cutting off unemployment credit at April 20 the committee eliminated the need for those funds, which then became available for hiring more temporary workers, Kane said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Wins Vote Giving Him a Reformist Politburo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs with Gorbachev winning vote on Politburo makeup; pickup 18th graf pvs, `On Sunday...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won a critical behind-the-scenes struggle today for a new Communist Party Politburo that is expected to champion his reforms and push for a looser federation of the Soviet republics. The party congress voted to require the Politburo to consist of the general secretary, his deputy and the first secretaries of the parties of the 15 republics. The change guarantees that the small group of primarily Russian men who traditionally ruled the Soviet Union would be replaced by largely pro-reform, non-Russian Communists. Most of the republic party leaders want the political sovereignty, market economy and looser union of states advocated by Gorbachev. The change also allows Gorbachev to bypass the 250-member Central Committee, expected to be heavily conservative when the congress elects it later this week. The congress is expected to elect Gorbachev to continue as general secretary, despite vitriolic criticism of his political and economic reforms from delegates at the largely conservative party congress. Some delegates said he may be allowed to virtually hand-pick his deputy, although the congress officially elects the person when it meets once in five years. A weary-looking Gorbachev took the floor of the 28th party congress this afternoon after hammering his proposal through four hours of ``heated'' discussions in committee. After making his announcement, Gorbachev sat down next to the temporary chairman of the party congress, parliamentary chairman Anatoly Lukyanov, and urged quietly, ``Let's vote.'' The key vote on changing the Politburo membership to include the republic leaders was 3,325 to 839. Gorbachev told delegates that others could be added to the Politburo by the Central Committee from among its members. But the final rules did not mention this.
