The new rule could completely change the Politburo membership because none of the 15 republic party chiefs are now members of the 12-man body. Seven of the 12 men on the current Politburo already have said they will resign or have hinted of the possibility. Any decentralization, and particularly the looser union of sovereign republics now under discussion, would give the republics more power over their own affairs. Most republic leaders also believe their areas will fare far better under a market economy than under continued central planning, which they blame for sucking dry their republics' resources and giving little in return. Gorbachev said the new structure would allow the 15 republic parties ``to act independently, and to really influence the Central Committee and Politburo.'' The current 12-man Politburo has only two non-Russian members: Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, from the republic of Georgia, and Ukrainian President Vladimir Ivashko. There is but one non-Russian, Latvian Boris Pugo, among the seven non-voting members of the Politburo. The congress was expected to take nominations for general secretary later in the day. On Sunday, Gorbachev who has been the party general secretary since 1985, faced tough questioning at a meeting of workers and farmers attending the congress as non-voting observers. Many Soviets blame the Communists for the economic crisis and decades of institutional corruption, and the party's candidates have suffered defeat after defeat at the polls. Coal miners announced plans to stage a one-day nationwide strike Wednesday to warn party leaders they can no longer take for granted the support of the working class they claim to represent. The meeting of workers, farmers and Gorbachev was closed to foreign reporters, and Soviet media carried no details. Many of Gorbachev's remarks were conveyed by Nina Zhukova, a weaver from the Russian city of Ivanovo. She said she sat near Gorbachev at the meeting. Her account was confirmed by other participants interviewed on Red Square. Sergei Sotnikov, a party official from Yaroslavl, said the atmosphere was ``tense'' and included complaints about the lack of consumer goods in stores. ``They criticize me personally or the Politburo, (and debate whether) to remove us or not,'' Gorbachev reportedly said during the four-hour session. ``I will listen to it all but you will decide everything. Am I needed by you? You will decide,'' he said. Gorbachev sometimes reacts angrily to criticism, and at least four times in the past two years he has offered to resign. He told the workers and farmers that the matter was in the hands of the congress. ``I maintain only one thing: The policy that I have chosen I will pursue, and for me the biggest prize is that my homeland will live,'' he said, according to Zhukova. She said Gorbachev urged the audience to support him.

DOC.HEAD: Dealt Drugs 300 Times, Last Used Them A Month Ago: Witness Against Barry
DOC.TEXT: A key witness against Marion Barry acknowledged today that she used drugs just a month ago and said she has distributed them 300 times to about 10 people in addition to the mayor. The FBI hasn't asked for the names of her other customers, Lydia Pearson told the jury in Barry's cocaine and perjury trial. ``The only one'' of her alleged customers the FBI asked her about ``was Marion Barry?'' asked the mayor's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy. Yes, replied Pearson. She said the other customers to whom she has sold drugs numbered about 10. ``How many times'' did she distribute drugs, Mundy asked her, ``300 times, 400 times?'' ``I will say three (hundred),'' she replied. Pearson said she last used drugs June 8. She also used drugs in February days before appearing before a federal grand jury to testify in the Barry case. She acknowledged that she has been granted limited immunity from prosecution. None of her statements in the Barry case can be used against her. She testified she supplied him with crack about 25 times in a three-month span. Three bags of crack at $30 a bag was his usual purchase, she added. She described crack deliveries to Barry at two hotels and a government office building, and provided approximate dates for the alleged deliveries. Mundy had exploited the inability of former model Rasheeda Moore, an earlier witness, to recall dates of her alleged drug use with Barry over several years. Convicted cocaine dealer Charles Lewis had testified that he and the mayor used cocaine repeatedly at the Ramada Inn in December 1988. They conspired to cover up their drug use from investigators by agreeing to testify falsely to a grand jury, Lewis said. Moore testified that she and Barry used cocaine, marijuana and opium over 100 times from 1986 to 1989. She persuaded Barry to come to her hotel room in the Jan. 18 FBI sting where the mayor was videotaped smoking crack. Barry's lawyers say the mayor was the victim of entrapment and that his accusers are lying to avoid prison. Lewis was released from jail shortly before his testimony. Barry, his lawyers suggest, is merely another in a long series of black leaders targeted by the FBI. Barry, the city's mayor for nearly 12 years, pleaded innocent to 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony charges of lying to a federal grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Crime Gang Seeks Ransom for Stradivarius
DOC.TEXT: Criminals holding a 273-year-old Stradivarius violin stolen three years ago are seeking $2.5 million in ransom, an Italian newspaper reported Monday. The instrument, once owned by the last czar of Russia, Nicholas II, is believed held by an organized crime gang in Turin, according to the Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera. The instrument was stolen from French musician Pierre Annoyal in April 1987 when he was in Turin to teach a course at the European Academy of Music, the newspaper said. It was reportedly in the trunk of his car, which was stolen when he went into a shop to buy a pack of cigarettes. Police in Turin declined to discuss the case. The newspaper said a photo of the violin was recently delivered to the police by an individual known to have contacts with organized crime groups. Corriere della Sera said the ransom demand was made to the owner. It did not say how it got the information. It did not give a value for the violin but decribed it as ``priceless.''

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Lawmakers Pass Anti-Abortion Bill; Gov Takes No Immediate Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with further comment from Roemer criticizing haste of legislators' action but calling revised bill step in right direction; clarifies deadline for action. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The measure...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BT1
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer said today he was cool to way the Legislature's hastily passed anti-abortion bill was drafted but also called it a step ``in the correct direction.'' After failing to override the governor's veto of a stronger anti-abortion bill, the Legislature passed a measure Sunday that would ban most abortions and punish doctors who perform them with up to 10 years at hard labor. The law includes provisions demanded by Roemer to exempt victims of rape and incest, but he said today he wouldn't take action on it until he had read all the fine print. The bill approved Sunday night bans all abortions except those to end pregnancies that endanger a woman's life and those caused by rape or incest that is reported promptly. Despite being weaker than the bill Roemer vetoed last week, it still would be the strictest state abortion law in the nation. At a news conference today, Roemer said he was ``pleased that there was some movement in the correct direction'' but also was ``disappointed that it was a last-minute move.'' ``Not well done _ that was my feeling,'' he said. Roemer gave no timetable for acting; he has 20 days to take action. ``We'll have to read it first,'' Roemer said. ``It happened late last night. ... We have an obligation constitutionally to look at the bill and see if it does what they say it does.'' If he signs it or does nothing, it goes into effect 60 days after the end of the legislative session, which is today. If he vetoes it, the only way the legislature could revive it would be by calling itself into special session and staging yet another override vote. On Sunday, Sen. John Saunders, mastermind of the revised legislation, urged fellow legislators to ``vote for the 15,000 unborn children who are murdered in this state every year, for the 200,000 murdered in the nation. The nation is watching us.'' The measure is intended to challenge Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision recognizing the right to an abortion. Roemer had vetoed the Legislature's original bill Friday because it made no exceptions for victims of rape or incest. The bill was created by amending a flag-burning measure the Senate had refused to consider, then eliminating the flag-burning provisions, which would have reduced the penalty for beating up a flag burner to a $25 fine. The offense currently is punishable by six months in jail and a $500 fine. The maneuver, completed 30 hours before the legislative session ends at midnight tonight, enabled the Senate to circumvent the usual process of referring new legislation to a committee. ``I would have preferred a stronger bill, but we don't have the votes for an override,'' Saunders told his colleagues. The Senate vote on the bill was 32-7. Less than an hour later, the House approved the measure 83-22. The House had voted late last week to override the governor's veto of the earlier bill. The Senate on Saturday voted 23-16 to override, three votes short of the needed two-thirds majority. Both abortion-rights activists and staunch abortion foes criticized the new bill. ``We've just seen the Legislature go from the most restrictive abortion bill in the nation to the most absurd,'' said Planned Parenthood spokeswoman Terri Bartlett. ``The only thing that surpasses it is the mockery of the legislative process. Only in Louisiana could you have a flag-burning bill become an abortion bill.'' Rep. Woody Jenkins, the original bill's author, voted against the new version because ``the unborn is a human being from the moment of conception and we ought not make exceptions to the principle.'' The bill carries a penalty of one to 10 years in prison and $10,000 to $100,000 in fines for doctors who perform abortions. It would not penalize women who get abortions. The ``hard labor'' provision of the sentence means that the inmate, if medically able, would be required to perform physical work rather than clerical or cleanup duties. Louisiana's state penitentiary is a farm operation that requires field work. In the House, Rep. C.R. Jones urged colleagues to reject the bill, pleading with them to resist the intense lobbying by fundamentalist Christian groups and Roman Catholics. ``I'm concerned that religious groups have taken over in Louisiana, the South, maybe this nation,'' Jones said. Pennsylvania has the strictest state abortion law, but it is less restrictive than the Louisiana bill. The Pennslyvania measure, approved in November, bans abortions based on the fetus' sex and bans abortions after the 24th week of pregnancy except to save the life of the mother or prevent ``substantial and irreversible harm.'' A doctor convicted under the sex-selection ban or the 24-week provision could be punished with up to seven years in prison and a $15,000 fine. Portions of the law have been put on hold by a state appeals court. An even stricter abortion bill was passed in the U.S. territory of Guam. But it has been blocked for now by court challenges. That law prohibits any abortion except to save the life of the pregnant woman and makes it a felony to perform an abortion and a misdemeanor to have one.

DOC.HEAD: Plunged From Riches to Rags, Zambians Want Kaunda Out
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When former schoolteacher Kenneth Kaunda led the British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia 26 years ago, he was the head of one of Africa's richest and most stable nations. World prices for copper _ which accounts for 90 percent of Zambia's export income _ were riding high. Kaunda warmed in the glow of popular support and was hailed as the father of Zambia. The colonial rulers left him with $400 million in credit. Today, Zambia is one of the world's poorest nations. It has a $7 billion foreign debt and most of the country's 7.5 million inhabitants want the 66-year-old president to step down. ``Kaunda out, Tembo in,'' was the cry in Lusaka, the capital, and other parts of the country during last month's riots, six days of Zambia's bloodiest urban violence since independence in 1964. The imprisoned Lt.-Gen. Christon Tembo, 46, Kaunda's former army commander, has been hailed as Zambia's man of the hour. Summoned home from his job as ambassador to West Germany in October 1988, Tembo was arrested with three other officers for allegedly plotting a coup. He has been jailed ever since. His trial began last year and he has pleaded innocent to a capital charge of treason. The rioting and looting June 25-30 was fueled by state-ordered increases of 120 percent in the price of cornmeal, the nation's staple food known locally as mealie meal. At least 26 civilians were killed by police and army bullets, hundreds were wounded and more than 1,500 were arrested, mainly for violating a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Some victims were gunned down June 30 as they rejoiced near Kaunda's official residence over a state radio broadcast that the army had seized power in an overnight rebellion. The announcer was Signals Corps Lt. Mwamba Luchembe, 38, son of a Bemba tribal chief. He and three fellow officers plotted to overthrow Kaunda while the president was visiting the central province of Ndola. Luchembe and his comrades were arrested by loyalist troops at the Radio Zambia building. They face a treason trial and possible death if convicted. In the last urban unrest in December 1986 _ also over food price increases _15 people were killed by security forces. But anger then was directed at the army, not Kaunda. This time, in a dozen cities and towns, protesters demanded Kaunda's resignation, a return to old prices and a restoration of multiparty democracy, which was abolished with the imposition of a one-party state in 1972. Kaunda was defiant. ``All they can do is kill me,'' he said after he learned of the failed coup attempt. ``I will not bow to thuggery.'' Still, police guard was reinforced at State House, the curfew was extended and Kaunda cut down public appearances. ``We've had enough,'' said Lucas, a youth from Lusaka's Chilenje township, who clutched rocks in both hands at the height of the anti-government riots. ``It's time for him to go.'' Like most Zambians interviewed, Lucas spoke on condition of anonymity. Dorothy Mubanga, a primary school teacher, is a typical Zambian who suffered from the government decision to lift subsidies on cornmeal and more than double its price. The move was part of a package of economic austerity proposals made by the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and Western nations, Zambia's main creditors. At least two-fifths of export income is sapped by debt repayments. Mubanga earns about $32.50 a month, from which she has to buy at least two bags of mealie meal, which now costs $13.45. On top of other food purchases such as sugar, meat, tea, bread, and vegetables, she must pay rent for her small suburban house and bus fares to work and back, leaving her without a cent to spare. Her two brothers _ like most unemployed Zambians _ try to make ends meet by selling smuggled goods from Botswana and South Africa on Lusaka's black market. Even well-off Zambians expressed sympathy for the rioters and dismay with the president. However, Kaunda has refused to make any significant concessions. Instead, he promised to crack down on ``coup plotters'' and ``thugs.'' Some 5,000 students from the University of Zambia, who led the week of violence, have been sent home. But Kaunda did seize on the troubles to announce a national referendum on whether to revive political pluralism. The ruling United National Independence Party grudgingly agreed to put the issue to a vote in March, but only after Kaunda declared he feared democracy would plunge the country into tribal conflicts. If the referendum is free and fair, Zambians are expected to snub their head of state and opt for the multiparty system used by the British colonists prior to independence, observers say.

DOC.HEAD: Majority Of French No Longer Drink Wine, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: For the first time, most French people say they never drink wine, according to a study published Monday by a wine industry organization. The number of people who drink wine every day also dropped sharply, from 32.5 percent in 1980 to 18.5 percent this year, the study showed. The nationwide survey of 4,000 people was conducted in March and April by the National Interprofessional Office of Wine, which represents various associations of winemakers and sellers. Participants were asked about the drinking habits of all adults in their household, and the responses reflected the practices of 12,400 people, the organization said. No margin of error was given. In a 1980 survey conducted by the group, 38.7 percent of the respondents said they never drink wine. That percentage climbed to 45.1 in 1985 and to 50.7 this year. Wine consumption varies sharply by sex, according to the survey. It said 10.9 percent of the women and 28.1 percent of the men identified themselves as daily wine drinkers. Asked why they didn't drink wine, 73.4 percent of the respondents said they didn't like it and 25.3 percent cited health concerns. The beverage most commonly chosen to replace wine at the dinner table was water, the study found.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Leaders Face Tough Decision on Aid to Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 new grafs after pvs 4th graf bgng, Even more, to include plan to send experts to Soviet Union.
DOC.TEXT: A year ago, the idea would have been unthinkable. Now it is the most compelling question to confront these leaders of the Western world: Should they dig into their deep pockets to help the Soviet Union and Mikhail S. Gorbachev? The risk of saying no could be the failure of perestroika _ the ambitious restructuring of the Soviet system _ and Gorbachev's downfall. But saying yes has its perils, too, since it would mean pouring billions into an economic morass that has resisted five years of Gorbachev reforms. But ``Where would we be if he were chucked out?'' Brian Mulroney, the Canadian prime minister, wondered aloud on Sunday as he and leaders of the six other richest nations gathered for their annual economic summit. Still, Mulroney himself isn't ready to provide direct help just now. Even more skeptical is President Bush, who received Gorbachev's plea for help in his role as summit host. The President questions the wisdom of assisting the Kremlin while it provides $5 billion a year to Marxist Cuba, spends about one-quarter of its budget on the military and has put few free-market procedures into play. At a very minimum, the seven leaders are expected to send a team of experts to the Soviet Union to assess its economic problems. If the summit produces nothing more for Gorbachev than that, it would hardly amount to a ringing endorsement. Gorbachev knows he has problems. They are everywhere. And he wants help. As the summit opened today, the issue was completely up in the air. There was no decisive majority for or against helping Gorbachev to overcome an ossified economic system that makes the Soviet Union an unpopular trade partner and faint source of relief to deprived and depressed consumers. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, with a strong assist from French President Francois Mitterrand, wants to put together a $15 billion aid package for Gorbachev. They are the strongest advocates of direct assistance. Bush has ``big problems'' with the concept, he said at the NATO summit meeting last week in London. So does Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan. He reiterated last Friday it would ``not be possible'' for Japan to participate in economic assistance to Moscow until the Soviets resolved a 45-year territorial dispute over four islands in the Kuril peninsula. The split is fundamental. According to a well-placed U.S. official it is so deep the seven governments have not even decided whether to deal with aid to Moscow in their summit-ending declarations later his week. Decisions on virtually all the other items on the summit agenda await only the leaders' pro forma approval. They have been worked over by experts since the last summit in Paris. But aiding the Soviet Union is the vexing exception. It isn't the first time in the 16 years of economic summits that a solution to a tough issue had to be hammered out in hard bargaining at the summit itself. In 1983, the last time the United States played host, President Reagan held out at Williamsburg, Va., for a declaration demanding the Soviets negotiate the withdrawal of their intermediate-range nuclear missiles from Asia as well as Europe. Japan, of course, backed Reagan, and the president prevailed. Four years later, he signed a treaty with Gorbachev for the destruction of all U.S. and Soviet medium-range missiles _ in Asia as well as in Europe. At the Tokyo summit in 1987 a strong declaration against terrorism emerged from heated debate among the leaders. The decision was not pre-cooked by the aides, known popularly as ``sherpas.'' It was taken by the leaders, themselves. And last year, tough bargaining at the table in Paris produced the decision to set up a group of 24 nations to channel assistance to Poland and Hungary, which were shaking free from the Soviet orbit. Only last week in Paris, the 24 countries decided to expand their program to Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. At this point, said the U.S. official who discussed the issue on condition he not be identified, the three most likely ways of resolving the Soviet aid problem at the summit are these: _Declaring each of the seven nations can decide for itself whether to help Gorbachev. That would mean Bush and Kaifu would not stand in the way of Kohl and Mitterrand while maybe helping the Soviets in less dramatic ways, such as with technical advice. _Appointing a panel to study the issue. That would give the leaders possibly a year to make their minds up while monitoring how Gorbachev proceeds with his experimentation with capitalistic ways. _Setting out conditions in the declaration for direct aid to Moscow. They could include requirements for less military spending and a reduction or cutoff of aid to Cuba. Only a few months ago, when Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., proposed a package of direct U.S. aid to rescue Gorbachev, the Congressman was ridiculed by administration officials and some of Bush's strongest supporters, such as Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. But now, it is a real possibility, causing Bush to think hard about the consequences if the Soviet leader falls. Canada's Mulroney stressed that theme, saying ``If he were chucked out by some of the extreme right influences we see at play in the Soviet party conference that is ongoing in Moscow today, I think we would be at an infinitely worse position than we are today.'' And yet, Mulroney called Soviet aid to Cuba ``profoundly unacceptable'' and an obstacle to Western aid. He said Canada was willing at this point to provide trade credits, not direct assistance. Meanwhile, Douglas Hurd, the British foreign secretary, left no doubt where the Margaret Thatcher's government stands. The summit's message to Moscow, he said, should be ``mend the hole in the pants before you fill the pockets with dimes and cents.'' But no one doubts that a lot more than small change is at stake.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the AP's chief diplomatic c

DOC.HEAD: Residents Want Mary's Little Lamb Back
DOC.TEXT: Authorities can't find rhyme or reason to the theft of a statue commemorating the little lamb that followed 19th-century resident Mary Sawyer to school one day. The heist has vexed some residents who believe they've been robbed of a piece of history. ``I can't understand anybody taking it,'' said Karen Gaylord, a 20-year resident and part-time spokeswoman for the Sterling Police Department. ``It has great historical value to the town, but it's not something that you could sell.'' The concrete statute of the lamb hads stood on the town common since the early 1960s and was a fixture of this central Massachusetts town of 6,000, said Ruth Hopfmann of the Sterling Historical Society. ``Innumerable people have stopped and gotten out of the car with their children to see what the little animal was. It really has attracted a lot of attention over the past 30 years,'' she said. Police theorize vandals removed the statue by rocking it back and forth. The legs already were crumbling at the base, Gaylord said. The statue was taken during the night of July 1, and a search has revealed no clues, she said. ``We've been in dumpsters and behind buildings. We've been everywhere,'' she said. The society already was planning a new statue and has raised about $7,000 toward that, but Mrs. Hopfmann said residents had hoped to install the original version among the society's collection of artifacts. The statue was donated in 1962 by summer resident Alfred Altman, who was president of the National Dairymen's Association in New York. The legend dates to about 1816, when Mary Elizabeth Sawyer's little lamb followed her to school, Mrs. Hopfmann said. The child hid the lamb under her desk but when she went to the front of the class it followed her, was discovered and banished to a shed. John Roulstone, a young man visiting the school that day commemorated the event with three verses and in 1830 those were included in a book of poems compiled by magazine editor Sarah Josepha Hale, who added several more verses to the nursery rhyme. The lamb met with the sad fate of being gored by a cow, but its fleece lived on in the form of two pairs of stockings. The legend resurfaced in 1883 when Mary Sawyer, seeking to raise money to save Boston's Old South Church, sold cards carrying the story of the verse and wrapped with pieces of yarn from the unraveled stockings.

DOC.HEAD: Children Found After Allegedly Kidnapped By Alien Smugglers
DOC.TEXT: Alien smugglers abducted two children in a dispute over the $400 fee for sneaking them into the United States, police said. The youngsters were later rescued. Two men snatched Maria Morales, 11, and Nasario Morales, 9, off a downtown street Sunday after their mother told the smugglers she could not pay them the agreed-upon fee for bringing the children from Mexico, police said. Officers found the children several hours later, said Detective Dick Heidesch. They and several other suspected illegal immigrants were held by alien smugglers in a house but escaped by jumping out a window, he said. They were reunited with their mother, Ernestina Cruz Bautista, who apparently is in the United States legally, Heidesch said. Two people were arrested for investigation of kidnapping for ransom, he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Farmers, Steers Voice A Beef With Bush, But Without Tractors
DOC.TEXT: Fifty-five farm advocates and a pair of well-behaved longhorn steers paraded next to Rice University Monday, but the protest's tractors, like so many in summit-snarled Houston, got stuck in traffic. The group of farmers and environmentalists said they had a beef with President Bush's efforts toward an agriculture trade agreement, one issue on the table at the seven-nation economic summit. Motorcades and street-closings made a mess of usually congested Houston arteries Monday morning, and a half-mile stroll down Fannin Street by Redbone and Tumbleweed, two 1,400-pound farm advocates from Barker, Texas, only made the going slower. A dozen tractors from outlying farm communities never made it inside Houston's freeway loop, organizer Craig Merrilees said. The demonstrators claimed Bush's plan for agriculture under a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade would undercut prices for American farmers, and allow imports of cheaper foods grown with pesticides not allowed in the United States. ``It is the final nail in the coffin of the family farmer, and it may be the final nail in all our coffins,'' said Lana Nelson, daughter of country singer Willie Nelson. Bush has been pushing for a plan to phase-out farm subsidies over the next 10 years. Europeans have been resisting the idea, which doesn't sit well with small-scale American farmers, either. Carl King, corn cobs pictured on his tie, said farmers would accept a GATT agreement ``if its fair.'' ``If we open everything up, there will be no fairness involved because you're going to be competing with farms that have peon labor overseas and that don't have to deal with regulations from OSHA or EPA,'' King said. ``We just want to see the farmers get their price from the marketplace,'' said Don Vig, a Valley City, N.D., farmer with the National Family Farm Coalition. ``But we object to the way Bush wants to do it.'' The steers, sporting gold finials on their horns, were the centerpiece of the ragtag, half-mile march down one lane of traffic. Houston parks officials wouldn't allow the hungry animals on the grass of Hermann Park, so they kept to the street. A few German and Japanese farmers joined the march. ``With GATT, you tear down all the barriers that protect a people's own culture, and the farmers are the first to be hit,'' said Pieter Bricke, a Bonn economist who marched with his wife, Johanna, a farmer.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas School District Takes Quake Prediction Seriously
DOC.TEXT: A northeast Arkansas school district is taking a forecaster's prediction to heart and has tentatively planned an early December earthquake break. The South Mississippi County School District No. 57 won't hold classes on Dec. 3-4, if the school board approves, in deference to climatologist Iben Browning's prediction of a major earthquake along the New Madrid Fault during that time. Browning claims to have accurately predicted last fall's Northern California earthquake within one day. He also says he correctly predicted the 1971 earthquake in California's San Fernando Valley, a deadly earthquake in Nicaragua in 1972 and eruption of the Mount St. Helens volcano in 1980. South Mississippi County Superintendent Harvey Barton said he is taking Browning seriously. Browning has predicted a quake for Dec. 2 or 3, a Sunday and Monday. The district, north of Memphis, Tenn., has canceled classes on Dec. 3 and 4. It will use that time for staff development days mandated by the state Department of Education, Barton said. ``Because we are a large rural area covering approximately 400 square miles, transporting students would be a hardship if we should have an earthquake,'' Barton said. The New Madrid seismic zone stretches roughly from northeast Arkansas northward to southern Illinois. Communities that make up the South Mississippi County School District are within 30 miles of Marked Tree, the center of a series of great earthquakes measuring as high as 8.5 on the Richter scale that rocked the area during the winter of 1811-12. U.S. Geological Survey scientists consider those the strongest series of quakes in the nation's recorded history.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Condemns Rebel Call for Renewed Violence
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday that it condemned a call for stepped up military action from leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. The rebels said Saturday that a renewed offensive was needed to end El Salvador's long civil war. ``Cynicism and illogic underpin this appalling announcement,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said. ``We condemn it unequivocally. There is no explanation or excuse for returning to violence.'' Boucher said a renewal of violence ``would be the ultimate show of bad faith'' and could destroy negotiations for a settlement of the war. ``Peace requires an end to the bloodshed, not more violence,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Youngest of Widely Known Perricone Quadruplets Dies
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Perricone, the youngest of the world's first documented male quadruplets to survive, has died at age 60. Perricone died Sunday at a Nederland hospital after a heart attack, said his brother Donald. Bernard, Donald, Anthony and Carl Perricone were born on Halloween night, 1929, in a Beaumont farmhouse without electricity. Their parents, immigrants from Italy, already had five sons and had hoped for a girl. The Perricone quads were only the second documented quadruplets in the country. All four served in the same unit of the Army for seven months in Korea after receiving special permission arranged by then-Sen. Lyndon B. Johnson. Army policy normally prohibits brothers from serving in the same unit. Following military service, all four worked for Pure Oil Co., which has become Union Oil. After Bernard retired from the refinery's clerical department, he managed a warehouse with his wife, Mildred, until his death. He is survived by his wife, eight brothers, including Anthony, Donald and Carl, and three children. Services were scheduled for Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Huddles with Mitterrand, Kohl As Economic Summit Convenes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 5 grafs with Bush remarks, FOR RELEASE AT 3:15 P.M. EDT, picking up in 2nd graf pvs, Bush met
DOC.TEXT: President Bush welcomed leaders of the world's major industrial democracies to the economic summit Monday with a charge to work for ``new stability and prosperity'' in a world ``where all that seems possible is possible.'' Bush conferred privately with French President Francois Mitterrand and then with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl before the mid-afternoon formal opening of the summit. In remarks prepared the afternoon ceremony, Bush said, ``These economic summits have become a framework for frank, constructive dialogue, a dialogue for progress that I believe will be advanced greatly in these next three days.'' ``Together we are called upon as allies and as friends to work toward decisions here in Houston that will bring new stability and prosperity to the world, by tapping the power and energy of free wills and free markets,'' Bush said. He said, ``A new world of freedom lies before us, hopeful, confident, a world where peace endures, where commerce has conscience, where all that seems possible is possible. So let us begin, in good faith, to set the stage for the new millennium.'' Bush met first with Mitterrand, giving Kohl a little more time to rest up from his overnight flight from Rome, where he watched the West German 1-0 triumph over Argentina in Sunday's World Cup final. Bush later greeted Kohl with a jaunty thumbs-up, saying, ``Welcommen! Hail the champions of football.' ``World champions! It's a big win for Germany,'' said Bush, who later boasted that Bush had played soccer himself on a championship team at Yale in the 1940s. Mitterrand flew the speedier Concorde to Houston this morning, then flew by helicopter to the Bayou Club, a polo field near Bush's Houstonian Hotel. After a short motorcade, Bush was waiting to greet Mitterrand at the Houstonian's Manor House, but both leaders declined to answer reporters' questions about whether the Western allies can forge a common position on bailing out the Soviets' stumbling economy. As they sat across a table in a cool, green-shaded sun room at the back of Manor House, Bush waved off questions directed at Mitterrand, saying, ``This is a photo opportunity. President Mitterrand does not take questions at photo opportunities, and I'm defending his right not to take questions.'' ``Nice try,'' Bush told reporters who directed their inquiry at his guest. Then, as the media was ushered out of the room, Bush extended his arms and said, ``Well, welcome to the travelers. I'm very pleased you're here.'' The Soviet aid issue loomed as the largest facing the 16th annual gathering of the world's richest nations, with Bush on one side, Kohl and Mitterrand on the other. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has appealed to Bush, as summit host, for economic help. But so far, Bush has opposed any immediate funneling of Western cash into the foundering Soviet economy, while Kohl is pushing a $15 million package which could, in turn, enhance Kremlin support of German reunification. The summit partners were down to business after Bush played host to a weekend welcoming party that had some of his guests slurping Texas barbecue, tossing horseshoes and applauding rodeo tricks. Both Mitterrand and Kohl, arriving today, missed Bush's larger-than-life hoedown at the AstroArena. ``Tomorrow we get to work. I think we're all working for the same thing, for world peace and for harmony,'' Bush said at the end of a Grand Old Opry performance featuring Larry Gatlin, comedian Minnie Pearl and Charley Pride and Loretta Lynn. The evening saw some unlikely sights as the foreign visitors gamely tried to emulate Bush's exuberance for country fun. Margaret Thatcher, smartly dressed in a white and tan spring suit and clutching a white handbag, gingerly tripped over the indoor rodeo dirt in her impeccable spectator shoes. Toshiki Kaifu wildly waved a Stetson, matinee-cowboy style, above his head as he was announced into the rodeo arena. And a bluejean-clad Brian Mulroney tried his darndest to pitch horseshoes on astroturf topped with sawdust. No matter that some of the foreign guests looked a bit stiff standing in a buffet barbecue line, plates outstretched for potato salad and ribs. Or that the unmistakable county-fair smell of barnyard animals filled the air where sequined cowboys showed them lassos and saddles. This after all, was the ambiance of his adopted hometown, which Bush was eager to show off to guests who met a year ago in Paris. Mulroney, European Community President Jacques DeLors and Bush wore the specially crafted cowboy boots given to each leader by local bootmaker Rocky Carroll. Kaifu didn't wear his boots, but took great pride in showing off to Mulroney the huge western belt buckle that he wore with gray slacks, plaid jacket and loud print shirt. The evening capped a day when Bush remained true to his proclivity for engaging foreign heads of state in sports and relaxation. He shot some baskets with Mulroney in the elaborate gymnasium of the Houstonian hotel complex where Bush stays when he is in town. He attended morning church services with Thatcher.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Begins Deliberations in McMartin Pre-School Retrial
DOC.TEXT: The judge presiding over Raymond Buckey's second molestation trial told jurors today they must not consider public opinion in their deliberations of charges involving the defunct McMartin Pre-School. The case was placed in the jury's hands after Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg delivered 30 minutes of legal instructions. Buckey, 32, is being tried for the second time on eight counts of child molestation at the now-demolished school his family owned in Manhattan Beach. He took the stand in both trials to deny he ever molested children. The retrial, which lasted just three months, followed a nearly three-year odyssey that became the nation's longest and costliest criminal proceeding, with costs topping $13.5 million. It has been nearly seven years since Buckey was first arrested. Weisberg told jurors they must not base their decision on ``public opinion or public feeling'' about the notorious case. ``You must base your decision on the facts and the law,'' he said. ``You must not be biased against the defendant because he has been arrested for this crime or because he was brought to trial.'' Attending the hearing were a number of parents of former McMartin students, who had pressured District Attorney Ira Reiner to pursue a retrial against Buckey. The first trial ended Jan. 18 with Buckey's mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, acquitted of all charges and Buckey acquitted on 40 counts of sexually abusing children at the school. Jurors deadlocked on 13 other charges against him, however, and prosecutors refiled on eight of those counts. The second trial involved testimony from three young girls, who claimed Buckey molested them when they were students at the preschool. The defense alleged the children were influenced by therapists who interviewed them in the early stages of the case, and suggested their testimony was unreliable. Prosecutors said the children should be believed, although they acknowledged their memories had faded over the years. The judge told jurors in his instructions: ``You should not discount or distrust the testimony of a child, or give it greater weight, solely because the witness is a child.''

DOC.HEAD: `Die Hard 2' Opens in First Place
DOC.TEXT: ``Die Hard 2'' opened to strong business in its premiere weekend, grossing $22.2 million, according to preliminary figures released today. Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc. said ``Die Hard 2,'' in which Bruce Willis saves an airport from international terrorists, finished in first place on the box-office charts. In second, down about 29 percent from last weekend, was ``Days of Thunder,'' with estimated ticket sales of $11.1 million. ``Dick Tracy'' landed in third with receipts of $6.7 million, down 33 percent from a week ago, and ``The Jetsons'' was fourth with $4.8 million. ``Total Recall'' finished in fifth with $4.1 million. Among the bigger collapses was ``RoboCop 2,'' which fell 45 percent to $3.5 million and seventh place.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel to Issue Subpoenaes in S&L Probe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf, He said... with 2 grafs to fix wire garble
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Senate panel said today he would seek to subpoena former top thrift regulator M. Danny Wall and a former aide to President Bush to explain how an Arizona man could buy 15 failing Texas savings and loans by putting up only $1,000 of his own money. ``I expect each of them. ... They owe the public an explanation,'' said Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights. Among those to be subpoenaed within a week, Metzenbaum said, are Wall, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board; insurance executive James M. Fail of Phoenix, and Robert J. Thompson, a lobbyist and former congressional liaison for Bush when he was vice president. Metzenbaum's panel is investigating a federally approved deal in December 1988 in which Fail was promised $1.8 billion in subsidies while putting up only $1,000 of his own money and borrowing $70 million to buy 15 S&Ls consolidated into the Dallas-based Bluebonnet Savings. Metzenbaum said that Wall, Fail and Thompson refused to appear voluntarily before his panel. Thompson, according to Metzenbaum's investigators, pushed for approval of the Fail deal, and in 1989 borrowed more than $500,000 from companies controlled by Fail. Metzenbaum said federal payments amounting to $23 million a month helped Bluebonnet become the nation's most profitable large savings and loan last year. Wall told The New York Times: ``I did nothing for Bob Thompson that I didn't do for anyone else. There is nothing nefarious about it.'' Efforts to contact Fail, Thompson and Wall were unsuccessful Sunday. Investigators said Fail was allowed to acquire the institutions even though a company he controlled pleaded guilty o fraud in Alabama in 1976. Fail was indicted for securities fraud in that case, but the charges against him were dropped and he agreed not to conduct any new business in the state. The congressional panel is trying to determine why the bidding process for the failed S&Ls was concluded quickly, why some federal bank board officials who raised questions about Fail were overruled, and what role was played by Thompson. ``The political implications of this deal need a lot of explaining,'' Metzenbaum said. ``It appears from this particular instance the negotiators did not do their job very well.'' George M. Barclay, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas, acknowledged in a telephone interview Sunday that he wrote a letter overruling staff objections to Fail's eligibility for the deal. The letter to federal regulators was necessary for Fail's approval as a buyer. He said he could not recall why he came to that conclusion but acknowledged he may have acted in response to telephone calls from officials in Washington. But he said ``it's absolutely not true that anybody attempted to influence me,'' and that the letter raised a flag for regulators by mentioning Fail's past indictment. He said the bank only certified to federal regulators ``that we felt based upon the information we had that we had no objection, no legal objection, to his acquiring the institution'' and that the bank would be able to properly regulate Fail's new institution. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board's regulatory functions were taken away and replaced by the Office of Thrift Supervision, an arm of the Treasury Department, as part of the federal bailout of the savings and loan industry passed by Congress last year.

DOC.HEAD: Rapist Gets Lenient Sentence For Taking AIDS Test
DOC.TEXT: A man who pleaded guilty to raping a Columbia University freshman got a reduced sentence because he agreed to be tested for AIDS, according to published reports. Reginald Darby, 28, pleaded guilty in March to first-degree rape in the knife-point assault on a 17-year-old in her dormitory room, the reports said. In a secret deal with the district attorney's office, Darby was promised that he would be sentenced to no more than five to 15 years if he submitted to the test, according to Monday's editions of The New York Times and the July-August issue of Manhattan Lawyer. The maximum sentence for a first-degree rape conviction is eight and one-third to 25 years, they noted. Sentencing is scheduled for Aug. 3. Lisa Friel, an assistant prosecutor, said on the court record that the sentence was ``contingent upon the defendant submitting to certain testing and making the results of the test available to the district attorney's office and other appropriate parties.'' Neither Darby's attorney, Charles Blakeley of the Legal Aid Society, nor Friel would confirm that the test was for AIDS. But other Legal Aid attorneys told Manhattan Lawyer that it was an AIDS test and said it was the first time that Legal Aid had worked out such a plea agreement for a rape defendant in Manhattan. However, there are questions about the usefulness of the test. If the rapist tests negative, it does not guarantee that the victim is not at risk for AIDS because a person may be infected with AIDS and not yet have produced the antibodies detected by the most common test. And if the rapist tests positive, the victim may not have contracted the disease. Under New York law, those charged with rape cannot be compelled to submit to AIDS tests. At least eight states _ Illinois, Oregon, Washington, Indiana, Georgia, South Carolina, Texas and Colorado _ provide for mandatory AIDS testing in some cases, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Soviets Making Progress Toward Dismantling Radar
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has shown progress toward dismantling the Krasnoyarsk radar in Siberia that it has said it will remove because it is in violation of the U.S.-Soviet antiballistic missile treaty, the State Department said Monday. Department spokesman Richard Boucher, asked about the status of the radar installation, said, ``We have indications that preparations are under way to begin dismantlement of the radar, including the removal of some external equipment.'' The department had said several months ago that indications were the Soviets were preparing to dismantle the radar. What was new in Boucher's statement was the part about removing external equipment. He declined to elaborate on it. ``Certainly the removal of some external equipment is progress, but what really matters is the complete elimination of the radar,'' he said. Boucher declined to give any timetable for the removal. The United States has said, however, that it hopes to sign a strategic nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union by the end of the year and will not do so until the radar has been dismantled. An administration official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said some of the external equipment had already been removed from the radar installation. ``Something is being removed,'' the official said. ``Whether that involves actual dismantlement of the radar is something that I don't think we are prepared to say. External equipment has been removed, but that doesn't necessarily qualify as parts of the radar.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Back Socialists On Strong Military Stand
DOC.TEXT: The Socialist defense minister won praise from the conservative opposition Monday for pledging to maintain France as Western Europe's top military power and adhere to its maverick nuclear policy. In his address Sunday, Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement also said France plans to keep its 50,000 troops in Germany for at least four more years. Chevenement was right to declare that ``all the dangers haven't disappeared miraculously, and that France must keep the means of defending its territory, its expatriates and its positions in different parts of the world,'' said Pierre-Andre Wiltzer, an opposition legislator. Wiltzer, a defense specialist for the center-right Union for French Democracy, said there was a national consensus to maintain a strong military. He said the defense budget should not be reduced. Some Socialists have urged cuts in defense spending, but Chevenement thus far has the support of President Francois Mitterrand in opposing major budget reductions. Chevenement recalled that France refused to endorse a declaration at last week's NATO summit stipulating that the alliance would use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. ``It was in our interests to refuse to go along with this idea that one uses nuclear weapons as a last resort, when all would be lost,'' he said at a forum Sunday. France would stick with its ``completely opposite'' strategy of nuclear deterrence, he said. ``This is extremely important for France and for Europe.'' Surveys have shown that French voters across the political spectrum want to keep an independent ``force de frappe,'' as the country's nuclear arsenal is called. France ``is the biggest military power in Europe'' after the Soviet Union, Chevenement said, and must maintain its capabilities. ``In five years, there will be a strategic void, which is very dangerous because a void of arms can lead to outside interference.'' Wiltzer sounded a similar note in his statement. ``If France is a nation that counts in Europe and the world, it's due in large part to its defense. To cast doubt on the coherence and credibility of this policy under the pretext of budget cuts or because of internal rivalries in the Socialist Party would be irresponsible.'' Chevenement rejected any suggestion that French troops withdraw from Germany by the end of the year. ``That won't happen for at least four or five years,'' he said, adding that withdrawal even then would depend on actions of the Soviet Union and coordination with Western allies. Chevenement said the eventual withdrawal of the 50,000 French troops would fit in with plans to trim the armed forces by 35,000. The defense minister said the tentative withdrawal plans have no bearing on a newly formed joint French-German brigade.

DOC.HEAD: Hugging Allegations Keep Some at Habitat at Arm's Length
DOC.TEXT: Habitat for Humanity's founder is keeping some people at arm's length while its leaders and backers struggle with allegations that he improperly hugged and touched five female workers. The allegations have sent founder Millard Fuller into near exile and put an uncharacteristic strain on Habitat, a strongly religious organization that uses ``sweat equity'' to build housing for the poor around the world. It has a $50 million budget and 100,000 U.S. volunteers, including former President Carter. ``It has been a situation that has caused a lot of pain because we're all very close,'' said Claire Williams, spokeswoman for Habitat's board. Fuller, who says he only touched the women in exuberant shows of friendship, still can be found chatting with Habitat volunteers. But he avoids the headquarters and is careful how he greets people. ``I no longer initiate hugs,'' he said in an interview Thursday. ``When charges of this nature are made, it's very difficult to defend yourself.'' No criminal charges have been filed against Fuller, 55. The women have not been identified, and their allegations have been described only in general terms. Geoff Van Loucks, chairman of Habitat for Humanity International Inc., has said the women alleged ``nothing criminal'' when they complained to a Habitat chaplain. ``They claim inappropriate comments and inappropriate hugging and touching. They've never, ever claimed anything more. Nor is there a hint of anything more,'' Van Loucks said. ``Let me make clear there was no sexual intercourse.'' Fuller, who founded Habitat with his wife, Linda, also is to move his base of operations to Atlanta. Because of a reorganization that was planned before the controversy, he has gone from executve director to president. The organization also hired the Mennonite Conciliation Service to counsel Fuller and the women. But there have been divisions over whether enough has been done. Tim O'Donnell, who recently finished a 2{-year term at the headquarters, said he received a harsh handwritten note from Carter after O'Donnell complained about the way the board investigated the claims against Fuller. ``You are either completely foolish or trying to sabotage the work of Habitat,'' said a copy of the letter provided by O'Donnell. ``Attacking Millard Fuller and the board of directors is a reprehensible act. ... Don't make it more difficult for those trying to resolve the problem.'' Carter spokeswoman Carrie Harmon declined to comment on the letter's authenticity. Carter, who annually spends at least a week working at Habitat homebuilding projects, has publicly defended Fuller. In a recent interview with The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, he said the nature of the accusations upset the ``extremely conservative'' board members, who then were ``overly inclined to condemn'' Fuller. Fuller still is a visible presence in Americus, a town of 16,000 about 10 miles from Carter's hometown of Plains. Fuller now works out of his law office, a few blocks from Habitat's headquarters. Fuller, a former millionaire who gave away his money in 1970 and founded Habitat in 1976, said he has apologized to all five women and met personally with three of them. ``When someone says they have been offended, the common-sense thing and the Christian thing is to seek reconciliation,'' he said. ``I'm not trying to paint myself as a perfect person who has been victimized. I obviously was not sensitive enough in my relations with these women.'' Back at Habitat headquarters, California businessman Jeff Snider, who arrived Thursday, has taken over as executive vice president in charge of operations. As a reporter arrived, a male employee greeted a female receptionist with a hug. Ms. Williams, the board spokeswoman, said, ``We've seen progress in the two or three months it's been going on.'' But O'Donnell said the controversy has taken a toll at the organization, which has over 450 projects in the United States, Canada and Australia and more than 80 in 26 developing countries. ``People almost feel they have to take sides,'' he said. ``I know of a handful of people who have left because of the situation.'' Fuller said he wants to focus on the future. He said his promotion to president and the opening of a Habitat office in Atlanta are part of a long-range plan developed last year that just happened to coincide with the controversy. Fuller said he helped pick Snider to run Habitat. ``Because of the timing, it appears that I'm being run out of town,'' said Fuller. ``I want us to get on with the business of building houses for the needy.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Summons Leaders to Harness Free Wills and Free Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush remarks embargoed for delivery 3:15 pm EDT. Inserts Soviet reax in 4th graf and color on outdoor air conditioning into 22nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the world's richest nations began their 16th economic summit today, urged by President Bush to harness ``the power and energy of free wills and free markets'' to bolster the troubled economies of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The seven leaders were deeply divided on how and when to provide financial assistance sought by Mikhail Gorbachev, but officials said a team of western bankers and other experts would be sent to assess Soviet needs. As the meetings began, the leaders lined up ``about half on one side, and half on the other'' over how to extend financial assistance to Mikhail Gorbachev, said White House chief of staff John Sununu. Bush has said he has ``big problems'' with extending direct aid to Moscow until it reduces military spending, moves more forcefully toward a free-market system and curtails the $5 billion a year subsidy to Cuba. A Gorbachev aide said Monday that western aid must be unconditional, explaining, ``We aren't taking orders.'' Bush met this morning with Francois Mitterrand and a French spokesman said both men stuck to their position: Bush opposes direct aid _ at least for now _ while Mitterrand favors ``all aid that is serious and useful.'' Officials said the leaders would approve an assessment team to recommend applications for western assistance. Sununu said the study might be conducted by a mixture of western financing agencies, including the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Bush is offering the Soviets technical assistance for transportation and agriculture and advice on developing free-market mechanisms. Sununu pointed out that the Soviets currently lose almost half their grain crop through faulty storage. Sununu noted that different countries view Soviet circumstances in different ways, perhaps a hint that Bush will not staunchly oppose direct aid from France, West Germany and Italy _ nations that are ready to proceed. Also meeting here are leaders from Britain, Japan, Canada and the European Economic Community. ``We are called upon as allies and as friends to work toward decisions that will bring new stability and prosperity to the world, by tapping the power and energy of free wills and free markets,'' Bush said in a statement opening the summit. ``These economic summits have become a framework for frank, constructive dialogue, a dialogue for progress that I believe will be advanced greatly in these next three days. A new world of freedom lays before us. Hopeful. Confident. A world where peace endures, where commerce has conscience, where all that seems possible is possible. ``So let us begin, in good faith, to set the stage for the new millennium.'' Soviet aid questions were a highly charged and undecided issue as the three-day summit began. Decisions were likely to come Wednesday in a final communique. From Moscow came a fresh plea for financial assistance. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told reporters at the Communist Party Congress,``I feel it would be advantageous, for us and the West.'' He said Moscow was looking to the west for ``credit, technical cooperation, personnel training, joint ventures and joint projects.'' Meanwhile, the summit partners faced a tangle of their own differences over trade and the environment. Europeans are resisting Bush's demand for phasing out farm subsidies over the next 10 years and, together with Canada, are pushing for agreement on new steps to halt global warming. Sununu sniped at European critics of Bush's go-slow policy on curbing carbon dioxide and other pollutants blamed for warming the global environment. ``I think West Germany got a lot of good grades for rhetoric,'' he said on ABC. ``If you take a good look at what the United States has actually done in terms of cleaning up our environment ... I don't think the United States has to take a back seat to anyone.'' Yet, a prominent U.S. environmental group, the Wilderness Society, quickly chimed in to say, ``the U.S. gets a failing grade, no matter how Governor Sununu tries to rejigger the numbers.'' Before calling the summit into session on the campus of Rice University, Bush met separately with Mitterand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to discuss their $15-billion aid proposal for Moscow. The world has changed dramatically since the last economic summit in Paris. At that time, the West was considering a limited aid package to encourage the beginings of reform efforts in Poland and Hungary. Since that time the Berlin Wall has crumbled and most of the communist nations of Eastern Europe have been swept away, leaving the West groping for a way to respond to the dramatic changes. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said today the chief message from Houston will be to urge East European nations to undertake necessary economic reforms before they receive Western assistance. ``There's no sense in pouring money into a system that isn't ready to receive it,'' he said on NBC.'' Despite temperatures in the 90s and humidity topping 80 percent, the city of Houston went all out to welcome the heads of government, their contingents and hordes of reporters. Air conditioning was pumped onto the outddor platform to make the arrival ceremony comfortable for the leaders. Bush was host Sunday night to a pre-summit rodeo, complete with bareback riding, barrel racing and a calf scramble. Japan's Toshiki Kaifu, a first-time summiteer, waived his cowboy hat as if he'd been doing it all his life. Mitterrand, Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and Kohl delayed their arrival until today. Kohl was in Rome to watch his West German team win soccer's World Cup; Andreotti was there to present it. Bush had been in Houston since Friday, arriving from London, where he saw the NATO allies adopt a U.S. proposal to rewrite NATO's war-fighting strategy as a way of lessening tensions with the Soviet Union. Bush, as summit host, received a letter from Gorbachev appealing for western help. Gorbachev's latest plea was expected to be aired fully during a working dinner tonight. Pressing the Soviet case, foreign ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said Moscow was shrinking its military and moving toward a market-price system that would curtail Moscow's huge subsidies to Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Soccer Victory Spawns Neo-Nazi Rampages
DOC.TEXT: A day after cheering their soccer team to victory in the World Cup, Germans woke up Monday to hear of deaths, broken glass and looted shops, the aftermath of extremist rioting in both German states. Four people were killed and hundreds hurt when jubilant street celebrations turned reckless and violent following West Germany's 1-0 victory over Argentina in Rome on Sunday. Bands of neo-Nazi skinheads and other hooligans brawled with police in East Berlin and in the West German cities of Hamburg and Bielefeld. Foreigners were singled out for attacks, and stores were looted and vandalized nationwide, police said. More than 120 people were arrested and at least 60 police officers were among the injured. The celebration was far more violent and nationalistic than the good-natured euphoria that followed West Germany's last cup championship in 1974. It was also the first shared by East Germany, which is on the threshold of unifying with its Western neighbor and rooted strongly for its neighboring team. Unification and rising German influence on world affairs has intensified patriotic feeling and spawned new extremism. ``I was astonished by what had happened last night,'' said Detlev Liepmann, a sociologist at West Berlin's Free University. ``There is a special group at the right side of our spectrum who are searching for any occasion to do these sort of things.'' About 20,000 cheering, flag-waving fans greeted the West German soccer team when it returned to Frankfurt Monday after taking the championship. The peaceful display of pride was in sharp contrast to the ugly scenes of random violence that broke out the night before and lasted into the morning. Hundreds of thousands of people poured into the streets, fireworks streaked the skies over several cities and a concert of honking horns lasted into the morning. But in East Berlin, about 5,000 youths watching the game on a huge television screen across from the Parliament building began hurling bottles and demolishing concession stands when it ended. A group of 500 neo-Nazis shouting epithets against foreigners rampaged on the main square, Alexanderplatz, chasing Vietnamese workers and ransacking a bar frequented by homosexuals, police and witnesses said. A group of about 200 skinheads later tried to attack a house occupied by a leftist group, and fought pitched battles with police. Twelve were arrested and three people were seriously hurt, police said. In Hamburg, about 400 hooligans and skinheads clashed with police with rocks and bottles. Fifty-four police officers were injured and 88 people were arrested, according to police. Windows of more than 20 stores were smashed, one bar was destroyed and several police and private autos were damaged by the mob, police said. Police used truncheons and water cannons to break up the crowd. In the West German city of Bielefeld, about 200 neo-Nazi skinheads attacked police with rocks and firebombs. Six officers were hurt and 13 people were arrested. Six police wagons were damaged, authorities there said. In Cologne, a mob surrounded a car driven by an 18-year-old Turk and threatened to lynch him, police said. The car was rocked and three people were hurt when the motorist attempted to drive away. Anetta Kahane, head of the East Berlin office for foreigner affairs, said Monday that Asians and Africans living in the country are the target of daily attacks. Wolfgang Schoenpflug, a psychologist at the free University, said resentment of foreigners is rising in both German states, some of it influenced by East Germany. ``New emotions and attitudes are coming from the East, where hostility against foreigners was suppressed but heavily present,'' he said. Four people died in accidents related to the celebrations and hundreds were reported injured. In Cologne, a reveler died when he smashed a window in a moving street car, leaned out and was struck by a concrete pillar, police said. In the southwest West German city of Heilbronn, two people died when their car slammed into a lamppost. In Geislingen, a speeding car with four fans smashed into a post, killing one and seriously injuring three. In the West German city of Schwetzingen, 37 people were injured when a fan drove his car into a crowd of 5,000 people celebrating in the street.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Boy is Best Fence Painter in Tom Sawyer's Hometown
DOC.TEXT: A family whose members travel here each year from Kentucky and Minnesota for Tom Sawyer Days seems to have the makings of a fence painting dynasty. Tony Youngblood, 12, of Mayfield, Ky., did his part Sunday by winning this year's fence painting contest. His cousin, Scott McEndree, 13, of Minnetonka, Minn., was last year's champion. The contest is inspired by Tom Sawyer's fence-painting exploits in Mark Twain's ``Tom Sawyer,'' which is set in Hannibal. In the book, Tom gets friends to help him whitewash a fence by making the hated chore appear fun. Tony got no such help. He did have the benefit of experience, though, this being his third year as a contestant. His strategy for winning? ``Quality in painting and running,'' he said. ``Each year, I learn a little bit more.'' The contestants were judged on authenticity of costume, as described in Twain's writing, as well as speed and quality of painting. As this year's champion, Tony will carry back to Kentucky the governor's cup, which he will return to Hannibal next summer. He also won readings by Twain, a plaque and a $500 U.S. Savings Bond.

DOC.HEAD: New York Author Wins Hemingway Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf to include hometown of Richard
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Ernest Hemingway Foundation Award went to Mark Richard for his short story collection ``The Ice at the Bottom of the World,'' his first published book of fiction. The $7,500 award administered by the PEN association of writers was presented Saturday at the Fourth International Hemingway Conference. The conference is a biannual gathering that draws scholars and aficionados of the novelist. Hemingway's widow, Mary, established the award in 1976 to honor her husband's memory and noteworthy work by young writers. ``It's one of the major literary awards in America and in particular for new writers _ it means Mark Richard is someone to watch for,'' said Frank Rigg of the John F. Kennedy Library, where the conference was held. Richard's stories have appeared in publications that include Harper's, Esquire, Antaeus and Grand Street. His work was also featured in the ``Best American Short Stories'' of 1989 and ``New Stories from the South.'' ``Mark Richard's stories are ambitious and successful,'' wrote the judges. `We find the quintessentially American balancing act of despair and high spirits.'' Richard lives in New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Welcome Western Aid but No Conditions
With AM-Summit, Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Senior Soviet officials said Monday they would welcome Western aid to help rebuild their country, but they rejected attaching any conditions to such aid. Leaders of the world's seven richest nations convened in Houston, Texas, on Monday and aid to Moscow was at the top of their agenda. President Bush has said he has ``big problems'' with pouring cash into an anemic Soviet economy that still supports heavy defense spending and funnels $5 billion a year into Marxist Cuba. Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin, in charge of Soviet economic reform, appeared to rule out any conditions for the aid. ``Any political conditions are unacceptable for negotiations with the Soviet Union,'' Abalkin said during a break in the 28th Communist Party Congress. An aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he viewed Bush's concerns as conditions. ``To dictate conditions to such a country as the Soviet Union, a great power, is embarrassing,'' said Gorbachev staff member Georgy Shakhnazarov. ``We aren't taking orders.'' The urgings from the West could also backfire, he warned, playing into the hands of Soviet officials ``who consider that any foreign help would be insulting.'' Such officials, he said, believe accepting Western aid would ``mean we will be selling our national interests.'' Gorbachev is worried his country cannot make the painful leap to a market system without Western credits and wants help from the industrial powers to stop Soviet economic decline. The most prominent conservative in the Soviet leadership, Yegor K. Ligachev, said the West could try to push Moscow in a direction he opposes. ``If conditions are attached to these lines of credit ... such as a move toward a free market economy or private property, then Ligachev is against it,'' he said at the party congress. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was more conciliatory. ``We understand if no one wants to take a risk. The U.S.A. isn't speaking in favor of development of economic cooperation if reform doesn't proceed as we plan,'' he said. Such aid, he said, ``would be advantageous, for us and the West.'' Soviet officials offered their first detailed list of what kind of help they want from the West. Shakhnazarov said the Soviet Union would like Western technology for quick construction of small businesses to produce consumer goods and food, items in short supply. Gorbachev has made improvements in both a top priority. The Soviet economy also suffers from inflation and a huge budget deficit. Help in organizing market mechanisms _ such as banking, finance and management _ also are priorities, the Gorbachev aide said. In return, Shakhnazarov said, Moscow could offer the West help in converting the defense industry to produce civilian goods. Gorbachev has launched a program to tap highly developed defense plants to assist the civilian sector. The leaders of West Germany and France advocate helping the Soviet Union despite disagreements over Cuba, and have called for $15 billion in aid to bolster reform plans. Asked whether the Soviet Union would cut aid to Cuba, Shevardnadze said that was strictly ``a question of bilateral relations,'' and did not indicate the government's plans. Credits would help Soviet businesses pay bills to Western companies. The Soviet Union traditionally has been punctual in making such payments and recent delays have eroded confidence among foreign investors. West Germany already has granted an unconditional loan of $3.1 billion. Estimates of how much money the Soviet Union would need to begin to stabilize its economy range from $5 billion to $20 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Execs Are on Hold 60 Hours a Year
DOC.TEXT: The average business executive spends about 60 hours a year on hold on the telephone, according to a survey. In the survey, commissioned by Accountemps, a personnel agency, 200 executives of the nation's 1,000 largest corporations were questioned by an independent market research firm. They were asked how much time they spend on unnecessary meetings, on unnecessary memos and on hold. The executives were not asked how much time other people spend on hold waiting for them. The responses came out to 15 minutes a day on hold, or 60 hours a year for an executive with four weeks' vacation; 32 minutes a day reading and writing unnecessary memos, or 128 hours a year; and an hour and 12 minutes a day at unnecessary meetings, or 288 hours a year.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Leader Resigns After Being Accused of Adultery
LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Anti-apartheid leader Rev. Allan Boesak resigned his church positions after press reports alleged he was having an affair with a white television star, church officials said Monday. Boesak was in seclusion and his lawyers said he had nothing to say after telling his congregation Sunday that he was stepping down. Boesak, who is married, said he had done nothing wrong but had to resign. ``This is one of the darkest days of my life,'' he told the congregation of the Ned Geref Sendingkerk church in Cape Town's Bellville South area where he served for 21 years. ``I am deeply sorry for all the pain I have caused,'' he said. Boesak, a leader of the mixed-race community, had become a prominent anti-apartheid leader in recent years. He helped lead campaigns against white-minority rule and toured the world to denounce apartheid. Boesak resigned after South African newspapers reported he was romantically involved with Elna Botha, who works for the state South African Broadcasting Corporation. Mrs. Botha is a star and producer of ``Good Morning South Africa,'' a news and entertainment show. Mrs. Botha's husband, TV news anchorman Colin Fluxman, was taken off the air Monday after breaking down as he read a news report about his wife and Boesak during ``Good Morning South Africa.'' Business Day newspaper reported Monday that Fluxman said the couple were divorcing. Church officials said Boesak and his wife, Dorothy, had not decided whether they would divorce, according to news reports. Walter Sisulu, a senior leader of the African National Congress, the main black opposition group, said Monday Boesak's resignation would not harm the movement. Boesak has been an ANC ally. ``It's really a personal matter, a love affair is a personal matter,'' Sisulu said at a press conference. The incident was seen as a moral rather than a racial scandal. Apartheid legislation banning inter-racial sex was dropped in 1985. Boesak was temporarily suspended from his church posts in 1985 after allegations he was having an affair with a church worker. He was later reinstated. Business Day also reported that Boesak was likely to devote himself to a political career. He has strong ties to the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. Boesak is long thought to have had political ambitions that go beyond his role in the anti-apartheid movement. Boesak modeled himself on American black civil rights leader Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. He developed a vivid speaking style and often led non-violent marches and demonstrations. Rev. Johan Retief, leader of the council at Boesak's church, said church leaders were stunned and trying to decide what to do. ``We do not take this lightly,'' he said. South African newspapers said Monday Boesak was also resigning as moderator of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, an international body of Protestant churches.

DOC.HEAD: Divided or Not, Western Allies Move Toward Help for Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Whatever their differences on a formal framework, the prosperous Western democracies are gearing up for a multi-billion-dollar effort to protect Mikhail Gorbachev from the economic morass that threatens his hold on Soviet power. Long lines and restive consumers give ample evidence that Gorbachev's economic reforms need an infusion of imagination and cash. Inability to keep food stores stocked has already forced Moscow to spend an extra 3 billion rubles _ $500 million _ on food imports. The White House says half the Soviet grain crop goes bad before it gets to the marketplace. The French and Germans want to provide billions of dollars, the sooner the better. The United States leads a go-slow faction that includes Japan and Britain. Even so, American officials are briefing reporters at the economic summit on a U.S. drive to help Soviet agriculture and transportation. Seventy-three years after the Russian revolution, Soviet officials emphasized on Monday that assistance could not carry Western conditions. ``We aren't taking orders,'' said Gorbachev aide Georgy Shaknazarov. But Bush has three main objections to offering direct aid: the Soviets' heavy military spending, their sending $5 billion a year in aid to Marxist Cuba and their slow pace in adapting to capitalistic ways. It was vaguely possible that summit leaders might attempt to set specific conditions concerning one or more of those problems before approving aid. The Soviets are open about their need for Western help. ``I feel it would be advantageous, for us and the West,'' said Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. He said he disliked the term ``aid,'' preferring ``credit, technical cooperation, personnel training, joint ventures and joint projects'' _ a message welcome to Bush. Only a year ago, the United States, Britain, France, Canada, West Germany, Japan and Italy stepped gingerly into these uncharted waters and decided to help Poland and Hungary. The Soviet Union presents a far more difficult decision. Bush entered the summit discussions already committed to providing technical assistance. That may be as far as he is ready to go _ for now. But Bush doesn't seem to feel so strongly that he would try to block others from more ambitious assistance. West Germany alone hopes to make $3.1 billion in loans available and is leading the push for an overall Western aid package in excess of $15 billion. ``The president has understood different countries may have different ways of evaluating specific changes'' in the Soviet Union, Chief of Staff John Sununu said Monday. From the French delegation, meanwhile, came a statement of renewed determination to bolster Gorbachev and the Soviet economy with ``all aid that is serious and useful.'' The leaders may endorse diversity when they address aid to the Soviet Union in their Wednesday communique. Each nation would be free to go its separate way.
