But the summit nations are planning to act in concert in dispatching teams of bankers and other experts to assess Soviet needs. Failure of perestroika could mean Gorbachev's downfall and begin an era of instability across the Soviet Union. Where would the West be, asked Brian Mulroney of Canada, ``if they chuck him out?'' U.S. officials make this kind of case for moving slowly. _ It is impossible to keep tabs on assistance. Many of the billions could be diverted to the Red Army where the generals and Gorbachev do not always see eye to eye. _ It doesn't make sense to send billions to the Soviets while they are sending billions to Cuba, a state whose interests often collide with the United States'. Mulroney agrees with Bush that Soviet aid to Cuba is ``profoundly unacceptable,'' and he said Canada was willing to provide trade credits, not direct assistance. _ The Soviet economy is so messed up that immediate aid will be wasted. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Monday: ``There's no sense in pouring money into a system that isn't ready to receive it.''
Barry Schweid is chief diplomatic correspondent for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Surgeon Treated for Artery Blockage
DOC.TEXT: The doctor who performed the world's first successful liver transplant was recovering Monday following surgery to remove blockage in one of his coronary arteries, officials said. Dr. Thomas E. Starzl, 64, was alert and resting comfortably at Presbyterian-University Hospital, where he has performed hundreds of transplants during the past nine years, said Dr. Bruce Wilson, director of the University of Pittsburgh's Heart Institute. Doctors removed a severe blockage from Starzl's right coronary artery Sunday after he complained of chest pains, Wilson said. The artery was 99 percent blocked. ``He's doing quite well,'' Wilson told reporters. ``We expect a speedy recovery.'' Because the blockage was not total, Starzl's heart muscle did not appear to be damaged, Wilson said. The two remaining arteries ``look pretty normal,'' he said. Starzl gained attention in 1967 when he performed the world's first successful liver transplant at the University of Colorado. He also pioneered the development of a medical team that performed 200 kidney transplants at Colorado General and Denver Veteran's Administration hospitals. In 1981, Starzl began work at the University of Pittsburgh, which he helped make the world's premier transplant center. Last year, the hospital performed more than 460 liver transplants and 210 kidney transplants. Wilson said a severe blockage of the kind Starzl had can occur suddenly when blood strips away crusted plaque lining the arteries and causes a larger buildup farther along in the artery. People who disregard the first symptoms of pain run the risk of a complete blockage, which can cause a heart attack and permanent damage, he said. Wilson said he will monitor Starzl's condition the next few days and ask him to restrict his work schedule. But he added it may be difficult to persuade the energetic surgeon to slow down. ``A person like Tom Starzl might have more stress if you inhibit him,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Turns Down Request for Delay in Trial of Accused `Wine Country' Killer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with judge denying continuance, other detail. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Besides domestic...'.
DOC.TEXT: A judge today denied a request to postpone the case of Ramon Salcido, who is accused of killing seven people in a wine country murder spree, clearing the way for the trial to begin next week. Sonoma County Public Defender Marteen Miller requested a continuance for at least two months, but prosecutors argued against the delay and visiting Judge Reginald Littrell of Sierra County agreed with them. Salcido, 29, is accused of murdering his wife, two of his daughters, his mother-in-law, her two other daughters and a co-worker in Sonoma County 15 months ago. A third daughter, whose throat was slit, survived the attack. Miller, who claims his client has a brain dysfunction and also was illegally extradited from Mexico, said last week he had ``more than enough to justify a two-month continuance.'' The exchanges between Miller and District Attorney Peter Bumerts today were sometimes bitter. Salcido, who appeared in court with a Spanish language interpreter, listened to the proceedings attentively. At one point, Miller argued that a delay was justified because ``a man's life is at stake.'' ``If Mr. Salcido had had the same consideration for the seven people he killed, maybe we wouldn't be here,'' countered Bumerts. Investigators say Salcido killed his wife, Angela, because he suspected she was unfaithful. He told authorities bouts with alcohol and cocaine preceded the attacks. The case was moved to San Mateo County because of widespread publicity. Miller had said he would seek a second change of venue because of similar media coverage in the new locale, but no such request was made today. Jury selection is due to begin next week after the lawyers and the judge work out the list of questions to ask prospective jurors. Besides domestic distrust, investigators say Salcido was upset because he had been ordered to make back child-support payments to his first wife, a woman Angela Salcido had known nothing about until the order. The couple had a daughter before they divorced. In statements to Sonoma County sheriff's detectives while returning to the United States, he allegedly said he took his daughters, Theresa, 1, Sofia, 4, and Carmina, 3, to a county dump and slit their throats. Carmina survived and told police, ``Daddy cut me.'' Salcido allegedly said he then drove to his in-laws' house, where he knocked out his 47-year-old mother-in-law, Marion Louise Richards, before cutting the throats of her daughters, Ruth, 12, and Marie, 8. He stabbed their mother to death as she regained consciousness, authorities said. Salcido allegedly said he then returned home, beat his wife and shot her with a .22-caliber pistol. He told detectives he thought about killing himself but instead drove to the Grand Cru Winery, where he worked, and fatally shot co-worker Tracey Toovey, 35. Salcido said he then went to the house of another co-worker, Ken Butti, 33, who was shot but survived. Miller has said he will argue that his client had an organic brain dysfunction and was suffering from ``psychotic depression'' at the time of the slayings.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Claiming To Have Bomb, Gun Takes Hostages in Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd to UPDATE with negotiations
DOC.TEXT: A woman claiming to be armed with a bomb and gun held several hostages in a bank lobby today while police surrounded the building. The woman entered an NCNB Corp. branch in North Miami about 12:15 p.m., handed a teller a note, then ordered people from the bank, said police dispatcher Michelle Stoll. Deputy Chief Larry Juriga said police contacted the woman by telephone about 3 p.m. and began negotiations. He said police could not confirm the woman's identity or what was written on the note. Ms. Stoll was not sure how many people left the bank or how many remained inside. The dispatcher said that as far as she knew, nothing had been seen of the alleged gun or bomb. Police blocked off a half-mile area around the bank. The FBI and a SWAT team from the Metro-Dade Police Department was called to the scene. Ms. Stoll said she did not believe the incident was a robbery attempt. The bank is in the tree-lined main business district of the small town a few miles north of Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Unsure of Bill's Fate
With AM-Louisiana Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer said Monday he had questions about the constitutionality of a record labeling bill that could become the first law of its kind in the nation. Roemer said he favors warning labels on objectionable recordings but would prefer that the industry do it voluntarily. The industry has begun a voluntary labeling program, but it was not stringent enough for the Legislature, which overwhelmingly passed the bill Saturday. The measure also bans the sale of labeled records to minors. The measure was approved a day before the Legislature passed a bill that could become the nation's most stringent state abortion law. Roemer, who is still pondering the abortion measure, also said he had not decided whether to sign or veto the record labeling bill. It would mandate labels for recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, incest, illegal drug use, child abuse and satanic worship. During a news conference, Roemer said he had serious legal questions about the bill's constitutionality. Those questions have to be balanced with concerns about the content of some recordings, he said. Roemer said most of the industry was acting responsibly, but ``some portions of the industry produce pure trash. Parents don't know that until they are brought home and played.'' The governor said he preferred a voluntary program, similar to the ratings system adopted by the movie industry. ``We'll all be better off,'' he said. In May, the recording industry unveiled a voluntary labeling system that it hoped would halt state campaigns for mandatory labeling. Industry spokesmen said every legislature except Louisiana's pulled back their bills while the voluntary program was tested. The voluntary program went into effect this month, and labeled recordings already are showing up in stores, said Mike Cutshaw, an attorney representing the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. Last week, Capitol Records promised to provide legal help to store operators who are threatened with arrest for selling its recordings that bear labels warning consumers of sexually explicit lyrics. Although the labeling bill passed both chambers with more than the two-thirds vote needed to override a veto, the Legislative session was to end Monday night and a veto would kill it until the next session, which begins in April. Roemer has 20 days to decide on the bill after it reaches his desk. Under the legislation, record manufacturers would be required to label recordings with objectionable lyrics. Retailers would be subject to misdemeanor criminal penalties for selling labeled recordings to those under age 17. The producers of the Grammy Awards show have said such a law would scuttle Louisiana's chances of being host of the event. Also, backers of a proposed Grammy Hall of Fame in New Orleans say the law would end their project and cost the city $100 million a year. State Rep. Ted Haik, the bill's sponsor, told reporters he believed the bill was constitutional. He said that unlike the movie industry, the recording industry is spread out among companies of all sizes and difficult to regulate voluntarily. The legislation would not take effect until 1992. Haik has said that if the industry implements its voluntary program, he would push for repeal of the law.

DOC.HEAD: Country Music Star Under Medical Treatment in Nashville
DOC.TEXT: Tammy Wynette has been hospitalized for a respiratory infection, a spokesman said Monday. ``Tammy is being treated for bronchitis. She's expected to be out of the hospital in less than a week,'' said Fletcher Foster, a spokesman for Epic Records in Nashville. Dr. Barbara Bell, a doctor in the emergency room of Breech Medical Center in Lebanon, Mo., said the singer came in for treatment Saturday night. She said Ms. Wynette was transferred to Nashville. The family asked that the hospital not be identified. Ms. Wynette, 48, canceled a performance Saturday in Branson, Mo., because of the illness.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are President Bush's welcoming remarks Monday at the economic summit: Well, welcome to Houston. And we think this city a very appropriate place to host this economic summit, not of the post-war era, but of the post-post-war era. And over the past decade and a half, the leaders of the largest industrialized democracies have held these summits to address common problems and challenges. These economic summits have become a framework for frank and constructive dialogue, a dialogue for progress that I believe will be advanced greatly in these next three days. And together we're called upon as allies and as friends to work toward decisions here in Houston that will bring a new stability and prosperity to the world _ by tapping the power and energy of free wills and free markets. A new world of freedom lays before us. Hopeful. Confident. A world where peace endures, where commerce has conscience, and where all that seems possible is possible. So, let us begin, in good faith, to set the stage for the new millennium. And thank you for coming to Houston, and thank all who have made us feel so at home here. Thank you very much.

DOC.HEAD: Nosy Bears Force Campground Closures
DOC.TEXT: Two hungry black bears damaged cars and paid an unwelcome call on a camper, prompting authorities to close two campsites until the animals can be captured, a national forest spokeswoman said Monday. The bears have been spotted in the Pemigewasset Wilderness of the White Mountain National Forest. ``They've damaged some vehicles that belong to some of the volunteers that work for the Forest Service,'' said Alexis Jackson, a spokeswoman for the White Mountain National Forest. On Sunday night, ``they entered a tent that a woman was sleeping in.'' Jackson said the female camper was not injured. She did not have the woman's name and said a report had not been filed yet. ``I don't know if she had food in the tent with her, or just had clothes on that she wore when she cooked,'' Jackson said. The smell of food doesn't have to be very strong to attract bears. ``They have a very sensitive sense of smell,'' she said. The damaged vehicles were at parking lots up to five miles from the campsites. Jackson said Forest Service employees placed traps to catch the animals so they can be moved to a more remote area. No one has gotten a good look at the bears because they have turned up mainly at night, but both are fairly large, she said. ``We see a lot of bear up in there, but they don't normally bother people,'' she said. ``Black bear are kind of reclusive and they don't usually bother people.'' The last time Jackson said she could determine that bears had bothered campers and hikers in the national forest was in 1980, when bears also began raiding campsites for food. She said she has not found any record of anyone being killed by a black bear in New Hampshire.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SAN ANTONIO, Texas
High Court Refuses to Free Reporter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with court action
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Monday it would not free a Texas television reporter serving a six-month jail term for refusing to reveal the name of a confidential source. The justices, by a 7-2 vote, rejected an emergency request by reporter Brian Karem of KMOL-TV in San Antonio. Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall voted to grant Karem's request that he be freed pending his appeal of the judge's contempt order that led to his jailing. Karem was jailed June 27 after refusing to disclose the identity of a source who helped arrange his telephone interview last year with jailed murder suspect Henry Hernandez. Hernandez is charged with fatally shooting San Antonio Police Officer Gary Williams in March 1989. Attorneys in the murder trial of Hernandez and his brother, Julian, have said they need to know who arranged the interview to assure a fair trial and determine whether the interview should be admitted as evidence. Henry Hernandez said in the interview that he shot the officer in self-defense. Sheriff Harlow Copeland of Bexar County, Texas, said last week that he tracked down the source who helped Karem and identified the individual as Hernandez's cousin. Karem has refused to say whether the cousin was the source. Supreme Court Justice Byron R. White on June 28 denied an earlier bid by Karem to be freed. Karem renewed his request by asking Brennan for help, and Brennan referred the matter to the full court. Meanwhile, the Society of Professional Journalists called Sunday for Karem's immediate release and commended the reporter and his station ``for their dedication and willingness to stand by the principles in which we believe even in the face of such adversity and at the cost of such high personal sacrifice.''

DOC.HEAD: KGB Chief Says 8 of His Agents Defected in Past 11 Years
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB5
DOC.TEXT: The KGB chief said Monday that eight Soviet intelligence agents have defected to the West since 1979 and a spy from an unidentified foreign power was arrested in the past three weeks. Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, answering questions from delegates to the 28th Congress of the Communist Party, denied accusations by a former KGB general that the agency was ineffective in its counterintelligence and intelligence operations and had spied on Soviet citizens. ``All these are bald-faced lies,'' said Kryuchkov, who as a member of the Politburo was required by the congress to account for his activities and answer questions. Former KGB Maj. Gen. Oleg D. Kalugin has caused a sensation in the Soviet media since he surfaced last month, accusing the KGB of spying on the leaders of strike committees and emerging political groups, of running weak counterintelligence operations, and of having spy rings around the world blown through the defections of key agents. Kryuchkov defended the government for stripping Kalugin of his rank of major general and all of his service awards. The order was signed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has not commented publicly on the issue. Kryuchkov said the ``Committee for State Security (KGB) ... acknowledges that failures and errors in personnel selection that sometimes cause severe losses.'' But, he said, ``in the last 11 years, eight of our agents have gone into the service of the West, not 20 as Kalugin claims.'' Kryuchkov also said that ``about three weeks ago, another foreign intelligence agent was arrested. We did not report that. An investigation is under way, whose results will be communicated to the public.'' He also cited the arrest of two other alleged spies, A. Tolkachev, who worked in a sensitive military field, and a man named Polyakov, who he said spied for 25 years. The KGB has been waging a propaganda campaign against Kalugin, and Kryuchkov carried it into the Kremlin Palace of Congresses, where the Communist congress was meeting. ``Delegates asked me to talk about about Kalugin,'' Kryuchkov said. ``He was accepted into the service of the KGB in 1952, with the help of his father, a career officer in the NKVD,'' a forerunner of the KGB. ``Kalugin's career started to take off in the 1970s. In 1970 he became chief of internal counterintelligence, and quickly attained the rank of general. When Kalugin climbed the service staircase, he said nothing critical about the organs of state security or our political system,'' said Kryuchkov. ``But a complex situation involving him arose in 1979. The leadership of the Committee on State Security was forced to make a decision that he could no longer work in intelligence,'' he said. He did not give particulars, but said that ``as a result of his incompetence and breaches of discipline, we lost a valuable source of information.'' Kalugin was transferred to Leningrad, but ran afoul of authorities there, too, and was retired at age 55, said the KGB chief. On retirement, ``Kalugin tried to bargain with the leaders of the KGB, and threatened to turn to the press,'' but the KGB refused, Kryuchkov said. ``And Kalugin soon started to carry out his threats. On June 14, he gave a speech on Radio Liberty,'' the U.S.-government funded radio station broadcasting to the Soviet Union from West Germany. ``He waged a steady campaign against the organs of state security, in interviews with the Soviet and foreign press, in speeches and on television. He presented the KGB as an all-powerful monster, an organization of penetrating all spheres of society,'' Kryuchkov said. ``The KGB was said to be putting the brakes on the reform and democratization of the country ... Kalugin portrayed the majority of contemporary Chekists (KGB officers) as open Stalinists,'' Kryuchkov said. He denied all of Kalugin's allegations.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Engineers Believe They've Found Source of Shuttle Problem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, ``How big, with three grafs, shuttle boss comments; picks up 5th grav pvs, ``They did
DOC.TEXT: Engineers at Rockwell International in California may have located the source of a mysterious hydrogen leak that grounded the space shuttle fleet, officials said today. NASA spokesman Kyle Herring at the Johnson Space Center in Houston said that tests on Sunday found hydrogen pouring from plumbing attachments that had been removed from space shuttle Columbia. It was not immediately clear now long it would take to fix the leak and resume flights with the three-vehicle space shuttle fleet. William Lenoir, associate administrator for space flight at NASA, said investigators found ``a significant leak,'' but said they don't know which seal, valve or pipe in the maze of tubes is specifically leaking. ``We haven't eliminated any suspects,'' he said. Lenoir said engineers are looking hardest at a U-shaped, Teflon seal that prevents leakage at a joint where the external tank is jettisoned from the shuttle during launch. Herring said, ``How big the leak rate is, they don't know yet.'' ``They did get some sort of leak. It's on the orbiter side,'' he said. The winged spacecraft that carries the astronauts is called the orbiter. Rockwell was testing an apparatus called the umbilical. This is a group of pipes and valves that link the orbiter with the external tank, the large orange tank that holds the rocket propellant for the shuttle's main rocket engines during launch. NASA discovered a leak somewhere in the umbilical plumbing in May when Columbia's external tank was being loaded with rocket propellant. The source of the leak could not be found and NASA rolled Columbia back to the hanger and dismantled the umbilical. It was sent to Rockwell for testing. Engineers found a leak on space shuttle Atlantis that was similar to the one on Columbia. NASA space flight chief William Lenoir ordered the space shuttle fleet grounded until the source of the leak could be found and fixed. Lenoir said Friday that the Rockwell test was a key move toward correction of the leak. He said a leak test is now planned for late this week on Atlantis, which is still sitting on a launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir's Cabinet Wins First No Confidence Threat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new government surviving first confidence vote, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Cabinet easily survived its first test of no confidence on Monday when Parliament rejected five motions over a housing shortage and new Jewish settler guard units in the occupied lands. A close vote had been anticipated in the 120-member Knesset, where a coalition headed by Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc has a narrow majority of 62 seats. The opposition has a total of 58 seats, including 38 held by Likud's major rival, the center-left Labor Party. But following a five-hour debate, the five motions of no confidence were defeated, 60 to 51. Five legislators put themselves on record as abstaining and four did not vote. One left-wing legislator, Avraham Poraz of the Shinui Party, decided not to vote to cancel out the absence of Sara Doron of Likud, who was hospitalized after heart surgery. Poraz told Israel radio he acted on ``moral grounds'' after hearing Likud was considering taking Doron by ambulance to vote if a majority was not assured. Two other legislators also did not vote. The motions against Shamir were filed by five left-wing parties and won support from the Labor Party, headed by former Prime Minister Shimon Peres. It was the first threat to Shamir's coalition, made up of 10 religious and ultra-nationalist parties, since it was installed June 11 at the end of a three-month political crisis. The political crisis began March 15, when Labor toppled a joint coalition with Likud in a parliamentary vote of no confidence as a protest against Shamir's opposition to U.S. proposals for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Monday's motions focused on a housing shortage at a time when thousands of Soviets are emigrating to Israel. In the past month, hundreds of homeless Israelis have pitched tents in public parks around the country to dramatize the issue. Also on the agenda were motions against the government's recent decision to set up civil guard units in the occupied West Bank. The government earlier announced approval of two units, but revealed Monday that five were actually approved. Defense Minister Moshe Arens told Parliament the Jewish settlers in the occupied lands deserved the same protection as all the citizens of the state. But critics fear these units could spur further Jewish vigilante attacks on Arabs and exacerbate the 31-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israel in the occupied lands.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Hits Hezbollah Bases, Possible Hostage Release Feared Threatened
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted bases of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah for a second day Monday, killing 12 people and raising fears the violence might thwart the anticipated release of a Western hostage. Police said eight civilians and four combatants of Hezbollah, or Party of God, were killed. Twenty-eight others, including 10 fighters, were wounded, they said. A police spokesman said four U.S.-built F-4 Phantom fighter bombers mounted two bombing runs, 10 minutes apart, on Loweizeh and Melita in southern Lebanon. Palls of black smoke hung over the stricken targets in Iqlim al-Tuffah, or the Apple region, overlooking Israel's self-designated ``security zone,'' the spokesman said. The attacks came a day after Israeli jets had flattened a Hezbollah base two miles to the south. Three fighters were killed and 12 wounded in Sunday's raid. In Jerusalem, the Israeli military command said its warplanes struck targets used by Hezbollah for ``organizing and launching attacks'' and returned safely. It did not elaborate. Later Monday, Israeli artillerymen in the security zone traded heavy artillery fire with Hezbollah positions north of the buffer, police and U.N. sources said. A U.N. source said at that one point, the international peacekeepers monitored a barrage of 12 Katyusha rockets fired by Hezbollah into the security zone, which Israel established in 1985. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. Voice of the South, the radio of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia, said three people were killed and five wounded in the barrage. Monday's air attack was Israel's third in four days and 15th this year. In 14 previous raids, 19 people were killed and 51 wounded. The sudden escalation of violence coincided with reports that a Western hostage, most probably a European, would soon be freed by Moslem captors. ``Let us pray the Israeli attacks will not scuttle efforts to free one of the hostages,'' said a Shiite source close to Hezbollah's Iranian-backed leadership. ``The hostage-holders are definitely restless, but I personally believe Iran's pressure will probably override the impact of the attacks,'' he said on condition of anonymity. Danny Neveh, spokesman for Defense Minister Moshe Arens, rejected any links between the raids and hostages and said the timing of the air strikes was ``based only on our operating policy against terrorism.'' An Israeli government source said the timing of the latest raids might look unfortunate, but could be the result of a lack of coordination between the military and political echelons in Israel. He spoke on condition of anonymity. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States views the attacks ``as part of the cycle of violence which harms all the parties in the region.'' ``We are against all acts of violence committed by different groups in southern Lebanon,'' he said. Shiite fundamentalists accuse Western governments of favoring Israel and hold them responsible for its actions against Arabs. A Shiite source, who requested anonymity, said Tehran was pushing hard for the release of a hostage in appreciation for aid it received after the June 21 killer earthquake there. He would not speculate on the identity of the hostage, despite expectations in Beirut, London and Dublin that it would probably be Irish educator Brian Keenan. The Irish Red Cross flew the first Western relief plane into Tehran after the earthquake, in which 40,000 people were killed. The hostages are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. A source close to the Syrian command in Moslem west Beirut said Sunday he did not expect a hostage to be freed before the middle of the week. Syria, Lebanon's main power broker, has 40,000 troops in control of 70 percent of Lebanon's territory under a 1976 Arab League mandate to snuff out the civil war, now in its 16th year. The Syrians were instrumental in the release of American hostages Robert Polhill on April 22 and Frank Reed on April 30.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead in 2nd item to remove extraneous word
DOC.TEXT: The British rock group Pink Floyd is planning to stage an $8 million concert extravaganza based on its album ``The Wall'' in Berlin, where else, next to the Wall. The performance, set for July 21 at Patzdamer Platz near the site of the Brandenburg Gate, will feature the construction and demolition of a 80-foot-tall, 600-foot-long wall. The concert will launch a five-year campaign to raise $800 million for the Memorial Fund for Disaster Relief, said founding member Roger Waters. ``I want Russians, Germans, Americans building the wall and tearing it down, as a symbolic act of collaboration and the aims of the Memorial Fund,'' Waters said by telephone from London. The group wants to get ``the armed forces freed to do disaster relief work when they have time off from training or polishing their boots,'' Waters said. The movie version of ``The Wall,'' a story of a troubled rock star, was released in 1979 and is based on the band's album. Some 19 million albums were sold worldwide. Due to join Waters on stage in Berlin are Sinead O'Connor, Van Morrison, Thomas Dolby, The Band, Bryan Adams, The Scorpions, the East Berlin Rundfunk Symphony Orchestra, and the East Berlin Radio Choir.

DOC.HEAD: Sun Powers 31 Cars Racing 1,600 Miles into Future
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Rays of sun powered wheels of thunder on 31 exotically styled cars that hit the road Monday in a 1,600-mile race. The shiny, low-slung vehicles caused many doubletakes among motorists along U.S. 192 shortly after leaving their starting point at Walt Disney World. All of the automobiles for the 11-day GM Sunrayce USA were designed and built by college engineering students from the United States and Canada at costs ranging from about $30,000 to more than $1 million. The cars are powered strictly by the sun and solar-energy storage batteries. The winner will have the lowest elapsed time over secondary roads in eight states. The race is in daily stages, with each car starting at the same point each day. It ends July 19 at the General Motors technical center outside Detroit. GM President Bob Stempel said he hoped the race would serve as an incentive for young people to study science and engineering. Among the entries was a pontoonlike auto with two drivers in fishbowl-shaped cockpits facing in opposite directions. That one's from Western Washington University. The ``Sunshine Special'' from Florida Institute of Technology features wraparound solar cells, including the bottom of the car to catch sunlight reflected off the road. ``Midnight Sun'' from the University of Waterloo-Ontario, Canada, looks like a flying saucer gliding down the highway, and the University of Texas reportedly spent more than $1 million on its 340-pound dynamo made out of carbon graphite. Many of the entrants and officials were talking about the unique solar array on the bottom of Florida's car, which Professor Bill Thrasher said was ``a closely guarded secret'' for almost two years. Thrasher said tests showed that the reflected solar energy was about one-third as much as that captured from the top of the car. The entry cost $225,000 to build. The governor's energy office contributed $95,000, the rest came from about 40 sponsors. The auto from Massachusetts Institute of Technology is a squat, buglike affair with only the driver's head showing. It cost only $30,000 to build, said MIT driver Thomas Massie. Tuesday's leg from Floral City will end in Tallahassee, 192 miles away by the planned rural route. Wednesday, the drivers hope the cars will run 205 miles from Tallahassee to Montgomery, Ala., via Georgia. The race is sponsored by GM, the U.S. Department of Energy and the Society of Automotive Engineers. GM and the Energy Department provided each school with $7,000 in seed money to start their projects last year. The top two finishers and a third selected for technological innovation will be sent by GM to compete in the 1990 World Solar Challenge in Australia. ``We want to encourage students to pursue science and engineering in the future,'' said Stempel. The other states along the route are Tennessee, Kentucky, Indiana and Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Assault Slows in Liberia; Gov't Troops Roam Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This pool report was filed by journalists in Monrovia. Associated Press correspondent Michelle Faul was among them.
DOC.TEXT: The rebel assault on the capital appeared to have slowed Monday and government troops roamed the city, reportedly killing suspected insurgents. Automatic and semi-automatic gunfire and rockets echoed through the eastern suburb of Paynesville, eight miles from the city center. Rebels have said they are fighting there from house to house. It was not immediately clear what caused the rebel advance to slow. On Monday, the rebel radio station was reported to have said insurgents accepted a cease-fire proposed last week by President Samuel Doe. The radio said a rebel delegation would attend peace talks in Freetown, Sierra Leone aimed at ending the six-month tribal war. The talks were scheduled to begin Tuesday. But in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, chief rebel spokesman Tom Woewiyu said Sunday the rebels rejected a truce, and were sticking to their demand that Doe leave Liberia before fighting could stop. There have also been reports of infighting among rebel comanders. The rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 to overthrow Doe's government. They accuse Doe of corruption, tribalism and brutal suppression of opposition. Hundreds of civilians have been killed in the past week since rebels attacked the outskirts of the Liberian capital in an attempt to end Doe's 10-year rule. On Monday, three soldiers drove a man to the Monrovia's Atlantic Ocean shore, ordered him out of the car and shouted: ``Go to the beach.'' The man imploringly waved his identity papers. All three then pumped bullets into his head, back and legs from their U.S.-supplied M-16 automatic rifles just outside the front gate of the home of Dennis Jett, second-in-command at the U.S. Embassy. The soldiers told reporters who watched: ``This man is a rebel.'' The troops said they believed the man was a rebel because he said he was going to buy rice but had only $1.15 in his pocket. A cup of rice now costs $2. Doe's troops have been accused of killing hundreds of members of the Gio and Mano tribes, who support the rebels. The rebels have retaliated by killing members of the Krahn and Mandingo people, who back the government. Monrovia has been without water, electricity and fresh food for more than a week and food prices have soared. Monrovians lined up for hours outside a handful of supermarkets under army guard on Monday. Shopkeepers, fearful of soldiers who have been looting stores, opened only because Doe ordered them to in a Sunday broadcast. Doe also asked government workers to return to work, but most offices and shops remained closed. The broadcast was made from a makeshift radio in his executive mansion, protected by a presidential guard. The national bank, which was robbed by soldiers of about $2.5 million last week opened Monday to pay civil servants their wages. Thousands of Liberians have fled the country over the past two months. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the U.S. was arranging charter flights for a half-dozen Americans who asked for help leaving Liberia. The embassy has already evacuated most Americans from the country. In Monrovia's port, soldiers stole 50 Romanian Dacia jeeps from a ship which they had forced to berth Sunday. Doe had ordered one of his few remaining vessels to intercept the Rupea, shipping sources said without giving details. Doe seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of American slaves who founded this country in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Will Cut Its Oil Exports
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, facing a lack of fuel for domestic use, will cut its oil exports by 140,000 barrels a day, according to Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer, although production levels have been declining. The U.S. government estimated 1989 total Soviet oil output at 12.14 million barrels per day. Production has fallen because of the cost of maintaining output as well as ethnic unrest in oil producing regions such as Azerbaijan. Ryzhkov said the government decided in late June to cut its oil exports by 7 million metric tons, or 140,000 barrels a day. The cut in exports would apply to socialist bloc countries as well as Western nations, he said Saturday, answering questions by delegates to the 28th Communist Party Congress on the upcoming Soviet harvest. ``This will permit us to supply our agriculture,'' Ryzhkov said, adding that otherwise, fuel shortages would hurt the harvest.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Summit Rpd, Bjt
Sightseeing, Socializing On Summit Spouses Schedule
DOC.TEXT: As the summit leaders focus on global issues, their spouses have a full schedule of sightseeing and socializing, starting with a private dinner at friends of President Bush's Monday night. The seven leaders of the industrialized world planned a working dinner Monday at Bayou Bend, a mansion-turned-museum, while they spouses were guests of Betty and Hugh Liedtkes. The Liedtkes, close friends of both Bush and his wife, Barbara, invited the spouses to their home for dinner in the upscale Memorial neighborhood. Liedtke is a wealthy oil man who knew Bush when the president was in the oil business in Texas before entering politics. On Tuesday, the spouses planned to fly to San Antonio to tour the Alamo, the Mission San Jose and the renovated Majestic Theatre. San Antonio also was in the running to host the economic summit, but the city lost out to Houston, Bush's adopted hometown. . The Alamo is the site of the historic 1836 battle between the Mexican army and a group of men led by Col. William Travis who were fighting for Texas' independence from Mexico. Mexican Gen. Santa Anna's troops greatly outnumbered the Alamo forces, although historical records do not provide an exact number. The Mexican soldiers laid siege on the Alamo for 14 days before attacking. All of Travis' men _ 189 _ were killed, and the tragic fight gave birth to the battle cry, ``Remember the Alamo!'' for other Texans fighting for freedom. After visiting San Antonio, the spouses were to return to Houston. They also planned to tour the Texas Medical Center on Wednesday, the final day of the summit. Besides Mrs. Bush, the spouses include France's Danielle Mitterrand, Canada's Mila Mulroney, Italy's Livia Andreotti, Japan's Sachiyo Kaifu and England's Denis Thatcher, the only male spouse. Hannelore Kohl, wife of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and Marie Delors, wife of European Commission President Jacques Delors did not accompany their husbands to Texas. The wives of several other local leaders also planned to attend Monday night's dinner at the Liedtke home. The menu included quail, gazpacho soup, shrimp creole remoulade, poached snapper and asparagus. Dessert was called strawberries summit. After dinner, the group was to be entertained by a string trio and a singing duo. The trio's members are all teen-agers. Bush and Liedtke met years ago in West Texas while both were in the oil business, and they helped form Zapata Petroleum. Eventually, the company's investors spilt, although Liedtke and Bush remained friends. Liedtke is the former chief of Houston-based Pennzoil Co., the oil company that won an $10.3 billion judgment in 1985 from Texaco Inc. over Texaco's takeover of Getty Oil Co. Pennzoil later settled for $3 billion. Liedtke is still chairman of Pennzoil's board.

DOC.HEAD: Howard Duff, Popular Radio, TV Character Actor, Dead at 76
DOC.TEXT: Character actor Howard Duff, who played tough detective Sam Spade on radio in the 1940s and Sheriff Titus Semple on TV's ``Flamingo Road'' in the 1980s, has died. He was 76. Duff died Sunday night at his home, said Judy Duff, his wife of 17 years. She said authorities believe her husband suffered a heart attack. Duff had taken part in a telethon Saturday night to raise money for victims of last month's devastating Santa Barbara fire, which left hundreds homeless. He was a regular on such hit television series of the 1950s and '60s as ``Mr. Adams and Eve,'' ``Dante'' and ``Felony Squad'' and appeared in many movies, including ``Kramer vs. Kramer,'' ``The Late Show'' and ``The Wedding.'' In recent years, he was a guest on such shows as ``The Golden Girls,'' ``Midnight Caller'' and ``Knot's Landing.'' In addition to his wife, survivors include a daughter, Bridget, and a brother, Doug. Mrs. Duff said a memorial service will be held at a later date in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Fancy Food: Restaurants Compete From Soup to Nuts
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Restaurant and gourmet shop purveyors savored caviar soup, cactus salsa and other eccentric vittles Monday at a 19,000-course meal: the international fancy-food trade show. ``It adds a prickly flavor,'' W. Park Kerr, president of the El Paso Chile Co., said of his salsa, which features cactus leaves that were harvested ``very, very carefully,'' then dethorned with a vegetable peeler. Kerr was among about 1,250 vendors who eagerly angled their estimated 19,000 products at the Fancy Food & Confection Show in the Javits convention center. Their customers, thousands of industry buyers, milled around _ munching, networking and sipping wine from shot-glass-size plastic cups. Show-goers were plied with olives, espresso and wild-rice muffins; Belgian waffles, turkey sausage and espresso. Crackers were topped with cheese, or dipped in sauces and jams. Bags of ``all-natural'' potato chips beckoned. One woman, wearing shocking-pink roller skates and matching miniskirt, circulated with a tray of scones. An array of cake, cookies and chocolates made for a dieter's dream _ or nightmare. Tom and Sally Fegley of Brattleboro, Vt., hawked ``Cow Pies.'' The chocolate patties, with labels bearing animal cartoons, are sold in Washington, D.C., as ``Donkey Pies''; in New Jersey as ``Road Apples''; in Maine as ``Moose Pies'' and _ well, you get the picture. ``Ham I Am,'' a company from Plano, Texas, offered Hogwash, a sweet-pungent sauce, sampled with cubes of peppered ham. Company founder Sharon Meehan, mother of four, invented Hogwash in her kitchen; now it's sold by Nieman-Marcus and elsewhere for about $5 a jar. Bewley Irish Imports suggested topping toast with orange-whiskey marmalade. ``It does give you a little nip, but you don't get a buzz at breakfast, unless maybe you eat the whole jar,'' advised assistant manager Chris Hausler. The Hansen Caviar Company Inc. had a chef whip up a little chilled beluga caviar soup. The recipe calls for one-half pound ripe tomatoes, 1 cucumber, 2 onions. ... Actually, with 14 ounces of Hansen-Sturm Russian Beluga retailing for up to $750, do inquiring minds really want to know? Ron Tanner, spokesman for the National Association for the Specialty Food Trade Inc., said he'd noticed more health-oriented products, such as low-cholesterol cheeses and sugar-free jams and cookies, aimed at the general market this year. But Tanner said that doesn't necessarily indicate a trimming trend. Instead, he said, Americans seem to be devouring the decadent stuff _ then assuaging their guilt with diet foods. There was opportunity for both at the convention center. At the show, which continues through Wednesday, even the strong capitulated at the sight and aroma of food, food, food. In their midst was a courageous model of self-control: James Gilbert, salesman for Bel Canto Fancy Foods, whose salmon-pesto mousse was unveiled late Monday as the association's 1990 winner in the meat, pate and game category. ``This is my lunch,'' said Gilbert, downing a Slim Fast diet bar between sales pitches.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Announces Aid to Nicaraguan Orphans
DOC.TEXT: Orphanages in Nicaragua will receive kits for eye examinations for children and supplies to help grow vegetables as part of a $1.4 million grant announced Monday by the Agency for International Development. The grant was made to Partners of the Americas, a private voluntary association that works through state chapters to provide humanitarian and developmental assistance to Latin America. The group's Wisconsin affiliate will carry out the Nicaraguan program. AID said the grant will provide medical, psychological and nutritional care to orphans, whose country has been battered by almost a decade of war between the former Sandinista regime and the disbanded U.S.-backed Contra rebels. It will also strengthen hospitals, clinics and other institutions, the agency said. ``This grant represents one of many U.S. activities recently initiated in Nicaragua and is an example of our desire to assist the Nicaraguan people in rebuilding their lives,'' said James H. Michel, assistant AID administrator for Latin America. AID has also initiated three grants totaling $4 million to provide health assistance for victims of the civil strife and designated $2.5 million for emergency medical supplies, Michel said. The money will be used to train health care professionals and procure medicine, vitamins, food and recreational equipment for 15 orphanages, he said. Each orphanage will receive supplies for a self-help project to grow vegetables to improve the children's diets. The grant will also provide eye examination kits for the children. The Wisconsin Lions Clubs will donate eyeglasses for children with vision problems.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Investigators Delayed Probe of FBI Agent
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after a pregnant FBI informant was slain last year, state police had evidence that a federal agent was her lover and may have played a role in her disappearance, according to a published report. But eight months went by before investigators focused their probe on former FBI special agent Mark Putnam. He confessed last month to strangling Ms. Smith on June 8, 1989, during a dispute over her expected child. Some outside law enforcement experts said police erred by not making Putnam the prime suspect earlier, the Lexington Herald-Leader reported Sunday. In a controversial plea agreement the day he was indicted, Putnam pleaded guilty on June 12 to manslaughter. He immediately received a 16-year prison sentence. Ms. Smith's family, outraged at the deal, wanted him to stand trial for murder. John Paul Runyon, the commonwealth's attorney in eastern Kentucky's Pike County, said last month that without Putnam's confession, ``we had absolutely no evidence'' to prosecute the former agent. Afterward, the Herald-Leader reviewed the state police case file, interviewed investigators and witnesses, and asked several law enforcement experts to examine the file and evaluate the investigation. The newspaper concluded that authorities ``might have been able to build a case against Putnam if they had reacted promptly to information that pointed to him.'' Two weeks after Ms. Smith disappeared on June 8, 1989, police knew she may have been pregnant by Putnam, the newspaper reported. Police also knew Putnam threatened her before when she discussed the pregnancy. And Ms. Smith was expecting Putnam to pick her up at a hotel the day she disappeared, according to the newspaper. Further, Putnam and his partner, special agent Ron Poole, were giving contradictory accounts of why Smith was at the motel, the newspaper said. ``There was plenty of physical evidence that they could have developed,'' said Anthony V. Bouza, a former police chief of Minneapolis. Police did no laboratory examination of the motel room where Ms. Smith and Putnam stayed the night before her death or of the belongings she left there, Bouza said. And they didn't quickly locate the rental car Putnam was driving when he killed Ms. Smith. State police Detective Richard Ray, the lead investigator, acknowledged it was ``kind of awkward to investigate'' an FBI agent. ``But I tried to think of everything,'' he added. ``I did suspect from the start that something could have happened. Something very bad.'' State police Capt. Gary Rose said authorities wanted to eliminate stronger suspects, including Ms. Smith's estranged husband, before pursuing Putnam. Detectives were not even convinced Ms. Smith was dead until last Christmas, when she didn't contact her two children, police said. The agent was questioned June 20, 1989, and offered to take a lie detector test, Rose said. Putnam became the prime suspect in February when he refused to take a polygraph. George Parry, a former head of special investigations for the Philadelphia district attorney and a former federal organized crime prosecutor, said state police made a sincere effort. But Parry said the FBI should not have allowed the suspect's partner, Poole, to investigate Smith's disappearance. The FBI has declined requests from The Associated Press and the Lexington newspaper to interview Poole.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Saudis Sign $3 Billion-Plus Tank Deal
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has signed an agreement to purchase 315 of the Army's most advanced tanks in a deal worth more than $3 billion, the Pentagon announced Monday. The M-1A2 tank, the most up-to-date version of the Abrams, the Army's main battle tank, is manufactured by the Lands Systems Division of General Dynamics Corp. The tanks are scheduled for delivery from 1993 through 1995. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, citing lessening chances for U.S. involvement in a major European land war, had proposed terminating the M-1 tank program in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The Saudi deal means that the nation's tank production lines, at plants in Lima, Ohio, and Warren, Mich., will not be shutting down. Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., applauded the arrangement as ``good news for Michigan and for the nation.'' Rep. Michael Oxley, R-Ohio, said the Saudi order alone isn't enough to prevent scheduled cutbacks at the two plants, but will enable the United States to offer lower prices for tank sales to other countries. The $3 billion agreement includes support equipment, spare parts, training, munitions and the construction of maintenance facilities, the Pentagon said in a statement. The M-1A2 version is outfitted with a 120mm gun and toughened armor to protect it against Soviet-produced antitank weapons systems. It also features special viewers for the gunner and tank commander that will allow each to seek out targets in the dark. The systems are separate from one another, enabling the gunner to shoot at one target while the commander seeks out the next one. Congress was told last year that the deal was pending. Bush administration officials have said that United States would ensure that Israel maintains a qualitative edge over Arab armed forces. Oxley said the Saudis wanted to tanks to patrol their border with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Borrowing Increases in May
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $3.9 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in May, 10 times the amount incurred only a month earlier, the government said Monday. The Federal Reserve said consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.5 percent, up from the previous month's 0.6 percent growth rate. Net new debt in April totaled $390 million. It was the highest annual rate of increase since a 7.5 percent rate in October when Americans borrowed $4.4 billion more than they paid off. The May increase was concentrated in credit card debt, which rose $3.1 billion, or an annual rate of 18.5 percent. Consumers, who account for about two-thirds of U.S. economic activity, had appeared to be more cautious in their borrowing and spending in recent months. Analysts had attributed the slower pace to high interest rates, waning confidence because of adverse economic news and to the high level of debt already held by many Americans. The annualized rate of credit growth for the first five months of 1990 was 3 percent, down from the 7.6 percent for all of 1989 and 8.5 percent for 1988. At the same time, Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percentage of disposable income _ has been pegged above 6 percent for several months after dropping to a low of 3.2 percent for all of 1987. Gilbert Benz, an economist with Swiss Bank Corp. in New York, said varying methods of computing economic statistics are used by different government agencies and occasionally produce different results. The Commerce Department's retail sales reports, which have fallen for three consecutive months, don't include services such as health care and have a smaller survey sample than the Fed's consumer credit reports, Benz said. Benz also said that April borrowing was weak and that the May borrowing was ``somewhat of a payback.'' ``Consumers are not dying,'' Benz said. ``Perhaps they're a little more cautious, definitely slowing, but by no means do we have a recession scenario.'' Automobile loans continued to decline in May, but at a slower rate. Debt dropped $87 million, a 0.4 percent rate of decline. That compared with a net decline in automobile debt of $2 billion the previous month. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $533 million, a 3.1 percent annual rate after a 4 percent annual growth rate in April. Borrowing for mobile homes increased $325 million, a 17.2 percent annual rate of growth after a 0.3 percent decline the previous month. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of May at $724.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop Testifies He Supports Homosexual Ministers _ If They Don't Have Sex
DOC.TEXT: The Lutheran bishop who filed charges against two churches for hiring homosexual ministers says he supports parishes led by gays and lesbians as long as the preachers do not engage in homosexual sex. ``I found it necessary to file charges because the congregations had violated the (church's) constitution on a very serious matter,'' said Lyle Miller, bishop of Sierra Pacific Synod, the regional judiciary branch of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. A 14-member church discipline committee was set to begin deliberations Tuesday after three days of meetings on whether to expel two San Francisco churches, St. Francis Lutheran and First United Lutheran, for ordaining a gay man and a lesbian couple who refused to take vows of celibacy. The panel is expected to issue a decision by July 17. Miller in 1989 refused to recommend Jeff Johnson, an openly gay man, for an ordained ministry because Johnson would not vow abstinence from homosexual relations. But the First United Lutheran Church hired Johnson as an assistant pastor in 1989. Two months later, St. Francis Lutheran ignored church guidelines and hired two lesbian pastors who also refused to pledge celibacy. The Evangelical Lutheran Church, with 5.3 million members, is the largest Lutheran body in the United States. Like other mainstream churches, it forbids ordination of sexually active homosexuals, arguing that sex should only be practiced within marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Employers, Government Shouldering Burden of Rising Health Care, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Out-of-pocket health expenses are taking the same size bite out of Americans' incomes as they were in the early 1970s, and even less than in 1960, according to a team of government researchers. Over the past three decades, as health costs have climbed, the government and employers have shared most of the increased costs, the Health Care Financing Administration researchers reported. Private insurance has been providing more benefits, largely because states are requiring more coverage, but employers have been unsuccessful in shifting the costs of better coverage to workers, said economist Katharine R. Levit. However, she predicts that will change. ``Businesses are essentially being squeezed (by medical costs) on the employer side and by competition on the price side,'' she said. ``Some reconciliation of the problem is going to have to occur.'' But while many business leaders and some politicians have been calling for changes in the nation's health care system, ``we as individuals don't feel the pressure yet,'' Levit said. ``And until we do, we won't join the ranks of business and government'' in clamoring for changes. In 1988, spending from all sources for health care in the United States was nearly $540 billion _ more than 11 percent of the gross national product that year, Levit and two colleagues reported in an article published in the summer issue of Health Affairs, a quarterly journal on health policy. The figures tallied by Levit, Mark Freeland and Dan Waldo are the latest comprehensive figures available, they said. National health expenditures have grown at an average annual rate of 11 percent over the past three decades, and 10.4 percent from 1987 to 1988. Americans used about 5 percent of their after-tax income in 1988 on health care expenses _ including their share of insurance premiums and out-of-pocket costs to meet deductibles and pay for medical care not covered by insurance. This proportion is the same as in 1972-73 and lower than the 6.1 percent of after-tax income used for health care expenses in 1960-61, the researchers reported. Since 1964-65, health spending has grown from 4.2 percent of all federal expenditures to nearly 14 percent in 1987, Levit said. For state and local expenditures combined, health spending has grown from 7.4 percent to 13 percent over the same period, she said. Businesses have seen their share of health insurance premiums increase from 2 percent of total employer compensation in 1965 to 6 percent in 1987, Levit said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Widows Divide Estate of Husband They Shared
DOC.TEXT: Two women have agreed to divide the $10 million estate of a husband they unknowingly shared for more almost three decades, according to court documents. The estate of Harry Glenn Davis, a Calhoun County landowner, included cash, rental property and real estate in Calhoun and Talladega counties, according to 1989 documents unsealed last week at the request of a local newspaper. Davis was married to Ruth Davis and Flossie Davis for 28 years but neither wife knew of the other until after his death in 1988. Ruth lived on the couple's Boiling Springs farm near Oxford, in northeast Alabama, while Flossie, one of Davis' former tenants, lived in Tallahassee, Fla. Davis commuted between the two sites, telling the women he spent weekdays ``handling his business interests'' in Calhoun County and weekends ``gambling in New Orleans,'' according to their attorneys. There were no children from the 51-year marriage between Davis and Ruth. Flossie, who was married to Davis for 28 years, had two children: Harry Glenn Davis Jr. and Debbie Anne Davis. When Davis died at age 76, he apparently left only one heir, Ruth. But a few months later, Flossie filed a 1969 will in which Davis left most of the estate to her and their two children. It provided $50,000 and a monthly allowance to Ruth. Ruth's lawyers contested the 1969 will and contended that Davis left the estate to Ruth in a will written in 1959, prior to Flossie's 1960 marriage. According to court records, Circuit Judge Harold Quattlebaum said his opinion was that the marriage of Flossie and Davis was null and void because Davis was legally married to Ruth at the time of the second union. But the women agreed to share the estate rather than risk getting nothing in the court battle. Neither received the amount they were seeking. Flossie had filed a claim for $10 million, and each child sought $2 million. Ruth had filed a claim for $40 million. In the settlement, Flossie was awarded $360,000 in cash, a $165,000 promissory note owed to Davis by Williamson Oil Co. and real estate appraised at more than $600,000. Her children received $20,000 each. Ruth received the remainder of the estate, including several thousand shares of stock, two checking accounts which contained undisclosed amounts and property appraised at about $5 million.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Americans Among 10 Alleged Sect Members Jailed, 22 Kids Held
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday said they had jailed 10 adults, including three Americans, and placed 22 minors under protective custody after raiding a commune belonging to an outlawed religious cult. The three U.S. citizens, six Spaniards and one Briton were arrested Sunday when the Catalonian regional police raided two villas near Barcelona that allegedly belonged to members of the Children of God sect. A police spokesman declined to identify those jailed, but said they were expected to appear before a Barcelona judge on Tuesday on suspicion of kidnapping and illegal proselytizing. Children of God, also known as the Family of Love, was founded in California in 1968 by an itinerant preacher named David Berg. The group came to Europe in the early 1970s and has been criticized by parents of members who say it relies on brainwashing and hypnotism to woo and hold its young members. The police spokesman said the children, who were living with eight of the adults in one of the villas, were being held in a public foster care center. They included nine Spaniards and 13 others, and range in age from 11 months to 14 years, said the spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with custom. The group has been declared illegal in Spain, according to Pilar Salarruyana, former chairwoman of a parliamentary committee that investigates sects. The sect has been involved in several skirmishes with the law in Spain since the mid-1980s, authorities say.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle's Space Council to Receive Nearly $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a bill Monday providing $983,000 for Vice President Dan Quayle's National Space Council. The council, created last year as part of the Executive Office of the president, is conducting a study for Congress of the country's space launch capacity. Quayle chairs the council. Bush signed the spending bill before the opening here of the 16th annual economic summit of the world's seven largest industrialized nations. He also signed a bill designating July 19 as ``Flight Attendant Safety Professionals' Day.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Albanians Rally in Kosovo; Provincial President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians staged peaceful demonstrations and strikes throughout the troubled southern province of Kosovo on Monday to protest the near-abolition of Kosovo's autonomy. In the provincial capital of Pristina, 150 miles south of Belgrade, baton-wielding security forces dispersed a crowd of about 1,000 people. But witnesses and the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug said the vast majority of employees of Albanian origin left their jobs in state-run companies Monday and peacefully paraded on the streets of Kosovo towns. Hisen Kajdomcaj, president of Kosovo's collective state presidency, and two other members of the body resigned Monday to protest last week's decision by Serbia's Communist authorities to dissolve local governing bodies in Kosovo. In resigning, they described Serbia's action as ``a drastic, unconstitutional attack on the ... province.'' Kosovo is an administrative part of Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics. Serbia's move all but abolished the autonomy Kosovo was granted under the 1974 federal constitution. In reply, Kosovo's ethnic Albanian opposition groups organized the ``peaceful resistance protest.'' ``The autonomy of the province is guaranteed by the constitution, and cannot be jeopardized,'' they said in a joint letter of resignation carried by Tanjug. They appealed to the leadership of this nation of more than 23.4 million people to ``undertake immediate measures to ensure the democratic settlement of the situation.'' Serbian authorities disbanded the local assembly and government after 114 ethnic Albanian members of the assembly announced plans to declare Kosovo's full autonomy from Serbia. Both dismantled bodies were dominated by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million people. On Monday, heavy security forces patrolled the streets of Pristina, occasionally breaking up smaller groups of protesters, witnesses said. At least 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes with security forces since Kosovo's autonomy was limited by constitutional changes enacted by Serbia in March 1989. Serbia also announced Thursday that the managers and leading Albanian journalists of local news organizations were being replaced. Albanian-language programs on Pristina radio and television were taken off the air. The Rilindja Albanian-language newspaper was banned. Tanjug said the daily did not appear on Monday because police impounded its entire circulation during the night. Serbian authorities say ethnic Albanians seek independence and have pressured Serbs to move out of Kosovo. Ethnic Albanians deny it. They want free elections and a multiparty system, and say Serbia's Communist leader, Slobodan Milosevic, is using the Kosovo issue to gain popular support for his brand of orthodox single-party rule.

DOC.HEAD: Marathon McMartin Case is Placed in Hands of Second Jury
DOC.TEXT: The nation's longest and costliest criminal court proceeding went to a jury Monday for a second time, with a judge telling jurors to ignore public opinion in deciding charges against Raymond Buckey. ``It's been close to seven years of my life and now it's come to a finale, McMartin Two, the summer rerun,'' Buckey told reporters outside court, referring to the now defunct McMartin Pre-School. ``Twelve more people will decide my fate.'' Buckey is charged with eight counts of molestation involving three young girls who once attended the Manhattan Beach preschool operated by his family. Buckey, 32, is the only one of seven teachers accused of molesting children at the preschool still facing charges. Charges against five of the teachers were dismissed and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted on all counts following the first trial. At the first trial, Buckey was acquitted on 40 counts of sexually abusing children at the school. Jurors deadlocked on 13 other charges against him, however, and prosecutors refiled on eight of those counts. Jurors began deliberations after Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg delivered 30 minutes of instructions. He addressed the issue of witness credibility, focusing on how jurors should view the unique testimony of child witnesses. ``You should not discount or distrust the testimony of a child, or give it greater weight, solely because the witness is a child.'' Weisberg said. The retrial, which lasted just three months, followed a two-year preliminary hearing and a nearly three-year trial. That was the nation's longest court proceding and cost Los Angeles over $13.5 million _ a record for a criminal trial. Buckey took the stand in both trials to deny he ever molested children. Both trials have been held in a highly charged atmosphere, and Weisberg told jurors they must not base their decision on public opinion about the notorious case. ``You must base your decision on the facts and the law,'' he said. The retrial featured testimony from three young girls who said Buckey molested them when they were students at the preschool. The defense alleged the children were influenced by therapists who interviewed them in the early stages of the case, and suggested their testimony was unreliable. Prosecutors said the children should be believed, although they acknowledged that memories had faded over the years. The children who were barely verbal when they attended the school are now 12-and 13-years-old, prosecutors noted. Buckey was arrested nearly seven years ago and spent five years in jail before a judge released him on bail. The defendant said outside court he has not decided what to do with the rest of his life. ``For a long time I didn't want to deal with society. I wanted to go away and become a hermit. But now, people come up to me and ask me how I got through this. Maybe I can help other people. ... I don't know what I'll do, maybe grow Christmas trees in Oregon, maybe give advice on how you survive a witch hunt.'' The prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Joseph Martinez told reporters: ``We're confident that if the jury views the testimony of the children and considers the medical evidence and the testimony of the parents, we feel the jury might convict. ... You never know.''

The Environmental Protection Agency outlined hazardous waste cleanup procedures and standards on Monday that it said could cost private industry as much as $42 billion to carry out. EPA administrator William K. Reilly called the plan ``a pragmatic approach for correcting existing problems'' and said it will ensure ``to the extent practical'' prevention of releases that might threaten human health and the environment. The proposed standards and procedures, affecting a wide range of industries and federal facilities regulated under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, will be published later this month in the Federal Register. The public will have 60 days from publication date to comment on them. Public hearings have been scheduled in San Francisco and Washington, D.C. in October. EPA said the new regulations would affect 3,000 to 4,000 facilities, including several hundred owned by the federal government. The agency estimated it could cost privately owned facilities between $7 billion and $42 billion to meet the requirements. The price tag for federal facilities would total $3 billion to $18 billion, EPA said in a statement. ``The scope of the work that needs to be done under this program underscores the value of preventing, rather than having to clean up, pollution,'' Reilly said. The wide range of the cost estimates is due to markedly varied conditions from site to site involving uncertain levels of ground water monitoring and cleanup, the agency said. EPA said its plan allows corrective actions to be tailored to site-specific conditions and sets health-based standards for the cleanup of pollutants. The plan also contains requirements on how wastes must be stored, treated or disposed of during cleanups. Remedies would have to be consistent with those required under the agency's Superfund cleanup program. Industries affected would include petroleum refiners, wood preservers, metal finishers and auto manufacturers. Further information on the proposal can be obtained from EPA by calling 1-800-424-9346.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Army, Air Force Could Cut Rosters by 120,000
DOC.TEXT: Faced with a lessening Soviet threat and fewer dollars for defense, the Pentagon could cut Army and Air Force rosters by 120,000 personnel by restricting re-enlistments, imposing early retirements and reducing promotions, analysts said Monday. But a study by the Congressional Budget Office found that the savings from an across-the-board approach would amount to only $900 million from the $307 billion President Bush has proposed in military spending in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Savings totaling $1.4 billion would occur if the services simply scaled back promotions, a step that would be feasible only if the Army and Air Force expect no additional active-duty personnel cuts beyond 1991, the CBO said. This approach, however, ``would create a `hole' in the enlisted experience profile _ that is, the distribution of personnel over years of service,'' the study said. The CBO also said that ``some loss of readiness is probably inevitable whenever significant personnel reductions are made. Slowing the pace of the drawdown might merely spread out its effects.'' At the request of Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis. and the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, the CBO examined the options in reducing the two services by 120,000. The Navy and the Marine Corps were not included in the study. The Bush administration, in its budget for fiscal 1991, has proposed cutting active-duty strength by 38,000. About 80,000 troops would be withdrawn from Europe under the administration's proposal in negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing conventional forces. Hardest hit by the administration's cutbacks would be the Army and Air Force, the two services with the largest contingents overseas. As of March 31, the Army had 764,259 active-duty personnel. The Air Force has some 550,000. The analysis, which makes no recommendations, said the across-the-board approach would include reduced promotions; restricting first, second and third re-enlistments; selective early retirements, and so-called ``involuntary separations'' of personnel with more than six years of service. ``The approach to personnel reductions would avoid the hole in the enlisted experience profile,'' the CBO said. However, the across-the-board approach would raise the thorny issue of involuntary separations, or layoffs, for some personnel with more than 10 years in the military. ``These people would have their lives disrupted, face at least temporary unemployment and lose the chance to receive the retirement benefits that may have been an important factor in their earlier decisions to re-enlist,'' the CBO said. The analysis notes the three bills pending in Congress that would provide severance pay for enlisted personnel who are involuntarily separated. ``The proposed severance payments would offer fairer treatment than is available under current law, which provides severance payments only for officer personnel,'' the CBO said.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Thunderstorms in Ohio Valley; Sunny Skies West of Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Strong thunderstorms darkened skies in many eastern states Monday, bringing heavy rains and 60 mph winds to the Ohio Valley. Winds gusted to 64 mph at Mansfield, Ohio, and storms spawned a tornado at Celina and produced high winds which downed trees and power lines in Mercer County, western Coshocton County and Union County. A posted flood watch included Belmont County in eastern Ohio, which last month was hit by flash floods that killed 26 people. Thunderstorms developed along a cold front and extended from central Pennsylvania into northern Indiana Monday afternoon. Showers and thunderstorms also hit southern Florida and swept through northern Mississippi, northern Alabama and eastern Tennessee. Storms extended from southeastern Idaho to south-central Montana, and from eastern South Dakota to northern Illinois, and central Kansas. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies west of the Rockies. Strong southwesterly winds blew from the southern Plains to the lower Missouri Valley, and along the middle Atlantic Coast. Temperatures were generally in the 90s by early Monday afternoon from eastern Kansas and the southern Plains to the southern and middle Atlantic Coast, with 100 degree readings reported in Arkansas and western Tennessee. Temperatures were in the 70s in the central Plains, the upper Mississippi Valley, the upper Great Lakes region, upstate New York and northern New England. Temperatures were in the 60s and 70s along the northern and central Pacific Coast, but soared into the 90s and above 100 degrees in the southwestern deserts. The nation's low Monday morning was 43 degrees at McCall, Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: These Computer Birds Flock Together
DOC.TEXT: The age-old question of why birds of a feather flock together could be answered with a few equations and a computer, a zoology professor said Monday. Zoologist Frank H. Heppner of the University of Rhode Island and Ulf Grenander, a Brown University applied mathematician, have produced flocks of simulated birds by plugging in a few numbers, building on the work of others who have shown that in a branch of mathematics that deals with chaos there is order. ``We've got something here that looks like a bird flock or a swarm of bees,'' Heppner said. ``So we know we can produce that kind of behavior, but we're not sure why it works the way it does.'' The implications are tremendous, say those familiar with the field: New ways to control swarms of planes around busy airports, crowd control, even simpler computer animation. The beauty is that the complex behavior comes from some simple rules interacting with each other, said Christopher Langton, a mathematician with Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. Any minor change is magnified through the chain, much like one bird swerving suddenly can divert the whole flock. ``That's what chaos is all about,'' he said. Heppner, 49, who calls himself ``just a simple country scientist _ I like to work on things I can see,'' spent about 15 years pursuing theories that flocks needed a leader, before a computer game changed his thinking in 1987. The game, ``Life,'' uses a few simple rules to make squares interact on a screen. Heppner made up some rules and when he tried to generate patterns across the screen he realized ``this is a bird flock.'' He concluded that it explained the actions of a flock of thousands of starlings, for instance, much better than looking for a bird leader. He hooked up with Grenander, an amateur bird watcher, and graduate student Daniel F. Potter, and they wrote equations and a computer program. The simple rules were that birds like to be with each other, but not too close. They probably will try to keep up with each other and they will be attracted to something, such as a roost. Then, based on Heppner's real-life studies, they plugged in numbers. Sometimes the little triangles representing birds would fly off their perch on a simulated wire and come together, only to fly apart again. Other times they would come together but fly off the screen. ``Nine out of 10 times the birds didn't do anything,'' Heppner said. But sometimes the numbers would work, and the birds would swoop around the roost in complicated, but cohesive patterns. ``It's very dramatic when you see it on the screen,'' said Heppner. ``There's been a lot of serendipity with this,'' he said. ``We're really at the stage of playing with it.'' The current model looks down on the simulated birds. Next is to create a three-dimensional model that can be viewed sideways. Heppner says the team then will compare it with videotapes of real flocks. Heppner said he has had calls from people studying bee swarms and from Federal Aviation Administration researchers wondering if pilots, given more information about other planes in their area, might naturally slide into landing formation without as much intervention from controllers.
