A researcher from a military think-tank even called to see if the team's work might help explain if soldiers without a leader could function as a unit. ``What the birds would indicate is that, yeah, they probably could reach a pretty decent decision,'' Heppner said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes garble at end of grafs 3 and 4.
DOC.HEAD: Stately Mansion is Site of Summit Dinner
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The seven world leaders attending the economic summit have dinner reservations Monday night at Bayou Bend, a stately mansion that once was the home of the late Ima Hogg, the oil-rich daughter of the first native-born governor of Texas. It will be the first time that a U.S. president, much less the heads of government of Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada or Japan, have dined at Bayou Bend since it became a museum nearly a quarter-century ago. Sitting amid Miss Hogg's collection of antiques and art objects, the summit leaders will dine on tortilla soup, cornbread sticks, grilled gulf red snapper, sweet corn puree and onions, lettuce and almond salad and American cheeses. For dessert, there will be blackberry peach swirl ice cream with sliced peaches and cookies. Miss Hogg was a widely known Texas philanthropist from a family that made a fortune in oil and real estate. Her father, James Hogg, was the first native-born Texan to become the state's governor. Bayou Bend was built in 1927 along a bend in Buffalo Bayou. The 14-acre estate opened as a museum in 1966. It is situated in the River Oaks section on Lazy Lane, the most exclusive street in Houston. The home's value is unknown, but real estate broker Diane Lokey said the Dogwood Gardens estate next door listed for $11.5 million. Bayou Bend Director David B. Warren said the museum was chosen for the summit dinner partly because of its intimate, historical atmosphere. ``Surrounded by this wonderful collection of American art, objects and furniture, the president will be able to convey a grand sense of this country's heritage to our visitors,'' Warren said.

DOC.HEAD: Robert Mapplethorpe Exhibit: Not Banned in Boston
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after the film ``Caligula'' was seized by city vice detectives, the controversial photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe will arrive next month with the impassioned backing of the Institute of Contemporary Art. Far from being banned in Boston, Mapplethorpe's work will receive extra security, the director of the institute said Monday, to ensure that it is properly showcased in the city where Mapplethorpe died of AIDS a year ago. The exhibit will also receive corporate sponsorship for the first time on the tour, from Phoenix Media@Communications Group. Despite threats of protest from a Catholic lay group, ICA director David Ross said the museum wouldn't omit the seven sexually graphic photographs in the exhibit. The collection of 160 photographs, which includes still lifes, portraits and nudes, will be on exhibit from Aug. 1 to Oct 4. ``We promised him we would do what we could to make sure the exhibit was shown according to his wishes,'' said Ross. ``Robert Mapplethorpe was a friend of mine and someone I knew for 15 years. We're showing this because we believe Robert Mapplethorpe was an important artist. His work spoke to the tenor of our times, as all good artists do.'' To edit out the controversial works would be ``egregious,'' Ross said. ``He was an artist whose career deserved an entire retrospective.'' Philip Lawler of the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights said the art institute can ``count on some strong demonstration of outrage.'' Lawler and former Boston Mayor John Collins have called on Mayor Raymond Flynn to stop the exhibit. Flynn aides have said the mayor will not block the show. ``Caligula,'' a sexually graphic 1980 film about ancient Rome, was the last casualty of the legendary censorship that led to the phrase ``Banned in Boston.'' Since the last century, at least 16 books have been banned in Boston, according to the American Library Association. Casualties included works by Theodore Dreiser, Ernest Hemingway and Elizabeth Barrett Browning. Controversy has trailed the Mapplethorpe exhibit in its tour around the country. Last month an Ohio judge ruled that an art gallery and its director must stand trial for displaying two Mapplethorpe photographs that included nude or semi-nude children. A county grand jury indicted the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati and director Dennis Barrie on April 7, the day the exhibit opened. Ross called the Cincinnati indictment a ``very sad event. It's not a good day for museum directors when they're hauled off to court for doing what museum directors have been doing for years.'' The Boston show concludes an 18-month tour that included stops in Philadelphia, Chicago, Washington, D.C., Hartford, Conn., Berkeley, Calif., and Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: Engineers Find Hydrogen Leak During California Test
DOC.TEXT: NASA officials said Monday they still have not pinpointed the mysterious hydrogen leak that grounded the space shuttle fleet, even though engineers repeated the leak in laboratory tests. Rockwell International engineers detected escaping hydrogen in a weekend test of hardware from space shuttle Columbia, but NASA space flight director William Lenoir said engineers still don't know the precise valve, pipe or seal in the complex plumbing of the liquid hydrogen rocket fuel system that is leaking. The Rockwell test, in effect, proved that the leak was related to the design or assembly of the equipment. Lenoir said the next step now is to find the exact source. ``My biggest fear was that we would go through the Downey test and get no leak at all,'' said Lenoir. ``I'm encouraged.'' Finding no leak, officials said, would have made the leak even more puzzling and more difficult to repair. Space shuttle program director Robert Crippen cautioned that although the leak discovery is important ``we really do not know what the problem is yet. We haven't eliminated anything yet.'' An even more important leak test is planned for Friday or Saturday on space shuttle Atlantis, which is on a launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Lenoir said the ``prime suspect'' for the source of the leak is a U-shaped Teflon seal that is supposed to keep hydrogen from leaking from what is called a disconnect. This disconnect is in a 17-inch hydrogen pipe that pulls apart when the shuttle rocket propellant tank is jettisoned after launch. Rockwell engineers at the company's Downey, Calif., plant found the leak during weekend tests when liquid hydrogen was pumped through an apparatus of pipes, seals and valves, called an umbilical, which had been removed from the shuttle Columbia. The umbilical carries rocket propellant from the shuttle's large orange tank to the rocket engines in the orbiter, the winged spacecraft that carries the astronauts. The 17-inch disconnect separates halves of the umbilical. The umbilical also is used to load the fuel tank before launch. The hydrogen leak on Columbia was first detected in May, when technicians were pumping the supercold hydrogen on board. The mission was postponed and the umbilical on Columbia was removed and sent to Rockwell for testing. A second hydrogen leak was found on Atlantis last month. As a precaution, NASA grounded all three shuttles until the leaks are fixed. The Rockwell test was a laboratory experiment that did not exactly duplicate the conditions that occurred when Columbia's leak was detected, said Lenoir. He said it was a static test that attempted to match the pressures and the minus 420 degree temperature of liquid hydrogen, but it could not match the 84 gallon-a-minute flow used when the tank is being filled. The test late this week on Atlantis will match all conditions of the earlier leaks. Lenoir and Crippen said that Atlantis' umbilical is being outfitted with sensors and with plastic bags to capture and detect leaking hydrogen. It is hoped that the test will help to isolated the source of the leak. But Crippen noted, ``We have not eliminated the possibility that we might have two different problems on the two different vehicles.'' Liquid hydrogen is at minus 420 degrees when it is pumped into the shuttle fuel tank. Preflight tests of the umbilical had been conducted in the past using liquid nitrogen or helium, both of which are warmer than liquid hydrogen. The pipes and valves on Columbia and Atlantis had passed the nitrogen and helium tests. It was only when the supercold hydrogen was pumped on board that the leaks occurred. Rockwell engineers used liquid hydrogen, but NASA spokesman Kyle Herring said the rate of flow in the laboratory experiment is slower than what is used when the tank is being filled. The shuttles' main rocket engines burn liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. The supercold chemicals are loaded into separate vessels inside the propellant tank, the 153-foot-long tank attached to the belly of the orbiter during launch. In Houston, meanwhile, NASA said it was grounding two veteran shuttle crew commanders, Navy Cmdr. Robert L. ``Hoot'' Gibson and Navy Capt. David M. Walker, for violations of flight crew operations guidelines. NASA said Gibson was removed from shuttle flight assignments and from T-38 jet trainer flight status for one year for violating a policy that restricts high-risk recreational activities for astronauts named to flight crews. Gibson's stunt plane collided Saturday with another plane, sending the second craft hurtling into a cornfield and killing its pilot, Henry W. Jones Jr., 69, a retired fighter pilot. Walker was suspended for a May 1989 incident in which the pilot of a Pan Am plane reported a ``near midair collision'' between his aircraft and a T-38 flown by Walker.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Debate China Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the seven industrialized democracies debated on Monday whether to relax the restrictions they proposed last year on trade with China. Diplomatic sources said only Japan favored a lenient approach. It was the only unsettled foreign policy issue apart from how much aid to extend to the Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his effort to pep up his country's economy. Last July, the United States, Japan, Britain, France, Canada, Italy and West Germany condemned the repression of pro-democracy forces in China. The seven nations agreed that an examination of new loans by the World Bank be postponed. Also, the countries extended the stays of Chinese students in the seven countries. Since then, Chinese authorities have released thousands of political prisoners, but others are still being detained. The sources, speaking on condition they remain anonymous, said there is no split between the United States and Canada and the four European nations on taking a tough line in the political communique to be issued on Tuesday. Only Japan favors a softer line, the sources told The Associated Press. On two other issues unanimity was reported. President Bush and the six other leaders will condemn terrorism and deplore the proliferation of missiles and nuclear, chemical and biological weapons technology.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Uses Dollar Bill to Show How Barry Snorted Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with new testimony; edits to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Using a rolled up dollar bill, a Tehran-born restaurateur demonstrated on the witness stand Monday how he said Mayor Marion Barry repeatedly snorted cocaine, once only minutes before giving a speech. Hassan Mohammadi said he furnished cocaine to Barry about 30 times, once delivering more than 2 grams of the drug to the mayor in his office. ``He wouldn't ask for cocaine, but say, `What's happening? Are you loaded?''' the witness said. Barry never paid, Mohammadi testified. In fact, he said, on a November 1987 trip to the Bahamas, Barry played blackjack using the $3,000-$4,000 worth of chips that Mohammadi bought. The mayor leaned back in his chair at the defense table, sometimes smiling, once grinning broadly. During breaks in the proceedings he joked with his lawyers, his campaign manager and his press secretary. Mohammadi, who immigrated from Iran in 1972 at the age of 18, said he met Barry at a District of Columbia party during the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco in 1984. He invited the mayor to the grand opening of Pardi's restaurant, in the Georgetown section of Washington, in February 1985. The first time he saw Barry ingest cocaine, the witness said, was on that occasion, in an office atop the restaurant. Mohammadi said he, Barry, and nightclub owner Samad Arshadi, went upstairs where Arshadi, placed some powder on the table. Using a credit card, Arshadi ``made a line'' out of the powder ``and he and Mr. Mayor snorted'' the substance through a rolled-up bill, said Mohammadi. ``He bent over the coke and he snorted,'' Mohammadi said of the mayor. Barry then licked his fingers to make them wet and began ``cleaning his nose with his fingers,'' said Mohammadi. The mayor finished the cleaning by rubbing his fingers across the table top, the businessman testified. The men then went downstairs and Barry ``made a speech'' to the guests at the packed restaurant's grand opening, said Mohammadi. Then followed visits by the mayor to Mohammadi's apartment nearby in which Mohammadi and Barry snorted cocaine. There was another occasion in a room at the Capital Hilton and a number of times in the Cable Beach Hotel in the Bahamas. ``Did you force the defendant to accept those quantities of cocaine from you?'' asked Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts. ``Not at all,'' the witness said. ``Did anyone force the defendant to accept those quantities of cocaine?'' ``No.'' Barry is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs. Throughout his testimony, Mohammadi referred to Barry as ``Mr. Mayor.'' At Roberts' urging, Mohammadi demonstrated how Barry allegedly rolled up a bill, put his left finger to close off one nostril and inhaled through the bill with his right nostril. At that point in Mohammadi's demonstration, Barry grinned broadly. At the start of the afternoon session, with the jury out of the room, Roberts said he intended to elicit testimony from Mohammadi that he also saw Barry use marijuana and opium on several occasions. ``At one cookout,'' said Roberts, ``there was use of cocaine and opium.'' Roberts said the proposed testimony was to show ``the defendant's predisposition toward controlled substances,'' to counter defense claims that Barry was trapped into using cocaine on Jan. 18 when he was arrested. Mohammadi said that as part of his agreement with prosecutors to testify against Barry, the government promised to speak up for him in any deportation proceedings. Mohammadi has pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring with Barry to possess cocaine. Earlier, a prosecution witness testified that she smoked crack cocaine as recently as last month and had used drugs six days before she appeared before the grand jury that indicted the mayor. In cross-examination, Lydia Pearson stuck to her story that she had sold crack to the mayor 20 to 25 times in a three month period in 1988, delivering one shipment along with an application for a city job.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Protests to Kenya Over Comments About Envoy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 11 grafs new; picking up 7th graf pvs, In Nairobi
DOC.TEXT: A top State Department official lodged a protest Monday with the Kenyan ambassador over the East African nation's criticism of the United States. Herman Cohen, the assistant secretary of state for African affairs, made the complaint in a meeting with Kenyan ambassador Denis Afande amid continuing clashes in Kenya between the government and pro-democracy protesters. ``We protested the language they have been using against our ambassador,'' said a State Department official who spoke on the condition he remain anonymous. The official said Washington is concerned with statements by Kenyan officials that somehow the United States is fueling the demonstrations. ``We also made it clear that (U.S.) Ambassador (Smith) Hempstone has our full support,'' the official said. The meeting came as Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Africa subcommittee, said he would press Congress to freeze or cut U.S. aid to Kenya until that country improves its human rights record. ``I am deeply disturbed by these developments,'' Wolpe said of the events in Kenya. ``They are clearly are not isolated incidents.'' Wolpe said he has directed his aides to come up with a strategy for halting millions of dollars in development and military assistance given to Kenya. Wolpe's comments came as U.S. officials said they are helping Gibson Kumau Kuria, a human rights lawyer, find a way to leave the country. Kuria, 43, sought refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi on Saturday. Earlier, Kuria had been detained by the government of Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, who has banned political pluralism in the one-party state. Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Kuria is the only activist who had taken refuge in the U.S. Embassy. Kuria ``has expressed a desire to leave Kenya, and we are assisting with necessary arrangements,'' Boucher said The Kuria case came up in the meeting between Cohen and the Kenyan ambassador. In Nairobi, meantime, police used force to quell anti-government protests that have spread from Nairobi to other cities. In the last three days, eight people have been killed in rioting. Wolpe has long been concerned about human rights in Kenya. Last month, he joined Reps. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, and Rep. Gus Yatron, D-Pa., in asking Moi to relax his clamps on political activists. The lawmakers received no reply. A congressional aide, speaking on condition he remain anonymous, said Wolpe is seeking a consensus on how lawmakers want to handle aid to Kenya. Many members are out of town for the July 4th recess. One option is to freeze what is left in the unobligated accounts for fiscal yer 1990, the aide said. Washington has promised Kenya $35 million in development aid for the year. All but $8 million has been sent. The Kenyans have also been promised $10 million in military aid. Another option is to cut money for the fiscal year beginning in October. The House has passed a bill that includes about $33 million in economic aid and $9.1 million in military aid. That measure is pending in the Senate. Congress would not touch money for the Peace Corps or food aid.

DOC.HEAD: New Politburo Designed to Cede Power to Gov't, Ease Ethnic Tension
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has won another political victory, gaining Communist Party approval to restructure the Politburo that once ruled the country. The Politburo now promises to play second fiddle to the separate government structure he also leads. The vote by the 28th Communist Party Congress on Monday also marks a new effort to reduce the ethnic unrest that is tearing the Soviet Union apart by including party leaders from the 15 Soviet republics on the Politburo, the party's ruling inner circle. The new body will have up to 23 members, nearly twice the 12 voting members on the old body, and many if not most of the faces should be new. The expansion and restructuring will accelerate the process that Gorbachev began after he was elected to a strengthened presidency in March, transferring power to a newly created Presidential Council _ a development that has angered such hard-line Politburo members as Yegor K. Ligachev and could squeeze them out of their jobs. Unlike the Politburo, whose members are elected by the party, members of the Presidential Council are appointed and dismissed by the president, along the lines of a Western-style cabinet. The Politburo, which formerly met once every Thursday, has been meeting only once a month since March, and has been concentrating on Communist Party rather than government issues. Since most of the Politburo members will reside in their home republics, the Politburo will continue to meet relatively infrequently and will not exercise as tight control over national affairs as the body has traditionally done. The duties of the government council have not been fully defined. The 16-man body consists of six voting members of the Politburo, including the prime minister, defense minister, foreign minister, the KGB chief, and Gorbachev's right-hand man, Alexander Yakovlev. Other members are the chief law enforcement official, a reform-minded economist, a crusading environmentalist and a workers' rights activist. Significantly, whereas nine of 12 men on the old Politburo were members of the ethnic Russian majority, the new Politburo will include a majority of non-Russians. And the Presidential Council contains five non-Russians. The new Politburo will include the heads of the party organizations in the 15 republics, most of whom are clamoring for greater control over political and economic decisions affecting their regions. Shortly after becoming general secretary of the Communist Party five years ago, Gorbachev sought to centralize his authority, but he has been driven to support greater regional autonomy by the independence drives of the three Baltic republics. Moreover, the largest Soviet republic, the Russian Federation, last month proclaimed its intent to seek greater control of its affairs under the leadership of its populist Communist president, Boris N. Yeltsin. Mostly recently, Gorbachev has embraced the idea of reconstituting the Soviet Union as a looser confederation of republics. The Politburo has had its ups and downs since it was created on the eve of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution that swept the Communists to power. The first two Soviet leaders, Vladimir I. Lenin and Josef V. Stalin, exercised virtual one man rule, appointing aides and allies to the Politburo. Under Leonid Brezhnev, who ruled for 18 years until his death in 1982, the Politburo was a coalition that made all the key decisions. As Brezhnev and the other Politburo members weakened with age, the country lapsed into what Gorbachev has labeled the period of stagnation. The first Politburo consisted of seven Bolsheviks, among them Lenin, the founder of the Red Army Leon Trotsky, and the lesser-known Stalin. Following Lenin's death in 1924, Stalin eliminated Trotsky and other rivals from the ruling body. By the height of his power in 1952, he had expanded the membership to 25 voting members, all loyal aides. It also included 11 non-voting members. Nikita S. Khrushchev, who rose to power after Stalin's death in 1953, whittled the body to 15 voting and nine non-voting members. Although he instituted reforms, he tried to keep a tight personal grip on power, angering Politburo colleagues who tried unsuccessfully to oust him in 1957 and succeeded in 1964. Brezhnev, Khrushchev's successor, used the Politburo to forge a coalition among Soviet interest groups, such as the armed forces, the KGB, other government ministries and major industrial sectors, who held most of the dozen slots. He also included seven heads of republic parties as non-voting Politburo members, allowing them to run their regions in return for loyalty. Gorbachev and his allies argue that Brezhnev's system led to widescale corruption and blocked the transformation of the country into a modern industrial society.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley has been covering Soviet affairs for The Associated Press since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Incidents Prompt Warnings Along Appalachian Trail
DOC.TEXT: Appalachian Trail hikers have been urged not to stop or stray along a 14-mile stretch of the Maine-to-Georgia route because of a series of suspicious fires and booby traps. Forest Service officials blame the incidents, which include the stringing of fish hooks at eye- and hip-level across paths, on a dispute between the government and landowners who fear their land will be seized to create a 500-foot buffer along the trail. The Forest Service has put up signs encouraging hikers not to stop or leave the trail in the Buck Mountain area between Roan Mountain and the North Carolina state line, Forest Service spokesman Bill Sweet said. ``Hikers have been scared by them and since we don't know what we're dealing with, that's a good thing,'' said Brian King, public affairs director for the Appalachian Trail Conference, based at Harpers Ferry, W.Va. ``We haven't had any problems there since late April,'' King said Monday. No decision has been made on when the signs may be removed. King said that in April a shelter on the trail was destroyed by fire. Authorities determined that someone had pulled brush into the shelter and ignited it. Suspicious brush fires also were reported in the area. King said no injuries were reported. Sweet said no arrests have been made and none are expected. ``There's no way to have a very effective investigation,'' Sweet said. Congress has mandated that the Forest Service acquire about 500 feet on each side of the 2,143-mile trail. But Sweet said the Forest Service does not intend to take anyone's land in the disputed area, and is looking at an alternate route for that part of the trail in order to comply with federal law. He said he believed that message had gotten through to landowners. ``We don't think the trail hikers are in any danger,'' Sweet said. ``We just don't want to encourage people to get off the trail'' for these 14 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Police Hunt for White Extremist Group Members Linked to Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Police hunted Monday for members of the White Liberation Army, which claimed responsibility for a bombing that injured 27 blacks and threatened to carry out more such attacks to preserve white rule. Meanwhile, four more white right-wing activists were arrested in connection with an investigation of a series of recent bomb attacks against opponents of the apartheid system, according to police and news reports. Three of the men appeared briefly in the Johannesburg Magistrates Court on Monday in connection with the possession of weapons, although they have not yet been charged with any crime. So far 13 whites have been arrested in a police crackdown that began over the weekend against right-wing extremist groups suspected in the bombings. The Star newspaper reported Monday that security police hunting right-wing groups had uncovered a huge cache of weapons and explosives. The White Liberation Army took responsibility late Sunday for Friday's bombing of a black bus terminal in central Johannesburg. The bombing was one of at least six in Johannesburg the past 10 days. The group, calling itself the Wit Bevrydingsleer in Afrikaans, said in a fax to newspapers late Sunday that it planted the bomb to protest government plans to end white-minority rule. It warned there would be more bombings. The message was sprinkled with racist insults against blacks. It called Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, who heads the police, a ``traitor.'' A police official, who declined to be named, said the authorities had heard of the White Liberation Army before and were hunting for its members. It is one of several extreme right-wing groups linked to violent attacks in recent weeks, he said. The bombing targets included an anti-apartheid Afrikaans newspaper, a Jewish synagogue and several liberal politicians. Police said Sunday they had detained nine white men in connection with the recent bombings, but no charges have been filed against them yet. Vlok said all were being held under the Internal Security Act, which allows for indefinite detention without trial. ``The people arrested are all supporters of a far right political ideology, but can not thus far be connected to any particular organization,'' Vlok said. He said three prominent right-wingers were among those arrested, identifying them as Leonard Veenendaal, Darryl Stopforth and David Rootenberg. He said the other six arrested could not yet be named because of the delicate nature of the investigation. Vlok said the arrests quashed any suggestion that police were tardy in their investigation of right-wing extremists. Right-wing whites have expressed outrage at President F.W. de Klerk's plans to end apartheid and share power with the black majority. Both de Klerk and the African National Congress, the leading black opposition group, have acknowledged a terrorist campaign by heavily armed right-wing whites could undermine black-white negotiations. The Sunday Times of Johannesburg described Rootenberg as ``a close friend'' of Barend Strydom, who is on death row for killing seven blacks and an Indian in a racially motivated shooting spree in Pretoria in 1988. Eugene Terre'blanche, leader of the right-wing Afrikaner Resistance Movement, said Monday the arrests offered ``tragic proof'' that the government was yielding to the ANC and the Communists, who play an influential role in the black nationalist group's leadership. ``The government is recklessly busy intimidating right-wingers in order to impress its Communist Party allies so that they can go to the negotiation table as fast as possible,'' he said. He warned there would be ``greater actions of resistance and anger'' from whites if those arrested continue to be held without trial. The African National Congress had earlier criticized police for failing to solve any of the recent bombings, but on Monday the group said it ``appreciated'' the arrests. Walter Sisulu, the ANC internal leader, said the movement had demanded right-wing suspects be detained as ANC suspects had been in the past. Sisulu said there was an essential difference between the bombings committed by the right-wing extremists and the armed struggle launched by the ANC against the white minority government in 1961. He said the ANC's struggle was part of a human rights campaign on behalf of disenfranchised blacks, while the whites already had the vote and extensive privileges. ``They just have no reason to take up arms except to act as terrorists,'' Sisulu said. Most right-wing whites are Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended settlers of South Africa who account for 3 million of the 5 million whites. The right-wing whites want to maintain the apartheid system of racial separation that denies political and economic rights to the 30 million black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Two NASA Shuttle Crew Commanders Grounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES and RECASTS throughout to raise reason for Walker's grounding, add that he was a pilot on shuttle in 1984, NASA comment that announcements are coincidental, background on Walker incident.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-NASA Troubles
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Monday grounded two veteran shuttle crew commanders, one involved in a fatal collision of stunt planes at a weekend air show and one accused of flying too close to an airliner. Navy Cmdr. Robert L. ``Hoot'' Gibson and Navy Capt. David M. Walker were grounded for violations of Johnson Space Center flight crew operations guidelines, NASA said. Gibson was grounded for one year, Walker for 60 days. ``This is the first time we have removed crew members from flights for disciplinary reasons,'' said NASA spokesman Jeff Carr. Gibson, 43, piloted an eight-day Challenger mission in 1984 and commanded the 1986 Columbia mission and the December 1988 Atlantis mission. Walker piloted a space shuttle flight in 1984 and was commander of the space shuttle Atlantis during a four-day flight in May 1989. NASA said Gibson was removed from shuttle flight assignments and from T-38 jet trainer flight status for one year for violating a policy that restricts high-risk recreational activities for astronauts named to flight crews. Gibson's stunt plane on Saturday collided with another plane during a Texas airshow. The second craft hurtled into a cornfield and killed its pilot, Henry W. Jones Jr., 69, a retired fighter pilot from Newport News, Va. Gibson landed his plane safely at the New Braunfels Municipal Airport, 25 miles northeast of San Antonio. Donald R. Puddy, director of flight crew operations, said Gibson's participation in the event was a ``clear violation of safety.'' Walker was scheduled to command a Department of Defense mission in March 1991. He was replaced on the flight and suspended from T-38 flight status, NASA said. Walker was suspended for a May 1989 incident in which the pilot of a Pan Am Airbus 310 reported a ``near mid-air collision'' between his aircraft and a T-38 jet flown by Walker near Washington's Dulles International Airport. A near collision is generally reported when two planes come within 500 feet of each other and either pilot feels the planes were in danger of colliding. The Federal Aviation Administration said air traffic controllers filed a ``pilot deviation report'' accusing Walker of violating flight procedures. It said the planes came within 100 feet vertically but that it was not clear how near the planes were at their closest point. Walker had descended to 7,000 feet _ the assigned altitude of the Pan Am airliner _ when a controller ordered him to climb to 8,000 feet, FAA spokesman John Leyden said at the time. Carr said the timing of the two groundings was ``an incredible coincidence.'' The decision to ground Walker was made a week ago, but the announcement was delayed while authorities searched for a replacement for him on next year's Pentagon shuttle flight, Carr said. Walker had come up for disciplinary action review because of a number of ``aircraft operating infractions,'' including the Pan Am incident, Carr said. He refused to disclose any of the other infractions.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners Pay Last Respects to Late Activist
DOC.TEXT: Homeless people, activists and others who mourned the death of Mitch Snyder lined up in sweltering heat Monday to pay last respects to the man who ended his own life after years of fighting for the downtrodden. ``I always liked what he did,'' said Margaret Moore, a homeless woman who waited with others outside the shelter where Snyder's body lay. ``I didn't know anything about homeless people until I became one. I thought they all were bums. But I listened to him, and it helped me to learn that the homeless are people too.'' The mourners, waiting in temperatures that approached 100 degrees, stood in a line that snaked around the three-story shelter Snyder had fought to win from the federal government. Inside, his body lay in simple pine casket. Snyder's long-time companion, Carol Fennelly, said she hoped the commitment of many activists would not fade with the death of the nation's most visible advocate for the homeless. ``I want people not to remember him and go on with their lives but remember him and do something to make a difference,'' she said. ``We can't ever bring him back or replace him, but we can carry on.'' Members of the Community for Creative Non-Violence, the group Snyder spoke for, were also planning to keep pushing to help the destitute as they mourned Snyder's death. ``He learned to love everybody but himself,'' said CCNV volunteer Ronald Williams said. ``It's a story of human frailty, and tragedy, I guess.'' The funeral was planned as the sort of gathering that Snyder often organized to promote causes for the needy. Snyder will be cremated after a funeral Tuesday that will include a march to city hall in which Snyder's body will be carried in a horse-drawn carriage, said Fennelly. His remains will be kept at the shelter alongside those of homeless men and women who have died, many anonymously, on the streets of the nation's capital. Fennelly spoke with reporters only on condition that she not be asked to discuss her relationship with Snyder. Snyder's body was found hanging from an electrical cord last Thursday, near a note that police said contained ``suicidal references.'' Law enforcement sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the note referred to problems he was having in his relationship with Fennelly. The two had known each other for 13 years and had planned a September wedding. ``All I am willing to say right now is that he was very tired,'' Fennelly said. ``It's such a personal tragedy.'' She called Snyder's life of commitment ``a magical moment in time.'' Jesse Jackson, Mayor Marion Barry, actor Martin Sheen, and the Rev. Philip Berrigan were scheduled to speak. Sheen portrayed Snyder in a made-for-television film about Snyder's battles on behalf of the homeless. Snyder credited Berrigan and his brother Daniel, who is also a Roman Catholic priest, with helping him turn his life around.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Adjourns Without Solving Subsistence Dilemma
DOC.TEXT: The Alaska Legislature has adjourned its two-week special session after failing to agree on a way to end a federal takeover of game management on two-thirds of the state's land. The House, which agreed only that something needed to be done, ended up doing nothing by Sunday's adjournment, after the Senate had approved a constitutional amendment in the session's first week. The problem arose when the Alaska Supreme Court in December declared unconstitutional part of a state law that gave rural Alaskans preferential rights to subsistence hunting and fishing. The court said the law discriminated against urban hunters and fishermen; an estimated 110,000 Alaskans venture into the wild to hunt, fish and gather plants for food. That ruling put the state at odds with a fderal law that requires a rural preference on federal lands in Alaska. Because of the discrepancy, five federal agencies took over game management from the state on federal lands July 1. Management of fisheries remained under state control. Gov. Steve Cowper and the Democratic majority were unable to get enough votes in the House for any of several amendments they proposed to restore the subsistence preference for rural residents. Democrat Cowper, two-thirds of the Republican-led Senate, Alaska's all-Republican congressional delegation, the state's two largest newspapers and its largest native groups supported a constitutional amendment. But the 16-member Republican minority in the House remained solidly against amending the constitution, contending that would weaken the document's equal-rights guarantee. The minority said the state instead should challenge the federal law in court. A two-thirds majority _ 27 votes _ in the House was needed to refer an amendment to voters in November. The most votes any of the amendments attracted was 23. Minority Leader Robin Taylor, R-Wrangell, said the defeat of the amendments was his ``proudest moment'' in six years in the Legislature. ``What we have done is we have protected the bill of rights so that equality still exists among Alaska citizens,'' Taylor said. Some of his fellow Republicans did not share Taylor's pride. ``Federal intervention in the management of Alaska game is a serious affront to the state,'' Senate President Tim Kelly said. ``The Legislature, had it acted, could have avoided it. I think it's going to be much tougher to regain control with the more time that goes by.'' Julie Kitka, president of the Alaska Federation of Natives, said the lack of action was a setback for the state. ``A number of native people in villages will see this as a failure of the state system to respond to real needs of people, and to let people decide their own destinies and future,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Begins in Georgia Gubernatorial Runoff Challenge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with afternoon developments, judge saying unlikely he will rule before election; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge told attorneys Monday he doubted he would take action in a lawsuit challenging Georgia's majority-rule vote before next week's state primary elections. U.S. District Judge Richard C. Freeman addressed the timeliness of the suit at the end of the first day of testimony in the case. David Walbert, an attorney representing the state, had asked Freeman if Tuesday's session could start a few hours later than scheduled. Freeman responded: ``The longer we wait, the harder it will be to get this done. ... I don't think it will be done anyway, to be perfectly frank.'' Freeman noted that the lawsuit challenging the majority-vote requirement was filed in May, though a motion asking him to stop the use of the requirement in the July 17 primary was filed only last week _ ``at the last minute.'' The lawsuit filed by a group of black officials contends that the 1964 majority vote law, which requires a runoff when one candidate fails to win a majority, effectively keeps blacks out of public office. The lawsuit seeks to replace the current system with a plurality method, which would give the election to the candidate who wins the most votes. The plaintiffs say the majority-vote requirement hurts black candidates because it is difficult for them to win more than 50 percent of the vote in a state that is about three-quarters white. Freeman did not indicate if he was leaning toward either side in deciding the suit. Laughlin McDonald, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney representing the plaintiffs, said filing the suit before the election gives the plaintiffs the option, if the judge rules against them, of maintaining their objections to the election results and seeking to have them changed afterward. The first witness in the case was a political scientist from the California Institute of Technology, who testified there were numerous indications that the Georgia Legislature had racial motivations in enacting the majority-vote law. J. Morgan Kousser, a professor of history and social science and the author of a book on Southern politics, said state Rep. Denmark Groover pushed the majority-vote law through the Legislature after national civil rights legislation led to the abolition of the state's county unit election system. That system, resembling the electoral college system of choosing presidents, awarded one to three ``units'' to a candidate for each county he carried. Kousser said Groover was at the time an avowed segregationist. Groover, who lost his legislative seat in 1958 to a moderate white candidate with considerable black support, had publicly complained about black ``block voting,'' according to Kousser. Groover returned to the Legislature in 1962. In 1984, Kousser said, Groover admitted that in the early 1960s ``I was a segregationist ... I had my prejudices and I don't mind admitting it.'' McDonald said he does not plan to call Groover as a witness. Kousser said there were other signs that lawmakers in 1964 wanted to keep blacks out of public office, including an attempt to stiffen the literacy test for voter registration.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Receives Standing Ovation from African Leaders at Summit
DOC.TEXT: African leaders gave a standing ovation Monday to Nelson Mandela, who declared that South Africa's apartheid system was nearing its end in a speech to the opening session of the 26th Organization of African Unity summit. The deputy president of the African National Congress made a triumphant appearance at the OAU summit just five months after South African President F.W. de Klerk released him from prison and agreed to talks with black leaders on ending apartheid. ``Nothing can stop the emancipation process,'' the deputy president of the African National Congress told the gathering of African leaders in the Ethiopian capital. ``The days of apartheid are numbered,'' Mandela, 71, said to thunderous applause. Mandela, who was accompanied by his wife Winnie, was making his first appearance at a summit of the 51-member OAU, which joins together the black and Arab states of the African continent. The three-day summit is expected to focus on the impact on Africa of the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe, popular demands for multiparty democracy, the growing plight of refugees on the continent, and how to deal with foreign debts now totaling more than $250 billion for member states. The African leaders are likely to issue declarations on these issues at the closing session on Wednesday. Mandela, who spoke for 10 minutes at the opening session, appeared weary after his recently concluded month-long tour of European, North American and African countries aimed at winning support for the ANC and backing for continued sanctions against the white minority government. He nodded off briefly several times during the opening addresses by other African leaders. In his speech, Mandela paid tribute to the OAU for its assistance to the African National Congress during the 27 years he spent in prison for his anti-apartheid activities. He said the OAU's backing had given the ANC ``inspiration and strength'' in its efforts to gain full political rights for South Africa's black majority. ``Only South Africa now remains victim of white minority rule in Africa,'' he declared, praising the help provided by the OAU in bringing the black majority to power in Zimbabwe and Namibia. Ethiopian President Mengistu Haile Mariam, the summit host, welcomed the recent political reforms in South Africa that led to the release of Mandela and other anti-apartheid activists from prison. But he said these measures ``have in no way affected the basic structure of the inhuman system of apartheid.'' In his opening speech, Mengistu hailed Mandela as ``a shining symbol of the struggle for liberation and a man of unbreakable will ... a true son of Africa.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Kohl: `Hail the Champions of Football'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with new items on Houston heat, photo op small talk.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush figured there was more on Chancellor Helmut Kohl's mind than trade and economics when he arrived for the start of the summit. ``Hail the champions of football,'' the president said as he greeted the West German leader, who missed a rodeo and other pre-summit festivities so he could watch the German team beat Argentina, 1-0, in the World Cup soccer final. ``World champions! It's a big win for Germany.'' Bush said. ``There must be great excitement at home.'' Later, Bush told Kohl he was a soccer player in college. Bush played for Yale University in 1945. ``I loved the game, and the American people are lod more,'' said Bush. The United States hosts the next World Cup in 1994. `ving it more an`I think President Bush is going to inaugurate that great event in four years,'' said Kohl. ``Either as an unemployed person or as president,'' Bush said.

One buffet line in the giant food hall at the media center is a concession to the summit's only non-Western nation. Offerings include tofu soup, squid and other delicacies familiar to the Japanese press delegation, largest among the more than 3,000 reporters and other newspeople registered. Other n the 16-member Common Council, was censured by his colleagues June 29 for the threats and for the sausage scare, in which he told newspapers an underground black militant group had injected rat poison into products from Usinger's Famous Sausage Inc. The warning forced the family-owned business in downtown Milwaukee to recall and destroy nearly 38,000 pounds of meat, at a cost of more than $135,000. An investigation found none of the meat was tainted. Before the sausage incident, McGee had picketed Usinger's when the owner opposed renaming a street in front of its retail outlet after slain civil rights leader the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. McGee complained in his letter Monday that police protection has been limited ``by all the fun Milwaukee is having this year.'' The reference was to the city's annual Summerfest, an 11-day lakefront festival that ended over the weekend after drawing nearly 900,000 visitors. The festival requires a large police presence at the lakefront. ``White people's fun is more important than black lives,'' McGee said. A crime wave has been sweeping Milwaukee's black community. Seventy-three murders have been committed in the city this year, compared to 58 by this time last year, when a new murder record was set.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Got $29,000 From Columbia Officials, PAC, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: St Germain without a period in 13th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle, D-Mich., was the top congressional recipient of campaign donations linked to the troubled Columbia Savings and Loan, an independent watchdog group said Monday. Common Cause reported that Riegle received $29,000 from individuals associated with the thrift's political action committee between January 1981 and last April. He was a member of the banking panel during that time and became chairman last year. Columbia executives, their spouses and the PAC contributed a total of $284,900 to congressional incumbents and challengers during the nearly decade-long period examined by Common Cause, the report said. The federal Office of Thrift Supervision last week filed civil charges of violating banking regulations against Thomas Spiegel, the thrift's former chief executive. Aside from Riegle, 51 congressional candidates _ including 38 incumbents _ received donations from people associated with Columbia Savings and Loan and its PAC. Spiegel's nearly-insolvent institution was the thrift industry's biggest purchaser of risky, high-yield junk bonds. The government is seeking $24 million from Spiegel, who is accused of squandering depositors' money on personal expenses such as wine-tasting classes, rock concerts and $100,000 worth of firearms. Riegle is among five senators under investigation by the ethics committee for intervening with federal regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, another S&L executive. The government seized his insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif., last year. That bailout alone is expected to cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. Keating and associates contributed $78,250 to Riegle's 1988 re-election campaign. Riegle later returned the money. Riegle spokeswoman Martha Quinn said the senator had received $6.2 million from more than 10,000 contributors during the last decade. ``As the new chairman of the Banking Committee in 1989, Sen. Riegle led the effort in Congress to crack down on the savings and loan industry and enact the toughest financial regulation bill in 50 years,'' Ms. Quinn said. ``It did stop once and for all the abuses carried out by the savings and loans.'' Columbia S&L was the institution hit hardest by the bill Riegle sponsored, Ms. Quinn said. Spiegel was the thrift's top campaign contributor, personally giving $50,150 to congressional candidates from 1981 to April of this year, the Common Cause report said. Riegle received $2,000 from Spiegel. The leading recipient of money from Spiegel was former Banking Committee chairman Fernand St Germain, D-R.I., who received $3,500. He was defeated for re-election in 1988. Other leading recipients included Sens. Jake Garn, R-Utah, $25,200; Tim Wirth, D-Colo., $17,500; Bob Packwood, R-Ore., $17,000; Pete Wilson, R-Calif., $15,500; Alan Cranston, D-Calif., $13,500; Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, $11,000; Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., $7,000. Top House recipients included Reps. Howard Berman, D-Calif., $5,000; Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., $4,000; Carroll Hubbard, D-Ky., $4,000; Barney Frank, D-Mass., $3,000; Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga., $2,000.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Takes Hostages at Bank For Four Hours
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to change from bomb to hand grenade in lead, CORRECTS age from 38 to 37 in 2nd graf, charges filed, woman had history of psychiatric problems, other details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A woman who police said craved attention held seven people hostage in a bank Monday, claiming she was armed with a hand grenade and gun during a four-hour standoff. The hostages escaped at about 4 p.m. after a police SWAT team distracted the woman, identified as 37-year-old Vicki Molina. She was arrested and no explosives or weapons were found, police said. ``When the negotiators and these tactical people started to move in she became distracted,'' said Metro-Dade police spokesman William Kinnebrew. ``Most of the hostages ran toward the tactical people. They got them out to safety and then were able to go in and subdue this woman and take her into custody.'' No shots were fired and no one was injured. Ms. Molina was charged with nine counts of false imprisonment and jailed under a suicide watch, said Police Lt. Nancy McCue. The ordeal began after the visibly nervous woman entered the NCNB Corp. branch shortly before noon. After a few minutes, she handed an employee a note, then ordered an undetermined number of people to leave the bank, said Metro-Dade Officer Ralph Hernandez. ``She said she wanted attention,'' said McCue. The woman allowed several calls to be made by hostages, including one to North Miami police informing them she did not intend to rob the bank, she said. Ms. Molina's husband told police she has been in and out of psychiatric treatment for 15 years. She was chain-smoking and kept her hand in her purse during much of the standoff. At one point, she tried to cut her hair with a pair of scissors, McCue said. ``Apparently she was trying to prove a point to someone,'' McCue said. ``We don't know who at this time.'' The woman said that before entering the bank she had ``taken care of everything,'' including giving away her dog, said McCue. Police contacted the woman by telephone about 3 p.m. and began negotiations, said Deputy Chief Larry Juriga. The FBI and a SWAT team from the Metro-Dade Police Department were called to the scene, in the small town's main business district, and police blocked off a half-mile area around the bank. Relatives of the bank hostages were taken into another bank across the street to wait out the standoff.

DOC.HEAD: Int'l Press Group Calls for Release of Jailed Kenyan Journalist
DOC.TEXT: The International Federation of Newspaper Publishers called Monday for the immediate release of a Kenyan journalist who was detained last week in a crackdown on government opponents. Police took Gibotu Imanyara, editor of the Nairobi Law Monthly, from his home Thursday evening, and neither his family nor colleagues know where he is being held, the newspaper publishers organization said. ``It is clear that Mr. Imanyara has been arrested as a result of his journalistic activities and the principled stance he and his publication have taken in favor of the protection of constitutional guarantees and, among them, the guarantee of press freedom,'' the federation said in a message to Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi. The federation called for the immediate release of Imanyara as well as ``all those detained for the peaceful exercise of their right to freedom of expression.'' The Nairobi Law Monthly, founded in 1987, has carried outspoken criticism of the government and its human rights record. Imanyara, 36, has been jailed twice before and spent two years in solitary confinement before establishing the publication, the federation said. At least eight people have been reported killed in rioting the past three days after police broke up a pro-democracy rally in Nairobi. The violence follows last week's detentions of Imanyara and other prominent advocates of a multiparty system.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Smoking Increases Risk of Death for Diabetics
DOC.TEXT: Researchers are warning insulin-taking diabetics to quit smoking, citing discoveries that tobacco use greatly increases their risk of death. The researchers studied more than 500 patients in what is believed to be the first look at the ill effects of smoking in insulin-dependent diabetics. The study's results were published in the July issue of the journal Circulation, published by the Dallas-based American Heart Association. Claudia Moy and colleagues at the University of Pittsburgh and Children's Hospital said the risk of premature death for insulin-dependent women is more than twice that of diabetic females who don't smoke. The researchers said diabetes increases the risk of death 10-fold, meaning insulin-using women who are heavy smokers are 20 times more likely to die prematurely than the general population. The risk of premature death among diabetic men who smoke heavily is about 10 times greater than the general population, according to the study. Non-smoking diabetics run a risk about six times higher than normal men.

DOC.HEAD: Party Chiefs Vote to Include Republic Bosses on Politburo
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party congress voted Monday to require the Politburo to include the general secretary, his deputy and the first secretaries of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. The 15 republic party chiefs include Givi Gumbaridze of Georgia, whose republic is pushing for independence from the Soviet Union, and Pyotr Luchinsky of Moldavia and Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, whose republics have declared themselves sovereign with the right to overturn national laws. Nursultan Nazarbaev of Kazakhstan has spoken in favor of some limited sovereignty. Ayaz N. Mutalibov of Azerbaijan leads a republic that has been under martial law for six months, since ethnic rioting that turned into what Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov said was a revolt against Soviet power. Ivan Polozkov of Russia and Efrem Sokolov of Byelorussia are conservatives who would counterbalance reformers. The Communist Parties of Lithuania and Latvia have split, and their most progressive members chose to form separate independent parties. The conservative branches loyal to Moscow have representatives at this congress, indicating it is their first secretaries who are likely to sit on the Politburo. They are Alfreds Rubiks of Latvia and Nicolas Burakevicius of Lithuania. The Estonian Communist Party plans to split next fall. The independent faction is led by chairman Vaino Vyalyas and first secretary Enn Arno Sillari, while the loyalist faction is led by Alexander Gusev, according to the Estonian News Agency. Both Estonian factions are represented at the congress. The other republic party chiefs are Vladimir Movsisyan of Armenia, Stanislav Gurenko of Ukraine, Sappar Niyazov of Turkmenia, Kakhar Makhkamov of Tadjikistan and Absomat Masaliyev of Kirgizia.

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Israeli Satellite Burns Up on Re-entry
DOC.TEXT: Israel's second experimental satellite disintegrated on re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere on Monday, 97 days after it was launched, officials said. The 352-pound Ofek-2 satellite was launched April 3 amid speculation it was part of a program to spy on Israel's Arab enemies. Israeli leaders denied this was the purpose but also bragged the launch showed Israel's scientific and military superiority over Arab states. Ofek-2 was launched a day after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to react to any Israeli assault on his country with a chemical attack that would destroy half the Jewish state. The satellite's orbit ranged from 130 miles at its lowest point to 923 miles at its highest, according to a statement from Israel Aircraft Industries, which developed the satellite. It did not say where the re-entry occurred. Ofek-2, Hebrew for Horizon-2, stayed in orbit about 40 days longer than expected ``due to the large reduction in the actual solar activity compared to the forecast,'' the statement said. It termed the flight ``an unqualified success.'' Ofek-1 was launched on Sept. 19, 1988, and stayed in space 115 days. Israeli officals had said Ofek-2 would not stay in space as long as its predecessor. Ofek-2 was more advanced because it was capable of two-way communication with its earth base, scientists said. According to official reports, Israel is expected to launch a third test satellite in 1992 and eventually put in orbit a communications satellite with 10-year lifespan. Israeli scientists have developed a prototype of a communications satellite called the Amos.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Group in Arkansas Offers Aid to Louisiana Women
With Louisiana Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Arkansas abortion rights group offered Monday to arrange car pools for Louisiana women seeking abortions should the restrictive bill passed by that state's Legislature become law. ``Should the legislation in Louisiana be signed into law, we will be available to assist them _ whether it's caravans or whatever,'' said Kimberly Collins, chairwoman of the Committee for Reproductive Choice. ``We will certainly find a way to help those women.'' She said the group also would buy advertising space in newspapers promoting the availability of abortions in Arkansas. Louisiana lawmakers Sunday passed a measure that would ban most abortions and punish doctors who perform them with up to 10 years at hard labor. The law includes provisions demanded by Gov. Buddy Roemer to exempt most victims of rape and incest, but he said won't act on it until he had read the bill carefully. Abortions are legal in Arkansas, although a constitutional amendment narrowly approved in 1988 makes it illegal to spend public funds on abortions, except to save the mother's life. That amendment also makes the protection of unborn children state policy. A 1989 law requires women under the age of 18 to notify both parents should they seek an abortion. Minors can avoid notification of their parents if they convince a probate judge they have good reason to get the abortion without notifying their parents.

DOC.HEAD: Author Says Ties Tied Too Tightly Can Impair Vision
DOC.TEXT: Dapper dressing may help you get ahead, but a necktie tied too tightly can make your head swim and blur vision, says the author of a book on improving health habits. Viselike ties can constrict blood flow to the brain and sensory organs, says Dr. Don R. Powell of the American Institute for Preventive Medicine. He cited 1989 research at Cornell University for the necktie tip, one of 365 suggestions in his book, ``A Year of Health Hints.'' ``It can be a problem for people who have to use their eyes in an important way,'' Powell said Monday, noting that computer operators, pilots and surgeons depend on clear vision. Powell suggested buying shirts a half-size bigger in the neck, leaving the top button undone, tying knots loosely and loosening the tie throughout the day. He also said ``casual days'' at work, when a tie isn't necessary, would help alleviate the problem and boost morale. He said the institute has ``casual Mondays'' and ``casual weeks,'' and is discussing ``casual summers.'' ``Not having to put on a necktie and a suit seemed to improve morale,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Namesakes Share Other Traits
DOC.TEXT: With all the mysterious phone calls and misguided mail over 50 years, the Frank William Boumas of this town knew someone shared their name. But when the two Frank William Boumas finally met about ten years ago, they found the name was but one of many coincidences. They first met at the Kent County International Airport because of a ticket mixup: they were booked to Florida on the same airline the same day. In conversation, they learned each had married on July 9. On Monday, Frank and Trudy Bouma celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary; Frank and Nella Bouma celebrated their 55th. ``We tried to get our anniversary picture in the newspaper five years ago, but they must have looked at the name and thought it was a duplicate picture. The only one that got printed was Frank and Nella's,'' said Trudy Bouma. After Frank and Trudy returned from their honeymoon, they read in the newspaper that the other Frank William Bouma had fathered a child. ``We hoped people didn't get the wrong impression from that,'' Trudy said. ``We weren't married nearly long enough to have a baby.'' The next year Frank and Trudy had a daughter, whom they named Marcia. They did not learn until much later that Frank and Nella also have a daughter named Marcia. The uncanny name game not only goes forward a generation, but back one. The two Frank's fathers are both named Fred.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Leaders With Lots of Air Conditioning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts news grafs 12-14 after 11th pvs, `British Prime xxx to update with details from class photo, dinner menu; picks up 12th pvs, `Bush began.
DOC.TEXT: With a 21-gun salute, a flourish of trumpets and a steady flow of high-powered air-conditioning, President Bush formally opened Monday what he dubbed the first ``post-postwar'' economic summit. After a weekend of rodeo and down-home Texas hospitality, Bush welcomed the other foreign leaders on the picturebook campus of Rice University where the Academic Quadrangle proved a good staging ground for a full-dress military welcome. But a lot of people were thinking at least as much about the weather _ temperatures in the mid-90s and humidity topping 80 percent. With the heat in mind, the welcoming ceremony was held to 10 minutes, from the time the leaders stepped into the quadrangle until they retreated inside Lovett Hall. And in an effort to make even those few minutes more bearable, the outdoor reviewing stand they stood on had a three-ton air conditioner spewing cold air up from vents at their feet. A white canopy overhead also shielded the leaders from the broiling sun. Offstage, the sweat poured off the faces of less fortunate summit aides and the military color guard. Bush, the transplanted New Englander who now calls Houston his hometown, said, ``We think this city is a very appropriate place to host this economic summit.'' As Cold War tensions continue to recede, he called the gathering the first ``not of the postwar era, but of the post-postwar era.'' ``A new world of freedom lays before us,'' Bush told the leaders of Great Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and Canada before they went inside to begin their deliberations in private. Bush urged his fellow presidents and prime ministers ``to work toward decisions here in Houston that will bring new stability and prosperity to the world.'' The president and his wife Barbara personally greeted each leader upon arrival on the campus. After meeting each motorcade, they waited inside before venturing out again in the heat. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who had to walk gingerly amid the dirt and hay at Sunday night's rodeo, was overheard telling her host, ``Last night was fabulous!'' The leaders finished their first round of talks early and, emerging back out in the heat, walked down a long red carpet to pose for their traditional class photo. ``We had very good discussions,'' said Bush, who playfully waved behind his back to photographers as the leaders turned to walk away. Later, they were reassembling to talk politics over a working dinner at the Bayou Bend, a mansion-turned-museum where the summit fare included tortilla soup, grilled red snapper and blackberry peach swirl ice cream. Bush began his day in separate talks with French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who are leading the push against Bush's resistance for direct Western aid to bolster the staggering Soviet economy. Bush met first with Mitterrand to give Kohl a little more time to rest from his long overnight flight to Houston from the World Cup finals in Rome, where Kohl witnessed West Germany's triumph over Argentina on Sunday. Mitterrand also flew in early Monday morning, but his was a less time-consuming trip aboard the supersonic Concorde. Bush and Mitterrand both resisted reporters' efforts to draw them out on the potential squabble over Soviet aid. ``I'm defending his right not to take questions at photo opportunities,'' said Bush. As soon as Mitterrand left the Houstonian hotel after his meeting with Bush, the French tricolor flag was replaced on the wall of the Houstonian's Manor House with the black-red-and-gold banner of West Germany in readiness for Kohl's arrival. Bush greeted the chancellor with a jaunty thumbs-up, saying, ``Willkommen! Hail the champions of football. ... World champions! It's a big win for Germany.'' Inside, Bush boasted that he had played soccer himself on a championship team at Yale in the 1940s, and Kohl said Bush would get to inaugurate the next World Cup games, which will be played in the United States in 1994. ``Either as an unemployed person or as president,'' Bush quipped.

DOC.HEAD: First Albanians Arrive in Czechoslovakia; 5,000 Cram Embassies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with landing details, quotes, color. Picks up 7th graf, `ATA said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR3
DOC.TEXT: The first of more than 5,000 Albanians who rushed foreign embassies in Tirana in a desperate bid to emigrate arrived in Prague early Tuesday aboard the personal plane of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel. In the Albanian capital, a U.N. envoy was trying to negotiate safe passage abroad for the thousands stranded in their flight from Europe's last bastion of hard-line Communism. Havel sent his Soviet-built TU-154 to Tirana and it arrived back at about 1:15 a.m. carrying 51 Albanians who sought asylum in the Czechoslovak Embassy. The beaming occupants, all adults, yelled ``Long live Havel!'' before being whisked away on buses to dormitories in an outlying district of Prague. Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier told reporters at the capital's airport that Czechoslovakia got the refugees out first due to ``a little luck and a lot of patience.'' He said most of the group wanted to emigrate to the United States, but that in any event, ``we're not going to send them back.'' In a brief dispatch, Albania's state ATA news agency had announced that the group left shortly before midnight Monday. ATA said ``a group of Albanian citizens, sheltering in the Czechoslovak Embassy, left for Prague with regular documents.'' Although Albanian authorities agreed Saturday to permit all the Albanian asylum-seekers to leave under foreign supervision, the process of providing them with travel documents and transportation was expected to take days. Albanian authorities continued on Monday to refuse aid shipments for the would-be-emigres packed in Western embassies. The Austria Press Agency reported from Tirana that 2.5 tons of supplies destined for the West German and French embassies were flown out on the same Swissair plane they came on because authorities did not permit unloading. About 3,000 Albanians seeking asylum were jammed behind the gates of the West German Embassy. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher promised that ``those Albanians wishing to come to Germany will be welcomed,'' the ministry said in Bonn. About 1,000 Albanians were in the Italian Embassy. The refugees overwhelmed the missions, which have been unable to provide sufficient food and water. Sanitary conditions were bad. Genscher termed the situation ``intolerable.'' One refugee gave birth to a girl in the West German compound over the weekend, the Germans said. The shaken Albanian leadership announced more government changes on Monday, an apparent attempt to reduce public dissatisfaction over shortages of food and other consumer items in that nation of 3.2 million people. The Albanian parliament fired Jovan Bardhi, the minister in charge of food production, and Vita Kapo, minister of light industry, and reassigned ministers of public services and home trade, ATA reported. The changes followed the replacement of the minister of police and the minister of war on Sunday. ATA also announced wage reforms that will result in more wage differentiation and said unemployment benefits would be paid to workers idled through no fault of their own. Many of the more than 5,000 Albanians crowding foreign embassies have said they seek a better economic life abroad. A spokesman at the Foreign ministry in Budapest, Gyoergy Lukacs, said six of the 40 Albanians at the Hungarian Embassy expressed a desire to settle in Hungary. Most wanted to go to the United States, he said. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said he had no information about requests to travel to the United States and no comment on what U.S. policy would be toward such requests. There is no U.S. Embassy in Tirana. In Paris, the Foreign Ministry said the formalities of obtaining passports for the 550 refugees at its embassy in Tirana were moving along rapidly, and ``we hope they will be finished by the end of the day.'' The asylum-seekers, some dodging police bullets, began taking refuge on June 28. Albanian authorities pledged Saturday that those seeking to emigrate would receive travel papers. Hanns Schumacher, spokesman for the West German Foreign Ministry, said in Bonn that a U.N. envoy was representing the West German, Italian, French and Greek embassies in talks with the Albanian government. About 30 Albanians were in the Greek Embassy. Albania's Communist leader, Ramiz Alia, has begun this year to institute some cautious economic reforms in an attempt to alleviate shortages and raise the standard of living by creating incentives for workers and farmers. For 45 years, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible. But since the death of President Enver Hoxha in 1985, Albanian leaders have sought better ties abroad and in the last year began to implement reforms. Albania this year has been seeking better relations with the outside world. New regulations that took effect Tuesday entitled all Albanians over age 16 to own a passport. Police sealed off Tirana's embassy row on Sunday to prevent more Albanians from taking refuge, but some appeared to be getting through. In Warsaw, the Polish Foreign Ministry reported 51 Albanians at its embassy, compared to 46 Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyers in Shooting Spree Try to Block Possibility of Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a man accused of killing seven people in a 1988 shooting rampage at a Sunnyvale defense company moved Monday to block prosecutors from seeking the death penalty. It was the first day of trial for Richard Farley, who faces seven counts of first-degree murder and three counts of attempted murder stemming from the February 1988 massacre at ESL Inc. Farley is accused of entering the Sunnyvale office draped with guns and ammunition and going on a shooting spree because a co-worker, engineer Laura Black, had refused a date with him. Public Defender Gregory Paraskou argued that the refusal of the U.S. government and ESL Inc. to turn over information on Farley's work history would hurt the defense and jeopardize the penalty phase of the upcoming trial if Farley is convicted. Prosecutor Alan Nudleman argued that the defense already had been given ``voluminous'' amounts of information on Farley's work. Santa Clara County Superior Judge Joseph Biafore issued a gag order that bars lawyers from discussing the trial with news reporters. Biafore also said he would take Paraskou's arguments under submission and review the documents in question before issuing a ruling. Farley allegedly told police negotiators he only wounded Black so she would survive and regret what she had done. Black had obtained a court order against Farley because she said he had been constantly bothering her. Farley surrendered at the shooting scene after long telephone negotiations with police.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Shows No Signs of Budging on Environment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 8th graf: `Several European ...' to update with Kohl statement; SUBS 18th graf pvs, `West German ...' to delete first reference to Kohl.
DOC.TEXT: Standing apart from its summit partners, the Bush administration on Monday renewed its opposition to any concrete guide for reducing pollutants blamed for warming the earth's atmosphere. Shortly before the seven-nation summit formally opened, White House hief of Staff John Sununu reiterated American worries that efforts to sharply curtail polluting emissions would hamper economic growth. The administration is concerned that it is being asked for ``in essence a perpetual stabilization'' in energy use, Sununu said at a news conference. ``Continued economic growth ... requires that you continue to use energy, and that any growth at all then would not be permitted,'' he said. A discussion of environmental issues was on the agenda for the summit meeting of President Bush and the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan. At the end of their talks Wednesday, the leaders will release a final statement expected to include endorsement of a 93-nation accord that in turn calls for getting rid of chlorofluorocarbons, which deplete the earth's protective ozone layer, by the end of the decade. The United States, though, has been isolated from its European allies in a go-slow policy on curbing carbon dioxide and other pollutants blamed for warming the global environment. Several European countries intend to reduce or stabilize carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000 or 2005. But Bush argues more research needs to be carried out before such dramatic measures are adopted. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, in an opening statement to his counterparts, said, ``A lack of scientific knowledge about the causes and effect cannot justify slowing down the taking of concrete measures.'' He said decisive steps must be taken to reduce the greenhouse effect and urged immediate action to stop the destruction of rain forests. ``The Houston summit,'' he said, ``should give a clear and concrete signal for the effective protection of mankind and environment.'' In advance of the summit, officials said the Europeans appeared willing to ease their previous insistence that specific reduction goals be set at the summit. Led by Germany, some had wanted agreement to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions or reduce them by up to 25 percent by the end of the decade. Sununu, in an interview on ABC, took a swipe at the United States' critics on the other side of the Atlantic. ``I think West Germany got a lot of good grades for rhetoric,'' he said. ``If you take a good look at what the United States has actually done in terms of cleaning up our environment ... I don't think the United States has to take a back seat to anyone,'' he said. But the Wilderness Society, a private American environmental group, shot back: ``The U.S. gets a failing grade, no matter how ... Sununu tries to rejigger the numbers.'' On Sunday, environmentalists denounced what they said was the failure of the summit nations to meet the aims of last year's Paris summit, during which they promised to protect the world's environment. Sununu told reporters the United States wanted ``a commitment ... that would allow both the industrialized countries and the developing countries to address the broad issue of greenhouse gases without picking them one by one and setting caps on them individually.'' ``What we have proposed constantly is to address them in the broad context and let each country take into account its own particular structure,'' he said. In addition to global warming, summit participants are expected to discuss ways to curtail the destruction of tropical forests and whether to create an international ``green fund'' to help developing countries protect their environments. Kohl told Bush he wanted the summit to support help for Brazil in its fight to save its rain forests from destruction, said spokesman Hans Klein. Kohl and Bush met privately Monday morning before the summit began. Environmentalists from Eastern Europe appealed to the summit leaders at a news conference Monday to help their countries clean up. ``In the past, money was pumped into the government without economic or environmental concern,'' said Zbigniew Bochniarz, a member of the Polish Ecology Club. ``Now we must create a new approach and build conditions that will modernize outdated pollution standards.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Horn Of Africa Nations Sign Peace Pact
With AM-Mandela-OAU
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the six East African nations on Monday signed an unprecedented peace pact to end conflicts in their region.
