The signing followed urgings by President Mengistu Haile Mariam of embattled Ethiopia that the African heads of state follow the lead of superpowers and try to defuse confrontations through negotiations. The pact committed Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Sudan and Uganda to seek peaceful means to end regional conflicts. ``Peoples and governments in various parts of the world which had been locked in antagonism are now making efforts to resolve their differences through peaceful negotiations, '' Mengistu said. ``With the phasing out of the Cold War the peoples of the world have begun to breathe the air of peace.'' Mengistu's government is engaged in what he has termed ``life and death'' struggles with two separate insurgencies in Eritrea and Tigre provinces. Sudan, Somalia and Uganda are trying to contain long-running insurgencies and the six nations that signed the pact have at one time or other accused each other of harboring and aiding their opponents. The accord was signed by Mengistu; presidents Hassan Gouled Aptidon of Djibouti, Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, Maj. Gen. Omar Hassan El Bashir of Sudan and Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, and by Somalia Prime Minister Ali Samantar. The six met hours before the opening of the 26th annual summit of the heads of state of the 51-member Organization of African Unity in the Ethiopian capital. The OAU summit is expected to focus on issues ranging from mounting popular calls for multiparty democracy to the mountains of foreign debt. Mengistu's government held fruitless peace talks late last year with Ethiopia's two guerrilla groups each of which has intensified its efforts to topple him. One group has been fighting 29 years, seeking independence for Ethiopia's northernmost province, Eritrea, and Mengistu has not softened his objection to the secession. He did not mention his troubles at home, but observed that unification had become a current byword with mergers of the two Yemens and East and West Germany. ``Furthermore, the countries of Western Europe through the European Community are taking historic steps towards integration and, by developing closer ties in all fields with East European countries, are moving toward making Europe for the first time in its history, a continent of peace and cooperation,'' Mengistu declared.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Salcido Bid For Murder Trial Delay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with discussion of jury selection, defense attorney's effort to fight death penalty; picks up 9th graf pvs, `A man's...
DOC.TEXT: Ramon Salcido, the winery worker charged with the bloody slayings of his wife, two daughters and four other people, lost a bid Monday for a two-month delay of his trial. Sonoma County Public Defender Marteen Miller had sought to stall the trial until September. But after a 40-minute private discussion with lawyers, Superior Court Judge Reginald Littrell said jury selection would start next Monday. Salcido, 29, is accused of murdering his wife, two of their three daughters, two of his wife's sisters, his mother-in-law and a co-worker 15 months ago in the wine country of Sonoma County, north of San Francisco. Miller had said he also planned to ask for a second change of venue, but did not make a formal request Monday. The trial was moved to San Mateo County, south of San Francisco, because of heavy news coverage. Miller and the prosecutors agreed on a list of 97 questions for potential jurors. Many deal with the jurors' frame of mind regarding the death penalty _ the expected focus of the Salcido trial. Jury selection is expected to take at least six weeks with 500 prospective jurors called for possible selection. Miller said he plans to agree to most of the evidence against his client, who submitted a full confession to police, but said he would fight the death penalty. ``I want to keep my client alive,'' Miller said outside the courtroom. Miller and Prosecutor Peter Bumerts clashed repeatedly in court. At one point, Miller stood, jabbing the air as he argued for a delay in the trial. ``A man's life is at stake,'' he pleaded. ``If Mr. Salcido had had the same consideration for the seven people he killed, maybe we wouldn't be here,'' countered Bumerts. Authorities say Salcido began his murderous rampage after a night of drugs and drinking, because he thought his wife, Angela, was unfaithful and that he was not the father of the couple's eldest daughter. Contributing to his anger, they believe, was a court order to make back child-support payments to his first wife, a woman Angela was not aware of until the order arrived at their home. Salcido has a daughter by his first wife. Salcido was arrested in his native Mexico a few days after the slayings. Sonoma County Sheriff's detectives said he confessed on the return trip to California. According to the detective, Salcido gave this account of the rampage: He took daughters Theresa, 1, Sofia, 4, and Carmina, 3, to the county dump and cut their throats; Carmina alone survived. Then Salcido drove to his in-laws' house, where he knocked out and stabbed to death his mother-in-law Marion Louise Richards and cut the throats of her daughters, 12-year-old Ruth and 8-year-old Marie. Salcido returned home, beat his wife and shot her with a .22-caliber pistol. He next drove to the Grand Cru Winery where he worked, and shot and killed co-worker Tracey Toovey, 35. Then he shot and wounded a second co-worker, Ken Butti, 33, at Butti's home. Salcido was charged with seven counts of murder and three counts of attempted murder. One of the attempted murder counts stems from his allegedly pointing a gun at Butti's wife, Terri. Miller has said he will argue that his client had an organic brain dysfunction and was suffering from ``psychotic depression'' at the time of the slayings.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSITTING a0741 to fix header
Catholic Official Says Brazil Fails to Halt Genocide of Indians
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic church official assailed President Fernando Collor de Mello on Monday, saying he failed to halt the destruction of the Yanomani Indians, one of the world's largest remaining primitive tribes. ``The Yanomani genocide and violence against indigenous peoples continues ...,'' said Antonio Brand, secretary of the Catholic Church's official Indian Council. ``The Indians are tired of declarations that don't bring change.'' Collor, who took office in March, has vowed to defend Indian rights. In April, he ordered the destruction of clandestine landing strips on Yanomani lands that are used by Amazon gold miners. The Yanomani live on Brazil's northwest frontier with Venezuela. Thousands of miners invaded their territory after large reserves of gold, diamonds and other minerals were found there in 1987. Brand dismissed the dynamiting of the landing strips as ``a publicity stunt.'' ``Only 14 of over 100 strips were destroyed and the majority have already been recovered (by the miners),'' he said. Brand said the church's Indian Council wants the government to remove all gold miners from the region and revoke decrees issued by former President Jose Sarney's government which created mining reserves on Yanomani territory. ``The negligence of Collor's government in the face of this problem makes it co-responsible for the Yanomani genocide,'' he said. He said the Yanomani's situation was rapidly worsening, and medical care and food supplies were desperately needed. Miners have disrupted the Yanomani's hunting and fishing, polluted rivers with mercury used to clean gold, and brought diseases previously unknown to the indians. Many tribes have been hard hit by malnutrition, venereal diseases and malaria introduced by the outsiders. Other tribespeople have died in clashes with miners. Brand said 15 percent of the Yanomani population, estimated at 9,000, ``has disappeared in less than three years.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Defense Secretary in Turkey for 1-Day Visit
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney arrived in Ankara on Monday for a one-day visit for talks with Turkish officials on how the NATO alliance can adapt to changing conditions in Europe. Turkish foreign ministry officials said planned cuts in U.S. military aid to this country would also be raised in the talks. Cheney arrived from Greece where a new bilateral defense treaty was signed on Sunday. The treaty has angered the Turks for including a U.S. guarantee to protect the territorial integrity of Greece against any hostile country. Turkish officials maintain that Greece sought and secured the protection primarily against Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Leader, 40 Other Suspects Flee Peruvian Prison by Tunnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs with minor editing, CORRECTS attribution to Miranda. Picks up 4th pvs, `The breakout...'
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a pro-Cuban guerrilla group and at least 39 other suspected leftist rebels escaped early Monday from a maximum-security prison by crawling through a 660-foot tunnel, officials said. Corrections department director Victor Miranda identified Victor Polay, head of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, or MRTA, as among those who escaped the Miguel Castro prison on the northeastern outskirts of this capital. Miranda said 39 male and nine female members of MRTA fled, while President Alan Garcia said 40 rebels escaped. The different figures could not immediately be reconciled. The breakout occurred about 3 a.m. in a facility that is considered the country's highest security prison and houses hundreds of suspected communist rebels. Government prosecutor Maria Astete said police found two submachine guns, a walkie-talkie and four booby-trap bombs in the block-and-a-half-long tunnel. Ms. Astete also said five hooded gunmen held up a bank at midday in a northern suburb, killing a guard and making off with 45,000,000 Peruvian intis, about $450. She said police believed the five to be among the escapees. Police captured Polay on Feb. 3, 1989, in the highland city of Huancayo, 120 miles east of Lima. His capture was considered a serious blow to the pro-Cuban MRTA, which began fighting Peru's elected government in 1984. The Shining Path group that operates primarily in the Peruvian highlands is considered the largest and most dangerous of the two anti-government organizations fighting President Garcia. Polay, 38, was facing terrorism charges and was to be sentenced within weeks after a highly publicized trial. The government prosecutor was recommending a 15-year sentence. Before taking up arms, Polay was a student leader of the center-left Aprista Party in the late 1960s. He studied with Garcia, current leader of the Aprista Party, in Spain in the early 1970s. The MRTA is believed to number about 1,000 combatants and operates mostly in Peru's northern and eastern jungles. It also carries out occasional bombings against banks, embassies, and government buildings in the capital. Its most spectacular action to date was the assassination in January of former Defense Minister Gen. Enrique Lopez. Lopez was gunned down in broad daylight by three men near his office in a fashionable Lima suburb. Speaking to reporters, Garcia blamed the prison guards, who he said shared responsibility for the breakout. Garcia said that despite the dramatic escape the guerrillas were losing their fight against the government. ``I reiterate that terrorism in Peru is in retreat,'' Garcia said. ``They have had 10 years and have not achieved anything.'' Hugo Otero, adviser to Garcia, told The Associated Press the president canceled appointments for the day because of the breakout. Officials did not say how the escape was engineered, but sources in the Interior ministry, who asked not to be named, said given the high number that escaped they may have gotten inside help. Prison workers have been on strike for months demanding higher pay. Corrections department officials said striking workers had been replaced by temporary workers. Police said they had closed off roads leading from the city and detained more than 2,000 people throughout the metropolitan area who were not carrying documents. On May 14, a column of 300 MRTA rebels seized the northern jungle town of Saposoa, freeing 35 suspected guerrillas from the town's jail and robbing three banks. The MRTA takes its name from an 18th century mestizo, or mixed blood revolutionary who led a peasant revolt against Spanish colonial rule in the Andes. It is smaller and less radical than the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla group, which has been fighting since 1980. The government says more than 18,500 people have died in the decade of political violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Mass Graves Found Near Former Nazi Death Camp
DOC.TEXT: East German officials have discovered what they said were two mass graves of people executed by Soviet secret police, the East German news agency ADN reported Monday. The discovery on the site of a former Nazi concentration camp was the latest in disclosures on alleged atrocities committed by the Soviet occupiers who directly ran what is now East Germany until 1949. ADN did not say what evidence existed to assume the victims were executed by the Soviets rather than by Nazi troops. The Nazis set up the forced labor camp on Berlin's northern outskirts in 1936. More than half its 200,000 inmates died of execution, starvation or disease before the Red Army captured the camp and interned Nazis and Nazi sympathizers there. Investigation into purported atrocities followed the ouster of East Germany's hard-line communist leadership last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Says Captors Poisoned Him With Arsenic
DOC.TEXT: Air Force doctors informed former hostage Frank Reed that his captors poisoned him with arsenic during his 44 months in captivity, the former hostage said Monday. Reed also said that hostage Brian Keenan's sister had told him in a telephone conversation from Belfast, Northern Ireland, that negotiations toward the Irish educator's release were ``50 percent finished.'' ``I think it's the most wonderful news I've heard since I've been home,'' Reed said of Keenan's possible release. ``Brian and I were mates in the holes, the hideouts. Brian on several occasions tried to intervene to try to stop the beatings that were going on.'' A Shiite source in Beirut, Lebanon, said Iran was pushing hard for the release of a hostage in appreciation for aid it received after the devastating June 21 earthquake. The Irish Red Cross flew the first Western relief plane into Tehran after the earthquake, in which 40,000 people were killed. Based on hair and nail samples, Air Force and Justice Department officials believe Reed, 57, was given arsenic over a long period of time and one large dose shortly before he was released April 30, Reed told Boston television station WHDH. The news made Reed wonder if Keenan may also have been given arsenic. ``Brian was exhibiting the same symptoms that I had of arsenic poisoning, so let us hope that it hasn't been too severe. Brian and I got in a little trouble over there together and maybe they were giving it to him for the same reasons,'' he said. Reed speculated that the captors' goal may have been to subdue the hostages or to make them appear sickly in order to speed negotiations. Exposure to high levels of arsenic can produce a burning pain in the esophagus and stomach, vomiting, diarrhea and depression. Prolonged exposure can lead to a rapid, feeble pulse and circulatory collapse. Traces of arsenic are present in water and food, especially seafood. A spokesman at the Malcolm Grow Medical Center on Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland said Reed was released from the hospital on Friday. Neither Reed, the Justice Department nor medical personnel on the base could be reached for comment late Monday. The hospital reported last month that tests on Reed had found arsenic, but gave no indication of deliberate poisoning. Hostages held in the Middle East include six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Keenan was taken hostage April 11, 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Officials Nab 947 Alleged Illegal Aliens
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Border Patrol arrested a record 947 alleged illegal immigrants in a weekend raid, and officials said Monday that arrests of aliens are up more than 40 percent over last year. ``The thing that this illustrates is the volume of illegal alien traffic that we are dealing with down here,'' said Ted Swofford, the Border Patrol's supervising patrol agent for the San Diego sector. This and other raids also indicate that illegal immigrants are coming across the border steadily throughout the year and that jobs other than seasonal farm work are luring them, he said. ``It's just gradually increasing. The seasonal fluctuations have evened out,'' Swofford said. Arrests of illegal immigrants are running 40 percent to 50 percent above last year's levels, he said. Charles Wheeler, director of the non-profit National Immigration Law Center in Los Angeles, said: ``This shows that the administration's efforts to control illegal immigration through employer sanctions have not worked to discourage aliens from coming to the United States.'' All but 10 of the 947 taken into custody at the San Clemente border checkpoint were from Mexico. The Mexicans all were returned after waiving deportation hearings, Swofford said. Deportation proceedings were being held for the others, from Guatemala, India, Egypt, El Salvador and Australia, he said. The last major sweep was three years ago when 720 suspected illegal immigrants were arrested in a 24-hour period, officials said. Four other people were taken into custody for possible alien smuggling. Swofford said some were released, but he did not have further details. The sweep was accomplished by a team of 67 agents who manned the border checkpoint and fanned out into fields on both sides of Interstate 5, said Douglas Becktel, a supervising Border Patrol agent. Northbound freeway traffic was tied up for several miles from 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. Saturday. A helicopter searchlight helped spot illegal immigrants attempting to get around the checkpoint. Most of those arrested were either walking or riding in cars and trucks trying to cross the checkpoint, Becktel said.

DOC.HEAD: Immigration Officials Offer to Release Bosch to House Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-10, bgng `The two...' with 6 grafs to add comment from family, Bosch's conditions for signing agreement, details on restrictions; picks up 11th graf, `The release
DOC.TEXT: Immigration officials Monday night offered to release anti-Castro militant Orlando Bosch from federal prison and place him under a restrictive house arrest, his attorney said. Bosch, a convicted terrorist who has been imprisoned since 1988 when he illegally entered the United States, could be released as early as Tuesday if he agrees to the government's terms, said attorney Raoul Cantero. For two years, the Justice Department has sought to deport Bosch, but 31 countries have said they will not take him. Bosch's family maintains the 63-year-old former pediatrician is suffering from ulcers and that years in prison have taken their toll. Bosch was jailed for 11 years in Venezuela for the 1976 bombing of a Cuban jetliner that killed all 73 people aboard, mostly Cuban athletes. After being acquitted in three trials, Bosch returned to Miami in 1988 to be reunited with his family, and was immediately arrested for violating his parole. The Bosch controversy has been a cause celebre for Miami's staunchly anti-Castro Cuban exile community, which has held rallies and demonstrations on his behalf attended by leading politicians. The two-page list of conditions for Bosch's release that the government set include requirements that Bosch wear an electronic monitoring device, remain at home for 21 hours a day, keep a visitors' log and allow his telephone to be monitored, said Richard Smith, director of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service in Miami. Bosch also would be subject to unannounced searches, lie detector tests and would be banned from meeting with any Cuban exile groups that advocate violence to achieve their political goals, according to Cantero. The agreement also says the INS can alter the terms of Bosch's house arrest program at any time, and if instructed, he must present himself for deportation within 72 hours, Smith's statement said. Attorney Henry Adorno said Bosch would agree to all the conditions except for the visitors log. Keeping the log ``would indicate to the people of this community that he is an informant. He is not an informant. He believes that lists are kept by people like Joe McCarthy and Fidel Castro,'' said Adorno. ``This set of conditions is so ridiculous. You get more freedom in a communist country than you do with this ... it's pure harassment,'' said Myriam Bosch, one of Bosch's daughters. The release offer signified a departure for the Justice Department, which has maintained for years that Bosch would continue his terrorist ways if released. ``It would be prejudicial to the public interest for the U.S. to provide a safe haven for Bosch. We must look on terrorism as a universal evil, even if it is directed toward those with whom we have no political sympathy,'' wrote acting-Associate Attorney General Joseph Whitley in a 1989 deportation order. Even before the airliner bombing, in which he has denied involvement, Bosch had an extensive record of involvement in terrorist acts directed at Fidel Castro's communist government. In 1968, he was convicted of firing a bazooka at a freighter at the Port of Miami. He was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison and was paroled in 1972. In 1974, Bosch fled the country in violation of parole. He traveled throughout Central and South America, using aliases.

DOC.HEAD: Feminist Attorney, Jane Roe Plan to Ask for Boycott
With AM-Louisiana Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The woman whose lawsuit led to legalized abortion in 1973 called for an economic boycott of Louisiana on Monday if a bill banning abortion on demand becomes law in that state. Norma McCorvey, the Jane Roe of the U.S. Supreme Court case Roe vs. Wade, said she and her lawyer, Gloria Allred, have sent a letter to Louisiana Gov. Buddy Roemer urging him to veto the bill. The bill approved Sunday night bans all abortions except those to end pregnancies that endanger a woman's life and those caused by rape or incest that are promptly reported. The bill is weaker than one Roemer vetoed last week, but still would be the nation's strictest state abortion law. Roemer has 20 days to veto the bill before it goes into effect. If he vetoes it, the only way the Legislature could revive it would be to call itself into special session for another override vote. ``If this bill is not vetoed, not only will women lose their rights as individuals but women will have illegal abortions that may possibly end up in death,'' said Ms. McCorvey. She and Ms. Allred called on feminist groups to urge the governor to veto the bill. Ms. Allred said she also plans to ask businesses in Louisiana to help with her fight. ``Ms. Roe and I will help to organize a `woman-cott' of Louisiana and urge all businesses to refuse to hold conventions and conferences in that state,'' she said. ``We will not allow Louisiana to continue to make a profit while at the same time attempting to kill women.'' The 1973 Roe vs. Wade case, which originated in Texas, made abortion legal. The U.S. Supreme Court said a woman's constitutional right to privacy included the right to have an abortion. The high court judged a Texas state law making abortion a crime unconstitutional.

DOC.HEAD: Worker at Vegetable Store Charged in Assault
DOC.TEXT: A manager of a Korean-American vegetable market that has been the target of a 5{-month boycott by black community activists was charged with assaulting a customer, authorities said Monday. Pong Ok Jang, manager of the Family Red Apple, was charged Saturday with third-degree assault and released on his own recognizance, said Patrick Clark, a spokesman for the district attorney. Giselaine Felissaint, a Haitian immigrant, said she was beaten in the store in the Brooklyn borough on Jan. 18. Three employees of the store grabbed her around the neck, slapped, punched and kicked her, she said. The store workers said they believed she was stealing. Black community activists have organized a boycott since the episode. Store owner Bong Jae Jang, the brother of Pong Ok Jang, was initially arrested, but charges were dismissed June 6 after Ms. Felissaint told prosecutors the wrong man was charged. Pong Ok Jang faces a $1,000 fine and a year in jail if convicted of the misdemeanor assault charge.

DOC.HEAD: Two Death Row Inmates Get Stays
DOC.TEXT: A death row inmate got an indefinite stay Monday fewer than 15 hours before his scheduled execution, and another condemned man was granted a temporary reprieve. Roy Allen Stewart and William Squires both had been scheduled to die in Florida's electric chair Tuesday. Stewart, under his third death warrant, got a temporary stay Monday from a state judge in Miami. He is now scheduled for execution at 7:01 a.m. Wednesday. Squires, under his first warrant, turned to the federal courts Monday for the first time and got a stay several hours later from a judge in Fort Myers. Stewart, 34, was condemned for the February 1979 murder of a 77-year-old woman who invited him into her home for a sandwich but became angry after seeing him take a gold watch. Squires, 48, was convicted of the September 1980 fatal shooting of a service station attendant in Hillsborough County. None of the 22 men executed in Florida since the state resumed capital punishment in 1979 went to the electric chair under the first death warrant. Defense attorneys for the men reprieved Monday have alleged that Florida's electric chair is broken and would subject their clients to cruel and unusual punishment. In May, during the execution of Jesse Tafero, smoke and flames rose from the head piece over Tafero's hea. The defense attorneys, who also raised the claim in the case of condemned ``Black Widow'' killer Judi Buenoano last month, say the problem was a broken head electrode that has not been fixed. The electrode, they say, lowered the level of electricity from a fatal 2,400 volts to a mere 90 or 100 volts. The state Department of Corrections, however, maintains that the problems in the Tafero execution were caused by a new synthetic sponge that has been replaced. Several state and federal courts have rejected the defense contentions. The issue is pending before the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, which issued Ms. Buenoano an indefinite stay.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of July 2-9:
DOC.HEAD: Gannett Sees Profit Dropping in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Gannett Co. Inc. says it expects second-quarter earnings to be lower than a year earlier, its first quarterly drop since the company went public 22 years ago. Sheila Gibbons, a spokeswoman for the nation's biggest newspaper company, said July 6 that Gannett would issue its actual earnings report for the April-June period in a few weeks. Douglas McCorkindale, vice chairman and chief financial officer, first projected an earnings decline during an interview published in July 6 editions of The Wall Street Journal. McCorkindale said he could not disagree with Wall Street analysts who forecast that Gannett's net income would be below the $112.1 million, or 70 cents a share, of the year-earlier quarter. However, he would not predict specific earnings figures. A decline in earnings would indicate how Gannett is being affected by a slump that has hit the entire newspaper industry. A number of Wall Street analysts have forecast declines for earnings of many newspaper publishers because of the soft ad revenue. ``We started to see softness in advertising business in 1989, and have been getting softer in the last eight to 12 months,'' McCorkindale said. ``We have not seen any signs of improved business conditions.'' The expected earnings decline would come at a difficult time for Gannett. The Gannett Foundation, the company's largest shareholder, announced April 26 that it planned to sell its 10 percent stake. A weak stock price could make the company a possible takeover target. The foundation, headed by former Gannett Chairman Allen Neuharth, is sorting through potential bidders.
DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Gives Up U.S. Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Ralph Ingersoll II agreed to give up control of his U.S. newspapers after failing to make an interest payment on junk bonds. The publisher said he would trade his U.S. interests and their troublesome debt to his investment partners in exchange for control of a smaller group of European newspapers. Ingersoll, whose U.S. properties included the New Haven (Conn.) Register and the short-lived St. Louis Sun, said the July 2 deal was driven by a desire to get more involved in European publishing. But bankers and investors with knowledge of the publisher said Ingersoll was facing the same reckoning as Robert Campeau and Donald Trump, who also used junk bond financing to build business empires but couldn't handle their massive interest payments. ``He has an unworkable balance sheet,'' said James Rubin, an analyst at M.D. Sass Investors Services, a New York investment firm that successfully urged bondholders to reject Ingersoll's bid to work out his debt troubles this spring. Rubin said Ingersoll took on too much debt in buying daily and weekly newspapers and was hurt further by the nationwide slump in advertising revenue. Ingersoll is relinquishing his stake in three companies that publish dozens of daily and weekly newspapers to the New York investment firm E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Co. The two had been joint owners, although Ingersoll had voting control. Warburg, Pincus gains full control of Ingersoll Newspapers Inc., which publishes nine dailies and 53 weeklies; New Haven Acquisition Co., publisher of the Register; and Community Newspapers Inc., which has newspapers in Ohio and on New York's Long Island. Ingersoll President Robert Jelenic, formerly second-in-command, was made chief executive officer of the new company. Ingersoll, meanwhile, will gain control of a group of British and Irish newspapers that he controlled jointly with Warburg, Pincus. The announcement came as Community Newspapers said it would not make a July 1 interest payment on its $125 million in 13 percent junk bonds. Ingersoll had been trying for months to buy back the bonds at a steep discount to alleviate his debt burden. In a telephone interview, Ingersoll said the three U.S. companies were on track to make $100 million in profits before taxes and interest this year on revenue of $400 million. ``We are having a record year despite the economy,'' he said. The companies could have serviced their debt if not for the collapse of the junk bond market, which hit bonds like Community Newspapers' especially hard, Ingersoll said. The announcement comes a little more than two months after Ingersoll folded the St. Louis Sun, a new tabloid that he hoped would revolutionize the slumping newspaper market by using new technology and marketing strategies. The British and Irish newspapers Ingersoll is gaining have combined circulations exceeding 1 million and annual revenue of $178 million. Europe offers great opportunities because of the planned dropping of trade barriers in Western Europe and the spread of free-market economies in the East, Ingersoll said.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Remains Jailed After Source Identified
DOC.TEXT: A reporter jailed for refusing to identify a news source remained behind bars despite a sheriff's claim that the source had been discovered. Sheriff Harlon Copeland said July 5 the source was a cousin of a murder suspect that KMOL-TV reporter Brian Karem interviewed last year. Karem started a six-month term for contempt of court on June 27. He won't be freed early without disclosing the source himself, said Prosecutor Beth Taylor. ``He still has to produce a piece of paper of his sources. We need to see that,'' she said. State District Judge Pat Priest agreed, but Karem refused to back down. ``I have a promise between myself and that source. That source has not absolved me of my promise,'' the reporter said. Jane Kirtley, executive director of The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press in Washington, said the only reason Karem was still in jail was to punish him. ``Once you've got the name of the source, you don't have to keep the journalist jailed, unless you're just offended that the journalist wouldn't buckle under to you,'' she said. Karem has refused to say who arranged an interview with Henry David Hernandez, accused of killing a San Antonio police officer last year. In the telephone interview, Hernandez said from the jail that he shot the officer in self-defense. Defense attorneys and prosecutors say they have to know who arranged the interview to determine if the interview is admissible in his trial. Copeland said he learned the name June 29 through his own investigation and tried to tell the judge, but was told Priest could not discuss the case with him.
DOC.HEAD: Sports Editors Seek Review of Club Racial Policies
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press Sports Editors called on major golf organizations to examine the membership policies of country clubs before awarding championship events. The July 2 action followed statements by Hall Thompson, founder of the Shoal Creek Golf Club near Birmingham, Ala., that the club ``would not be pressured'' into accepting blacks. Shoal Creek is the site of next month's PGA Championship. ``The country club is our home and we pick and choose who we want,'' Thompson said, adding that blacks were not admitted to the club because ``that's not done in Birmingham.'' He later apologized to ``those that took offense at those comments.'' The APSE, an organization of sports editors of AP member newspapers, sent a letter protesting Thompson's remarks to Patrick J. Reilly, president of the PGA; Deane Beman, commissioner of the PGA Tour; Grant Spaeth, president of the United States Golf Association, and William Blue, commissioner of the LPGA. The letter urged that membership and guest policies of country clubs be considered before championship sites are chosen. The letter was signed by John Rawlings of the San Jose Mercury News, the APSE president, and Dave Robinson of the Detroit Free Press, APSE liason to the Golf Writers Association of America.
DOC.HEAD: Technicians Reject AP Contract Offer
DOC.TEXT: Technical employees of The Associated Press have rejected a proposed two-year contract with the news agency, their union said July 3. The union and the AP agreed to meet again July 9. James Peecook, president of Local 1314 of the Communications Workers of America, said members overwhelmingly rejected the contract. He said the vote count would not be released. AP technicians have been working under a contract extension since early last month, when negotiators agreed to submit a two-year contract proposal to a ratification vote. The union, however, described the pact as inadequate and urged members to reject it. Local 1314 represents about 300 AP technicians. The contract calls for a ``managed care'' approach to control the cost of the medical plan. It also proposes weekly pay increases of $23.50 for top-scale technicians in the first year and $24 in the second, bringing weekly top-scale technician salaries to $612 in 1991.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Switching to Mornings
DOC.TEXT: The Beaufort Gazette will switch to morning publication on Sept. 3, Publisher John L. Heath announced. The Gazette, founded in 1897, has been published Monday through Friday afternoons since going daily in 1973. ``Switching to a morning publication will allow us to give the reader a better news and advertising product. The most comprehensive stock listings and the lastest sports news in the area will be found in the morning Gazette,'' Heath said July 2. He said delivery is expected to be completed by 6:30 a.m. daily after the conversion. The Gazette, along with The Island Packet on Hilton Head Island and The Herald in Rock Hill, are owned by McClatchy Newspapers. They were purchased from the News & Observer Publishing Co. of Raleigh, N.C., on Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Photographers, Reporter Injured in Melee at Club
DOC.TEXT: A dispute with promoters prompted the rap group 2 Live Crew to cancel a concert July 7, triggering a melee by fans that injured two newspaper photographers and a reporter. The rappers, whose album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' has been ruled obscene by a Florida judge and banned in San Antonio, refused to play after a promoter refused to pay them in advance. Shortly afterward, about 50 people went on a rampage, breaking chairs and throwing bottles. Police in riot gear dispersed the crowd within 15 minutes. Dallas Times Herald photographers Jesse Hornbuckle and Cedric Thompson, assigned to cover the concert, were treated for minor injuries. Reporter Mindy Donnelly was hit in the head and lost a tooth cap but didn't require treatment. Hornbuckle said up to 10 fans attacked him as he attempted to photograph a smaller group attacking Thompson. Cameras and other equipment belonging to both photographers were destroyed by the fans. Hornbuckle salvaged one roll of film, and his picture of a fan being restrained by guards appeared in one edition of the Times Herald on July 8. A car belonging to another Herald reporter was vandalized. The fans also smashed the windshield of a KXAS-TV remote broadcast van.
DOC.HEAD: Condoms Attached to Newspapers in Protest
DOC.TEXT: AIDS activists attached condoms to 2,000 coin-box copies of The Arizona Republic to protest an editorial cartoon that one protester claimed amounted to ``AIDS hate-mongering.'' The June 26 cartoon by the newspaper's editorial cartoonist Scott Stantis showed two men walking into a bathhouse and one saying, ``It puts me in a tizzie to think the government hasn't done a thing to stop the spread of AIDS.'' The Phoenix chapter of the national AIDS Coalition To Unleash Power, or ACT UP, said it attached the condoms in packages emblazoned with the group's name to July 2 editions of the newspaper on sale in Phoenix and three suburbs. ``That cartoon presents such misinformation, it's a heinous crime to the Valley,'' said the chapter's vice chairman, Jeff Ofstedahl. ``It was AIDS hate-mongering. ... It's been the gay community that's been chiefly responsible for closing down the bathhouses.'' Stantis said the cartoon was inspired by the ``abominable'' disruption of last month's Sixth International Conference on AIDS in San Francisco by AIDS activists who drowned out a speech by Health Secretary Louis Sullivan. The activists have criticized U.S. immigration restrictions on people with AIDS and say more money needs to be put toward the fight against AIDS.
DOC.HEAD: State Shows Interest in Daily News Contract
DOC.TEXT: New York state is preparing to enter the negotiations between the Daily News and its 10 unions, the head of the state mediation board said July 3. The chairman of the panel, Hezekiah Brown, said that because of union support for state intervention he would begin the process leading to a formal state inquiry into contract negotiations at the tabloid. Brown would look at the negotiations between the paper and the unions. If he determined it could be helpful to a settlement he would recommend the state labor commissioner form a board of inquiry. A board of inquiry, usually formed during a strike, is used to air differences between disputing parties and help them resolve their problems. It has subpoena power but no enforcement power. The Daily News is involved in contentious negotiations with the 10 unions making up the Allied Printing Trades Council over contracts that expired in March. One of the first steps toward a board of inquiry is to get at least one of the parties in a dispute to say it wants a board. The council adopted a unanimous resolution July 3 supporting a board because, it said in a statement, ``efforts to effect voluntary settlement of the disputes at the Daily News have been unsuccessful.'' The unions complain, among other things, that the hired negotiators are not familiar with operations at the News; that the News is trying to eliminate the unions; and that strikes or lockouts are feared. John T. Sloan, the paper's vice president for human resources, did not return telephone calls seeking comment. His secretary referred a reporter to a statement Sloan made earlier that the News favored face-to-face talks without outside participants.
DOC.HEAD: Arizona Supreme Court on Delivery People
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers could be liable in some instances for the acts of their delivery people, the Arizona Supreme Court said July 3. The decision came on a lawsuit filed by William Santiago, a motorcyclist injured in a 1986 collision with Frank Frausto, who was delivering Sunday editions of The Arizona Republic. Trial judge Daniel Nastro of Maricopa County Superior Court ruled that Santiago could not sue the Republic's corporate parent, Phoenix Newspapers Inc., because Frausto was an independent contractor and not a PNI employee. The Supreme Court, in its 5-0 decision, said Nastro should have let a jury decide the question because there was conflicting evidence as to Frausto's relationship to PNI. ``A jury could infer ... that Frausto was an employee because PNI involved itself with the details of delivery, received directly all customer complaints and changes so as to remove much of Frausto's independence, retained broad discretion to terminate, and relied heavily on Frausto's services for the survival of its business,'' the court said. ``The jury also could infer that Frausto was an independent contractor because he used his own car, was subject to little supervision, provided some of his own supplies, and could have someone else deliver for him within limits.'' Frausto's contract with PNI specifically said that he was an independent contractor, not an employee. But the court said contract language ``does not determine the relationship'' and that juries must look to such factors as the extent to which the workers set their own hours and working conditions, their degree of specialization, who pays for the material, how long the relationship lasts, whether pay varies with the work, how important the work is to the employer's bottom line and how the parties to the contract see their relationship.

DOC.HEAD: Damages for Man Named in Newsletter Reversed
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court has overturned $32,500 in damages awarded to a Santa Cruz man who sued a women's group for libel after its newsletter named him as a would-be rapist without proof. In a ruling June 27, the 6th District Court of Appeal said the trial judge failed to tell the jury that it had to find negligence by Santa Cruz Women Against Rape before awarding damages for libel. It also said the jury should have been told that a deliberate or reckless falsehood was required for punitive damages, which made up most of the award. A lawyer for Steven Carney, whose damages were reversed by the ruling, said July 2 that he looked forward to a new trial. ``We'll get a better verdict,'' said attorney David Sabih. ``Negligence is failure to investigate. ...They admitted they never investigated this girl's complaint.'' Sabih said the center had stopped publishing the names of alleged rapists in its newsletter based solely on the statements of the center's clients _ the practice that led to the suit. The court said a 19-year-old drug store co-worker of Carney's, identified as Karen W., came to the center in June 1984 and told staffers that Carney and another man had taken advantage of her the previous night after she had passed out drunk. Five months later, the center printed Carney's name, description and workplace in its newsletter under the heading ``assault@attempted rape.'' The center admitted it had relied solely on the woman's account and its observations of her behavior and had not tried to contact Carney or investigate in any other way, the court said. Before the trial, Karen W. sent Carney a letter, part of a settlement of suits they had filed against each other, saying she had not been raped or had sex with either man.
DOC.HEAD: Campaign Libel Bill Passed
DOC.TEXT: A bill passed by the state Assembly on July 5 would shorten the period for a political candidate to demand and get a correction of libelous campaign ads. Under current law, a person cannot sue for general damages if he demands a correction within 20 days and that correction is published or broadcast within three weeks of the demand. The bill would give the person who believes he or she is libeled or slandered seven days to demand a correction. The other side would then have seven days to publish a correction in substantially as conspicuous a manner as were the statements claimed to be libelous.
DOC.HEAD: Prisoner Claims Officials Stifled Quayle Accusation
DOC.TEXT: Federal prison officials were accused in a lawsuit July 2 of trying to silence an inmate who claimed during the 1988 presidential campaign that he had once sold marijuana to Dan Quayle. Inmate Brett C. Kimberlin accused federal prison authorities of canceling a news conference he had scheduled just four days before the election and in retaliation placing him in solitary confinement for a day. The Bureau of Prisons acknowledged in a letter to Kimberlin's attorneys that it placed him in solitary again on Nov. 7 when he tried to arrange a telephone conference call with reporters, according to court papers filed with the lawsuit in U.S. District Court. The lawsuit charged that Kimberlin was kept from meeting with reporters to repeat his allegation _ denied by Quayle _ before the Nov. 8 election, when the Indiana Republican won the vice presidency.
DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Want Congress To Allow Franchise Regulation
DOC.TEXT: Cities and towns have little control over cable companies, allowing those businesses to offer poor programming in exchange for unfairly high fees, state legislators said in a letter to Congress. The letter addressed by 24 legislators to Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., urged support for federal legislation allowing municipalities to regulate cable TV. Rep. Spencer Black, D-Madison, told a news conference July 2 that most cable subscribers have little say about programming. He said viewers' wishes are generally ignored because an absence of competition leaves the companies with little incentive to improve. Tom Hanson, a spokesman for the Wisconsin Cable Communications Association, said government regulation wouldn't help. He said rate increases had been needed to increase cable programming and for special features, such as sports events.
DOC.HEAD: Taped Delay Was Better, Network Says
DOC.TEXT: NBC says it wasn't trying to fool anyone with its special morning coverage July 5 of the dramatic match between Zina Garrison and Steffi Graf. Many viewers in the United States might not have known that the coverage was taped, not live. Garrison's upset of the two-time defending women's champion had been over more than an hour, but the only indication of that was a single announcement by host Bob Costas midway through the telecast. There were no other reminders, no graphic on the screen. ``We didn't think it was necessary because Costas made an announcement about halfway through the match,'' said network spokesman Ed Markey. ``We weren't trying to mislead viewers at all.'' Markey said NBC had been faced with showing the whole match on tape delay or picking it up in progress. The All England Lawn Tennis Club, and not NBC, schedules the matches, and Garrison-Graf was entering the third set when NBC came on the air. ``If we can go on live, that's our obvious preference,'' Markey said. ``But our main objective is to present the match to viewers as a complete story and in as close a sequence of how it unfolded as possible. ``Given the restrictions, we felt that was the best way to accomplish that.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Station Sues Government for Crash Documents
DOC.TEXT: A television station has sued four federal agencies to get documents related to the 1985 crash of a military transport plane that killed 248 U.S. soldiers. KDKA filed the suit June 29 in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C. Managing Editor Jim Esser said July 6 that the station is requesting more than 2,000 pages of documents. Esser said the station filed the suit after making 70 requests for documents with numerous government agencies. The requests under the federal Freedom of Information Act turned up nothing that the station considered significant, he said. The agencies sued included the Justice Department and the FBI. Esser would only say the station was seeking ``documents related to the crash.'' KDKA began looking into the accident because 14 families in the Pittsburgh area lost relatives in the crash. ``We've turned up enough unanswered questions that we feel it has to be pursued,'' Esser said. The crash occurred Dec. 12, 1985, in Gander, Newfoundland, Canada. It also killed eight crew members of the chartered Arrow Air troop transport.
DOC.HEAD: Jones Named Publisher of Starkville Daily News
DOC.TEXT: Melanie Pharo Jones, former city editor of the Starkville Daily News, was named publisher of the newspaper on June 27. She replaces George Williams, who will become vice president of Morris Newspaper Corp., in charge of the company's Tennessee and Mississippi newspapers, which include the Daily News. Ms. Jones was most recently a retail store manager in Columbus, Miss. She also worked in the advertising departments of the Daily News and the Columbus Commercial Dispatch.
DOC.HEAD: Blevins to Publisher in Dalton
DOC.TEXT: Keith Blevins, publisher of the Americus Times-Recorder, has been named publisher of The Daily Citizen-News of Dalton. Both properties are in the Thomson Newspapers group. Blevins, 41, was publisher of the Americus newspaper for two years. At Dalton, he succeeds Stanley Warren, who was recently named publisher of Thomson's Bluefield Daily Telegraph in West Virginia.
DOC.HEAD: Lundy Named Editor of Saint Paul Pioneer Press
DOC.TEXT: Walker Lundy, a general news executive with Gannett newspapers who has held key positions at several newspapers, was named editor of the Saint Paul Pioneer Press on July 2. Lundy succeeds Deborah Howell, who was named Washington bureau chief for Newhouse newspapers and editor of the Newhouse News Service. Lundy, 47, has been with Gannett newspapers in Washington for the past two months. Before that he spent two years as editor of the Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock. He has also worked as managing editor of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram, executive editor of the Tallahassee (Fla.) Democrat, city editor of the Detroit Free Press, and metropolitan editor of The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer.
DOC.HEAD: Ellis Named Editor of Kenai Peninsula Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Ben Ellis, a freelance writer and former editor of the Telluride, Colo., Times-Journal, has been named editor in chief of Kenai Peninsula Newspapers Inc. The company publishes the Peninsula Clarion and the Weekly Advisor. Ellis succeeds John Marrs, who said he is leaving at the end of July and hopes to teach journalism or get an advanced degree in communications.
DOC.HEAD: Distelheim Named Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Joe Distelheim, assistant to the executive editor at the Detroit Free Press, became executive editor at The Anniston Star on July 9. Distelheim started his journalism career as a reporter for the News-Journal in Wilmington, Del. He worked as metro editor and executive sports editor of The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer, and was sports editor of the Detroit Free Press before becoming assistant to the executive editor.
DOC.HEAD: Horton Named AP Senior Photo Editor for Sports
DOC.TEXT: Brian Horton, a veteran Associated Press photo executive, has been named the agency's senior photo editor for sports. Executive Photo Editor Vin Alabiso said Horton will be responsible for planning and monitoring AP's sports photo coverage worldwide. ``Sports is an area of enormous reader interest, and we are giving a senior executive full responsibility for our sports coverage because this area is so important to our members,'' Alabiso said. For the past two years, Horton, 40, has overseen the AP's day-to-day photo report in the United States as director of the LaserPhoto picture network. He joined the AP as a photo editor in Chicago in 1971, transferred to Philadelphia as a photographer in 1972 and to Cincinnati in 1975. He was named photo editor in Columbus in 1980, responsible for the Ohio photo report, and two years later moved to the New York photo desk as photo enterprise editor. Horton is the author of ``The Picture: An Associated Press Guide to Good News Photography,'' and with his wife, Marilyn Dillon, compiled an AP book, ``Great Moments in Sports.''
DOC.HEAD: Parziale Named AP Assistant Bureau Chief
DOC.TEXT: Eva M. Parziale, Associated Press news editor in Columbia, S.C., has been named assistant chief of bureau in Kansas City. Paul Stevens, chief of bureau for Kansas and Missouri, announced the appointment July 3. She succeeds Mercer G. Bailey, who retires next month after a 47-year AP career. Parziale, 29, joined the AP in San Francisco in 1984. After earning a master's degree in journalism at Columbia University, she returned to the AP in Miami in 1985. Two years later Parziale was named correspondent in charge of the Portland, Maine, bureau. She has been news editor in Columbia since March 1989. Bailey, 63, began his AP career in Atlanta. The West Palm Beach, Fla., native also worked in Mobile and Montgomery, Ala., and Miami before transferring to the AP's General Desk in New York as a supervisor in 1963. He became St. Louis correspondent in 1968 and assumed the Kansas City post two years later.
DOC.HEAD: Cassidy Named Honolulu Magazine Editor
DOC.TEXT: Ed Cassidy has been named editor of Honolulu magazine, replacing Brian Nicol, who has accepted a job as editorial director of Aster Publishing Co. in Eugene, Ore. Cassidy had been working as editor of Palm Boulevard (808), a fashion news magazine owned by Honolulu Publishing Co., which also operates Honolulu magazine.
DOC.HEAD: Seibert to Acting Journalism School Dean
DOC.TEXT: David R. Seibert, chairman of the speech and theater department at the University of Nevada-Reno, has been named acting dean of the school of journalism. Seibert succeeds Rollan Melton, who stepped down on the advice of his doctor, said school spokesman Bob Gabrielli. Melton has suffered a heart attack and undergone cancer treatment in recent years. Melton, 58, was named acting dean of the Donald W. Reynolds School of Journalism in June after Travis Linn announced he was stepping down to resume full-time teaching as a professor of journalism next fall.

James Curtis Barden, a retired vice president and chief financial officer of Media General Inc., died of a heart attack July 3. He was 59. Barden retired this year from Media General, parent company of Richmond Newspapers Inc. and other media holdings. A certified public accountant, Barden was named assistant controller of the company in 1967. He became vice president 10 years later and was appointed chief financial officer in 1983. He is survived by a son and a sister.

Robert David Cox, a newspaper reporter who gained national attention last year when he tore down an anti-Woody Guthrie sign, died July 5 when his pickup truck collided with a car driven by his cousin. Cox, 27, sports editor for The Seminole Producer, was on a county road in central Oklahoma when his car collided at an intersection with his cousin's, the Highway Patrol reported. The 17-year-old cousin was not seriously injured. Cox was charged in April 1989 with tearing down a banner on an American Legion building in Okemah, Guthrie's hometown. The banner, which read ``Woody Guthrie Was No Hero,'' had been posted a short time before a concert featuring Arlo Guthrie, the folksinger's son. The city decided a month later not to prosecute Cox. Cox previously worked at The Okemah News Leader and the McAlester News Capital & Democrat.

Merrill D. Hunter, owner and publisher of the Madison Daily Leader, died of a heart attack July 7 at his home. He was 64. Hunter, whose family has owned the paper since 1947, had been publisher for 25 years. His son, Jon, recently took over as general manager. Survivors include his wife, son, two daughters, three grandchildren, a brother and a sister.

Wip Robinson, a journalist for 26 years at WSVA radio in Harrisonburg, Va., died July 7. He was 80. Robinson won the Associated Press merit award for broadcast news gathering in 1958 and 1962. He served as the president of the Association of Professional Broadcasters in 1961 and as president of the organization's Virginia chapter in 1961 and 1962. He won a Sigma Delta Chi award in 1961 for broadcast journalism. Robinson began his broadcast career at a radio station in Tuscola, Ill., in 1941. He retired from WSVA in 1980 after suffering a stroke, and had been in poor health since. He is survived by his wife and a daughter.

Lud Shahbazian, the Hudson Dispatch sports editor emeritus who covered boxers from Jack Dempsey to Joe Frazier in a long career, died July 5 of congestive heart failure. He was 88. Shahbazian was hired as a sports cartoonist at the Dispatch in 1920. Two years later, he was named sports editor and remained in the post for 56 years. He retired as active sports editor in 1978. Shahbazian founded the New Jersey Boxing Writers Association, the New Jersey Racing Writers Association and the Ring 14 Boxing Association for writers and fighters. Shahbazian is survived by his wife, a son and three grandchildren.

Tony Simnett, a veteran journalist and former professional tennis player, died June 30 after a lengthy illness. He was 54. Simnett immigrated to Canada from Britain at age 20 and worked on newspapers in Toronto and Calgary, Alberta, before moving to British Columbia. He was a sports reporter at the Vancouver Sun from 1964 to 1966 before becoming managing editor of the Campbell River Upper Islander and city editor of the short-lived daily Vancouver Courier in 1979. Simnett later worked in public relations. He played professional soccer and represented both Britain and Canada in international tennis events. Simnett is survived by his mother, wife, son and daughter.

Jeffrey Sprung, an ABC Radio executive, died July 1 of a heart attack at age 50. Sprung joined the network in 1968 as manager of public relations and press information. He moved on to work as a radio news writer and editor for five years before being named news manager for the ABC FM Radio Network. In 1982, Sprung was named director of the Entertainment and Direction radio networks for ABC News. He is survived by two sisters.

Dick Thornburg, editor of The Cincinnati Post during much of the 1950s and 1960s, died June 30 in Prescott, Ariz. He was 86. ``He was the consummate newspaperman,'' said William R. Burleigh, senior vice president of Scripps Howard and a former editor of the Post. ``He loved newspapers and he understood what the role of a newspaper was in the community.'' Thornburg began his journalism career in 1929 as a copy boy with the old Columbus (Ohio) Citizen. He was managing editor of the Scripps Howard Newspaper Alliance in Washington, D.C., before being named editor of the Post in 1953. He retired from that job in 1969. The cause of death was not given. Thornburg is survived by a sister.

Harley ``Ace'' Tinkham, a Los Angeles Times sports columnist known for his anecdotes and knowledge of statistics, died July 4. He was 67. Tinkham died at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank of complications from pneumonia. He had suffered respiratory problems for several years. He wrote the Morning Briefing column of offbeat observations and statistics, as well as sports trivia and colorful anecdotes. Tinkham's last Morning Briefing appeared June 8. In 1950, he joined the Los Angeles Mirror, which was absorbed by the Times in 1962. He then went to work at the Los Angeles Herald Examiner but returned to the Times in 1968, covering track and field. He is survived by his wife, a daughter, a son and a sister.

Paul Wynne, a television news reporter who turned the camera on himself and his battle with AIDS in ``Paul Wynne's Journal,'' died July 5 of the disease he chronicled. He was 46. Wynne hosted the KGO-TV weekly show that began airing in January. The show was suspended several weeks ago, when his illness prevented him from working. He died at the Fort Miley Veterans Medical Center in San Francisco. ``Paul Wynne's Journal'' won a local Friends of the Human Rights Commission Award in June.
DOC.HEAD: Aubespin Honored for Work on Behalf of Minorities
DOC.TEXT: Minority affairs specialist Mervin Aubespin of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky., has won the Ida B. Wells Award from the University of Kansas. The award is given annually for outstanding work on behalf of minorities in the news industry. Aubespin, the Courier-Journal associate editor for development, is to be honored Aug. 4 at the National Association of Black Journalists convention in Los Angeles. He is a former president of that group. The award is co-sponsored by the National Conference of Editorial Writers, National Association of Black Journalists and the National Broadcast Editorial Association. It includes $10,000 in scholarships presented in the winner's name to minority journalism students. Wells was a journalist known for her campaign against the lynching of blacks during the late 1800s and early 1900s. In 1909, she helped found the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and took part in the campaign to give women the right to vote.

Richard Nixon's presidential library opens this month in Yorba Linda, Calif., but library director Hugh Hewitt says Watergate reporter Bob Woodward won't be allowed to study there. Woodward says the suggestion that he or others would be kept out ``demonstrates that the library will be part of a continuing cover-up.'' ... Arnaud de Borchgrave, editor in chief of the Washington Times, has won the Distinguished Service in Local Journalism Award from the Washington chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: A year ago, the idea would have been unthinkable. Now it is the most compelling question to confront these leaders of the Western world: Should they dig into their deep pockets to help the Soviet Union and Mikhail S. Gorbachev? The risk of saying no could be the failure of perestroika _ the ambitious restructuring of the Soviet system _ and Gorbachev's downfall. But saying yes has its perils, too, since it would mean pouring billions into an economic morass that has resisted five years of Gorbachev reforms. But ``Where would we be if he were chucked out?'' Brian Mulroney, the Canadian prime minister, wondered aloud on Sunday as he and leaders of the six other richest nations gathered for their annual economic summit. Still, Mulroney himself isn't ready to provide direct help just now. Even more skeptical is President Bush, who received Gorbachev's plea for help in his role as summit host. The President questions the wisdom of assisting the Kremlin while it provides $5 billion a year to Marxist Cuba, spends about one-quarter of its budget on the military and has put few free-market procedures into play.

Mikhail Gorbachev and trade feuds aren't the only hot topics on Houston's summit menu. At the Goode Co. Bar-B-Q barn, loyalists were simmering over the rival stuff the folks tasted at Sunday night's presidential hoedown for his summit guests. George Bush probably would agree. His favorite, Otto's, wasn't served up, either. In Houston, barbecue is a serious subject and a never-ending source of argument. ``We're the best,'' boasted Goode Co. manager Tanguy Libbrecht. ``Otto's is arguably one of the best-known because George Bush plugs it. I've got nothing bad to say against Luther's, but everyone know's we're the best.'' Luther's Bar-B-Q, a popular chain that sports red-and-white check tablecloths and curtains and boasts a ``Taste as Big as Texas,'' donated all the food at Bush's summit feast for 5,000 people. The spread included 1,250 gallons of barbecue sauce, 500 pounds of onions and a jalapeno or two.

After failing to override the governor's veto of a stronger anti-abortion bill, the Legislature passed a measure that would ban most abortions and punish doctors who perform them with up to 10 years at hard labor. The law, which includes exceptions demanded by Gov. Buddy Roemer, still would be the strictest state abortion law in the nation. ``This is the children's hour. Let's vote for the 15,000 unborn children who are murdered in this state every year, for the 200,000 murdered in the nation. The nation is watching us,'' said Sen. John Saunders, mastermind of the revised legislation. The bill approved Sunday night bans all abortions except those to end pregnancies that endanger a woman's life and those caused by rape or incest.

Democratic Rep. James McClure Clarke is being cast by the Republican Party as one of ``the worst violators of the public trust'' in the savings and loan crisis. Why? The North Carolina lawmaker voted last year to let the industry continue investing in junk bonds. So did 113 other House members, none of whom were criticized for that on the GOP hit list. Clarke is one of the politicians caught in the crossfire as Democrats develop the theme they hope to ride to the White House in 1992, and Republicans respond with fusillades of their own. The result is a spotlight on a handful of House members facing the voters this fall. And some of them aren't too happy about the escalating party rhetoric.

Despite spiraling heath care costs, Americans are using a smaller chunk of their income for out-of-pocket medical expenses than they were 30 years ago, a team of government economists reports. The bite is about the same as in 1972-73, said the Health Care Financing Administration researchers. The reason, says Katharine R. Levit, is that private insurance is providing more benefits _ in large part because states are requiring more coverage _ and employers have been unsuccessful in shifting the costs of better coverage to workers. That's bound to change, she predicts, as consumers are pressured to carry a larger share of the burden.

The power of an odor to stimulate memory, familiar to anybody who has suddenly thought of a long-lost lover after getting a whiff of perfume or cologne, has proved itself in a research laboratory. College students who smelled chocolate during a word exercise and again the next day when asked to remember their answers did better than others denied the memory-evoking aroma. Such an odor-based memory strategy could help students studying for multiple exams or airline pilots training for emergencies, said researcher Frank Schab. His work provides the first firm scientific evidence that odors can help bring back memories, said Brian Lyman of the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia.

A man accused of dunking his 2-year-old stepson headfirst into a toilet goes on trial on murder charges this week in a case that raised questions about social workers' failure to protect the toddler. Prosecutors will seek the death penalty for Thomas Coe, who told police he was punishing Bradley McGee for soiling his diaper. The boy's death brought unprecedented charges against four social workers, one of whom was convicted of child abuse. ``If nothing else, all this has made caseworkers be more careful to realize they're making life-or-death decisions here,'' said Pam Kirkland, the boy's foster mother before he was returned to Coe and the mother who abandoned him. ``With every child, they have to stop and ask _ `Could this be the next Bradley McGee?''' Coe, 23, goes on trial Tuesday in Fort Myers. Defense attorneys have acknowledged the dunking but say Coe did not intend to kill the boy, so it wasn't murder.

DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Monday July 16 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Public-Spirited Haitians Scrub Dirty Capital
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ One of the world's dirtiest capitals is becoming cleaner because public-spirited citizens got fed up with the filth and decided to tackle it themselves. ``Everybody's sick and tired, and ashamed, of the situation,'' said Cayotte Bissainthe, co-director of Lave Figi Potoprens, Creole for Let's Wash the Face of Port-au-Prince. ``If the government can't cope, we'll roll up our sleeves and clean up the mess ourselves,'' she said. From her makeshift office downtown, Bissainthe and three other unpaid members of the Lave Figi steering committee coordinate 100 neighborhood committees involved in the project. Cleanup squads have been taking a city block at a time, sweeping, hauling away refuse, hosing down and sometimes repairing the pavement, even planting trees in old tires filled with earth. In some cases, they've added a decorative touch by painting wall murals. ``The response has been wonderful and shows how full of life and hope the Haitian people are, in spite of all our troubles,'' Bissainthe said. This destitute city of more than 1 million people has long been not only unsightly, but woefully unsanitary, with chest-high heaps of garbage on every corner, and sometimes even in the middle of the street. Only 50 percent of the 500 tons of garbage the capital produces daily was picked up even in better times _ before the Public Works Ministry took over garbage collection from the city last year. Torrential rains washed the rest downhill, through the slums and into the polluted bay. Ecologists of the Federation of the Friends of Nature raised alarms about the health hazard but the city government went broke and, through similar mismanagement and corruption, so did the Public Works Ministry. Since April 12, when the government officially recognized it, Lave Figi has received $4,350 in private donations, ranging from individual gifts of $2 to a $2,100 contribution from the Roman Catholic charity CARITAS. President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot's civilian government, which assumed power March 13, is in financial straits and has not yet been able to fulfill its promise of funds for the campaign. Lave Figi has used the donated money to buy safety masks and hire workers to load garbage trucks. Businessmen provide some workers on loan. Shovels, rakes and wheelbarrows have been donated. The government provides the garbage trucks and Lave Figi fills the gas tanks and tips the drivers. ``We have no choice but to do it ourselves; our lives and our dignity depend on it,'' said Bissainthe, who was Haiti's consul general in Puerto Rico for a time after dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled the country in 1986. Response to Lave Figi was immediate from a citizenry that suffered one variety of flu after another and had to live with stench, flies, roaches and rats. Sixty neighborhood organizations joined as soon as it was formed. ``It isn't as much as we need, but it encourages us to go on,'' said Max Valbrun, 24, co-leader of the Dehoux Street Youth Committee. ``In our four years' existence, this is the first time we have been able to get any outside help.'' The 50 youths of the Dehoux Street committee clean up their street at least three times a week. Lave Figi is non-partisan, but Bissainthe said community action is part of the struggle for democracy in Haiti. ``The same community effort to clean its collective house occurred spontaneously after the fall of Duvalier, but this time the movement is organized citywide,'' she said. ``Our aim is to give it a permanent structure, to set up a non-profit association which will see that our citizens' initiative lives on and on and on.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, July 21, the 202nd day of 1990. There are 163 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On July 21, 1925, the so-called Monkey Trial ended in Dayton, Tenn., with John T. Scopes found guilty of violating state law for teaching Darwin's Theory of Evolution. (The conviction was later overturned.) On this date: In 1816, Paul Julius Reuter, founder of the British news agency that bears his name, was born in Hesse, Germany. In 1831, Belgium became independent as Leopold the First was proclaimed King of the Belgians. In 1861, the first Battle of Bull Run was fought at Manassas, Va., resulting in a Confederate victory. In 1899, author Ernest Hemingway was born in Oak Park, Ill. In 1944, American forces landed on Guam during World War II. In 1944, the Democratic national convention, meeting in Chicago, nominated Sen. Harry S. Truman to be vice president. In 1949, the U.S. Senate ratified the North Atlantic Treaty by a vote of 82-13. In 1954, France surrendered North Vietnam to the Communists. In 1961, Captain Virgil ``Gus'' Grissom became the second American to rocket into a sub-orbital pattern around the earth, flying aboard the Liberty Bell 7. In 1969, Apollo 11 astronauts Neil Armstrong and Edwin ``Buzz'' Aldrin blasted off from the moon after 21{ hours on the surface and returned to the command module, piloted by Michael Collins. In 1983, Maine schoolgirl Samantha Smith ended her two-week tour of the Soviet Union as she and her parents left without getting to see the man who had invited them, Yuri V. Andropov. In 1988, Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis accepted the Democratic presidential nomination at the party's convention in Atlanta. Ten years ago: Draft registration began in the United States for 19- and 20-year-old men as anti-war demonstrators staged protests. Five years ago: A state of emergency went into effect in South Africa, giving police broad new powers in 36 towns and cities to combat anti-apartheid rioting. One year ago: The State Department confirmed an ABC News report that Felix S. Bloch, a veteran U.S. diplomat, was being investigated as a possible Soviet spy. (To date, Bloch has yet to be charged with a crime.) Today's Birthdays: Violinist Isaac Stern is 70. Actor-comedian Don Knotts is 66. Movie director Norman Jewison is 64. Actor Edward Herrmann is 47. Yusuf Islam, formerly singer Cat Stevens, is 43. Comedian-actor Robin Williams is 38. Thought for Today: ``There is no bigotry like that of `free thought' run to seed.'' -- Horace Greeley, American journalist (1811-1872).

DOC.HEAD: Making a Case for Creating More Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, who is vacationing.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: America, land of immigrants, has long been of two minds about immigration. On the one hand, people remember their own forebears. They react to the words on the base of the Statue of Liberty. On the other hand, the new immigrant is often resented. When the Irish were pouring into America by the tens of thousands to avoid famine, public sentiment was against Irish immigration. When Italians arrived by the boatload to provide the labor supply that transformed the country from an agricultural society into an industrialized society, sentiment was anti-Italian. When the Chinese settled in San Francisco and became famous for the laundries they operated, their non-Chinese competitors persuaded the state legislature to require that laundries be built of brick. Somehow, the only launderers prosecuted for working out of wooden buildings were Chinese. There's always been at work a last-one-off-the-boat, pull-up-the-ladder syndrome. Organized labor, normally on the liberal side of issues, frequently opposes liberalized immigration. It suspects immigrants will take jobs and take lower wages. Old Guard conservatives also often want to restrict immigration. They fear that the Western European heritage that is the foundation of the Constitution and the culture will be worn away under waves of today's newcomers, many dark-skinned and from the Third World, who know nothing of the Bible, the Magna Carta, checks and balances. Yet humanitarian instincts exert their own tug. The land of opportunity over the decades has sheltered those yearning to be free. Exerting the tug these days are Russian Jews and Eastern Europeans who waited for years for the opportunity to leave and risked much by applying to go; Vietnamese who jeopardized their lives to flee home in dangerous boats; Afghans who fought in a war supported by the United States. Let them in, argues a conservative economist, Stephen Moore, who said he bases his appeal not on any squishy sentimentality but on self-serving pragmatism. ``I see it not that we're doing good for them but that they do good for us,'' he said. Moore, formerly with the Heritage Foundation, is executive director of the American Immigration Institute, newly founded to campaign for increased immigration. Its co-chairmen are a conservative, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who was born in Berlin, and a liberal, Mayor Raymond Flynn of Boston. ``If America's going to continue to be a first-class economic power, we've got to be able to compete,'' Moore said in an interview. ``If an immigrant works 18 hours a day, that's not something to be held against him, that's what capitalism is all about: work hard and you'll get ahead.'' He said the United States now admits about three immigrants per 1,000 residents. At the turn if the century it was 15 per 1,000. His group wants to return to 15. At the same time, as a conservative, Moore opposes the $5,000 per person given refugees (but not immigrants) resettling in the United States as a safety net. He said it implants a welfare mentality, starts the newcomers off looking for handouts. ``Refugees locating in California have four times as high a dependency rate and only half the labor force participation rate as do those in Texas, where benefits are less than half as generous,'' he said in an essay in Policy Review, published by the Heritage Foundation. He would substitute low-interest loans. U.S. law distinguishes between immigrants and refugees and between economic refugees and political refugees, those who have ``a well-founded fear of persecution'' if they were returned to their former country of residence. Currently, the United States admits about 600,000 people a year, of whom about 100,000 are political refugees. It is sometimes estimated that illegal immigration brings the annual total to 1 million. Moore argues that the distinction between political and economic refugees no longer makes sense. The policy, he said, translates to: ``We will not let you die at the hands of the executioner, but are ambivalent to your death from economic deprivation.'' He cites what happened 10 years ago. In what became known as the Mariel boat lift, thousands of Cubans, let loose by Fidel Castro as a safety valve for his island's faltering economy, traveling in tiny boats, arrived in Florida. Ultimately, they numbered about 120,000. Americans looked askance. In a poll, 91 percent said all immigration to the United States should be halted until the national unemployment rate, then 7 percent, fell to 5 percent. Much was made of the psychotics and the criminals Castro sent along with economic immigrants. ``But if you look at the vast majority who came, they have assimilated extraordinarily well in the Miami economy, which throughout the 1980s flourished,'' said Moore.
