DOC.HEAD: Couple About to Become Great-Grandparents Reflects on the Past
DOC.TEXT: My wife, Virginia, and I were born in the 1920s. She never had a glimpse of her grandparents. I have vague recollections of one _ my mother's father, who died when I was 5. Now Susan and Michael Springer of Canyon Country, Calif., have anounced we are to become great-grandparents. After the spontaneous outrush of joy, the full implication of the aging of America smashed in. And if two kids who began dating in high school get the chance, what lasting impression do Virigina and I want to leave with our first great-grandchild? My reporter's instincts always have been tantalizied by the lives of my grandparents. If only I could have interviewed them. Anders Valter (the name was changed to Andrew Walters at Ellis Island) was 39 when he left Sweden in the 1880s with a wife and three daughters (Two children were born in this country, including my dad). I have the 15-inch jardiniere grandmother Mathilda brought with her. What would induce her to take such an impractical but beautiful, piece of porcelain in the 10 cubic feet of steerage luggage allowed the family? Did my grandfather know before they left? Anders Erikson, my maternal grandfather who became Andrew W. Ericson, came alone from Sweden about the same time. I have his contract of passage. He paid $35.74 in U.S. currency. For that he was assured he would sail in steerage by way of England to New York City and be carried by train to Porter, Ind., all this ``with good and sufficient food and hotel accommodations where called for.'' In 1892, he won a gold medal at the World's Fair. I have a postal card, apparently as mass advertisement, showing him and his ``refrigerator,'' an ornate box using ice for the coolant. His wife, Emma, was born at Porter. Her death, at 42, rated a long front-page story in the daily newspaper at Michigan City, Ind., where the Ericsons and Walters then lived. But the story, also among my possessions, says only that she was known for many good works in the community, without specifying. When our parents were born around the turn of this century, life expectancy was about 50 years. Today it's 75. Many chldren know their grandparents, some their great-grandparents. However, the mother of Virginia's mother died from complications of childbirth. The father died a few years later. My future mother-in-law was raised by relatives. Those three events were common at that time. My wife's father immigrated from Poland. Virginia remembers receiving small packages of Polish hard candy once a year from her grandmother until World War II began. Nothing afterward. Virginia's dad was fluent in eight languages, including Russian, German and Polish. In Indiana, he managed a factory. But he was vague about Poland and the reason for his linguistic skills. Was he involved in revolutionary activities and had to flee for his life, as a relative later told me? Except for vital statistics such as birth, marriage and death records, that's about all I can tell my grandchildren _ three boys and three girls _ of their great-grandparents. Will my great-grandchild want to hear my stories? I can hardly wait. Actually, my own great-grandad may have warned me against smoking marijuana. I'm going to check courthouse records to see if I can find out when I visit Indiana later this summer. As a youngster, I went to Porter often to visit ``Grandpa Swanson.'' My grandmother Emma's maiden name was Swanson, so he could have been her father. He couldn't have been my grandfather. Family lines were blurred in those days, and most of us had dozens of ``aunts'' and ``uncles.'' Once in a while he would tell stories about the Civil War or Indians. On rare occasions he would take a troop of youngsters for short walks. On one he pointed to a weed growing alongside a ditch on his farm and said something like this: ``Years ago, when the Pottawatomie Indians lived around here, they would sit around their evening campfire and some would smoke this. Now I know you boys and girls are going to try smoking sometime. It's not a good idea. But if you do, stick to cornsilks and tobacco. The Indians who smoked this stuff would go real crazy.'' Maybe it was because his delivery was so impressive. Maybe we were so impressionable. But so far as I know, none of us ever tried. A Swedish immigrant, he also told of fighting with the Indiana volunteers at Gettysburg, arriving by forced march on the third day of the battle. ``There were bodies in blue and gray uniforms all over,'' he said. ``The smell was terrible. The flies came from miles away, thousands of them. The Army fed us hardtack spread with honey. At first we tried to pick them off, but two would land for every one we picked off. Finally, we gave up and ate it, flies and all.'' Years later, I went to Gettysburg and stood where he must have been. It was beautiful and peaceful. But in my mind all I could see where hungry soldiers eating fly-covered honey and crackers. I never have been sure of his first name. But each Fourth of July, when I was a boy, he would dress in his blue uniform and ride at or near the head of the local parade. Once, at the cemetery, I saw tears flood down his cheeks when the bugler played taps.
James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 12, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Planning Can Lessen Stress of Hospital Stay
DOC.TEXT: For many of us, going to the hospital is somewhat like traveling to a foreign country _ the sights are not familiar, the language sounds strange, and the people wear unusual costumes. No matter what the reason for the trip _ whether it's an overnight visit for tests or a longer stay for medical treatment or major surgery _ entering the hospital may be worrisome. In my experience, knowing about hospitals and the people who work there and planning can make the trip less stressful. The following hints are meant especially for those who know in advance they'll be going to the hospital and therefore have time to prepare. Relatives and friends of people who are admitted to a hospital because of an emergency also may find this information useful. Take as little as possible with you. However, be sure to pack the following: a list of the medicines you are taking (prescription and non-prescription drugs); details of past illnesses, surgeries, and any allergies; your health insurance card; telephone numbers of relatives to contact in an emergency; and a few personal items such as nightclothes, toothbrush, toothpaste, shampoo and deodorant. Leave money, jewelry (including wedding rings and watches), credit cards, and checkbooks at home or have a family member or friend keep them. If you must take valuables, ask if they can be kept in the hospital safe. If possible, ask a relative or friend to go with you to the hospital for support. While there, you'll have an attending physician, who directs your overall care. In a teaching hospital, you'll also be treated by medical students and residents, doctors who have graduated from medical school and are continuing their training. Registered nurses, licensed practical nurses and aides give medicines, check your blood pressure, and provide other services. Physical, occupational and respiratory therapists also may be involved in your care, as well as the hospital dietition, pharmicist and social worker. In some hospitals, a team that includes a doctor, a nurse, a social worker and other specialists performs a thorough review and examination, called a geriatric assessment, to learn about your physical and mental health, family life, income, living arrangements, access to community services and ability to perform daily tasks such as dressing and preparing meals. The team not only diagnoses health problems but also develops a plan to make sure you receive appropriate health care and social services on a continuing basis. Before leaving the hospital, you can arrange for home care. A service called discharge planning is offered in the hospital so that, if needed, a visiting nurse, hospital equipment, meals-on wheels or other services will be there when you go home. The discharge planner also knows about senior centers, nursing homes and other long-term care facilities in your community. In the event of a serious illness or accident, it's vital to seek medical help right away. In many areas, you can reach emergency help by calling 911 or the telphone operator. Be sure to tell the operator the type of emergency and your location. If you have a minor injury or your symptoms aren't severe, call your doctor or a nearby clinic before going to the emergency room. Sometimes an emergency room visit isn't necessary. If it is, your doctor can make things easier by calling the hospital to let them know you're coming. Your doctor also may arrange to meet you there. If there's time, try to take your health insurance card or policy number, your doctor's name and telephone number, a list of the medicines you take, information about other medical problems, and the telephone numbers of close relatives. It's helpful to record and keep this information on a note card you can carry in your wallet or purse. If you have a particular medical problem such as diabetes, epilepsy or allergies, you should wear an ID bracelet or necklace or carry an ID card to let rescue workers and hospital personnel know about these conditions. The National Institute on Aging distributes free information on topics including ``Hospital Hints,'' ``Finding Good Medical Care for Older Americans,'' and ``Who's Who in Health Care.'' These publications are available from the NIA Information Center, P.O. Box 8057, Gaithersburg, Md., 20857-8057.

T. Franklin Williams, a geriatrics physician, is director of the National Institute on Aging, one of the 13 institutes that comprise the National Institutes of Health of the Department of Health and Human Services.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 12, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Shortcuts to a Fruitful Garden
DOC.TEXT: As time goes by, some of us become shortcut gardeners _ happy to have found ways to lighten the work load and still enjoy the fruits of the soil. Viewed from this angle, the novice toils unnecessarily with spade and hoe, machinery, heavy bags of fertilizer. The veteran lets nature do much of the work. Back in the 1950s, a Connecticut gardener named Ruth Stout wrote a book called ``How to Have a Green Thumb Without an Aching Back,'' which became the bible of the lazy gardener. Basically, what Ms. Stout did was to cover her vegetable garden with a permanent eight-inch layer of hay and dump her daily kitchen scraps on top of that. Ms. Stout _ a sister of detective story writer Rex Stout _ also tossed leaves, grass clippings, uprooted weeds and other plant wastes on the pile, all of which gradually decayed and turned into rich topsoil. The thick cover _ called mulch _ also stifled weeds. When planting, Ms. Stout pushed aside the mulch and, after the seeds sprouted, pulled it back around the seedlings. The process goes all year round. In winter, the kitchen garbage gets tossed on the snow. This is organic gardening with a vengeance. In effect, your compost heap is your garden, so you don't have to build up and keep a separate compost heap. Practitioners never have to turn up the soil in fall or spring, never have to pull up a weed. Now, grateful as we are to Ms. Stout, not all of us want to look at banana peels on the snow. Out in the county where I live, my vegetable garden is the first thing people see when they come up the drive. My wife is great for vegetables _ sun most of the day and good drainage on a slight slope. But she draws a line at eggshells and coffee grains. Sacrificing the garbage, a mulch gardener can still achieve pretty much the same results with a deep cover of leaves, grass clippings and _ with money _ bales of salt hay available at nurseries. The yellow hay makes a pretty background for the vegetables. Wood ashes, or lime, occasionally mixed in with the leaves, insure against the danger of acidity. Having eliminated tilling and weeding, a lazy gardener soon finds additional ways to reduce work. The plants themselves will help, if you know the ones you can count on. Perennials, like asparagus and rhubarb, need only the initial planting. After that they come up year after year. All you do is harvest them. Most vegetables are annuals, however, needing to be sowed anew every year. Of those, broccoli is my ideal labor-saving crop. Planted early in spring in my southern New York garden, broccoli produces a large head in late June or early July. After this is harvested, the plant keeps yielding side shoots, or florets, deep into the frosts of fall, with little or no attention fro me. And broccoli ranks high on nutrition charts, a powerhouse of vitamins and minerals. I save much work by letting tomatoes sprawl on the salt hay instead of staking them. And I include a few tomatoes of indeterminate varieties, like Yellow Pear, which yield all season long instead of all at once. Pole limas, unlike the bush varieties, also keep yielding until frost. Many lettuces respond well to cut-and-come-again harvesting. At maturity, you cut the plant at near soil level and the stump will come back and give you another harvest. Plants like Swiss chard and New Zealand spinach also are season-long performers. A fine beet is Winter Keeper. It can stay in the ground for months and never lose its flavor. A gardener who prefers his exercise on the tennis court or golf course also learns to plant sparingly. Nine tomato plants will do handsomely. Who needs to lug baskets of produce out of the garden and then try to give them away to the neighbors?
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, July 12, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Survey: Elderly Consumers More Trusting than the Young
DOC.TEXT: Older Americans, who acquired their buying habits in a more trusting era, are less knowledgeable than the young about their rights as consumers, a survey shows. The survey, conducted for the American Association of Retired Persons, shows that while 62 percent of people under 65 believe businesses try to mislead consumers at least half the time, only 44 percent of older people say that is true. Of those older than 65, only 36 percent said they knew a buyer has several days to cancel a purchase made from a door-to-door sales person, and only 28 percent said they knew consumers are not liable for all charges to a stolen credit card prior to notifying the company. ``Older consumers' buying habits were formed during a time when a more trusting relationship existed between the sellers and buyers of goods and services,'' said Horace B. Deets, the association's executive director. ``To this extent, older consumers are at a disadvantage in dealing with some of today's business practices,'' he said. The survey was conducted by telephone with 1,305 people ages 25 to over 85.
DOC.HEAD: Elderly Black City Dwellers May Live Longer
DOC.TEXT: New evidence suggests that once they reach 75, big-city black Americans live longer and go to nursing homes less often than whites of the same age. On the other hand, elderly blacks are more likely to develop diabetes, high blood pressure and glaucoma. The study on race-related differences among the elderly was supported by the National Institute on Aging and is reported in the July issue of ``The Journal of Gerontology: Social Sciences.'' The study involved 1,598 urban dwellers aged 65 and over. Initial interviews were conducted in 1975, and 645 survivors were re-interviewed in 1984. Although interviewers rated elderly whites as more physically impaired _ 40.9 percent to 31.2 percent _ blacks rated their own physical health more unfavorably than did whites.
DOC.HEAD: The Elderly in Popular Music: `Over the Hill to the Poor House'
DOC.TEXT: Popular sheet music issued in the United States from 1830 to 1980 shows a clear preference for youth and often portrays the elderly with fear, concern and ridicule, a study shows. Reviewing more than 15,000 pieces of sheet music and titles, reviewers Elias S. Cohen and Anna L. Kruschwitz of the Community Services Institute Inc., of Narbeth, Pa., said a substantial majority of those dealing specifically with the elderly showed them in a distinctly negative light. ``Old age is seen more as a time of failing capacities and diminished status than as a time of fulfillment and the `golden years,' '' Cohen said. Fear of old age, he said, is seen in such titles as ``The Withered Tree,'' issued in 1850, and 1874's ``Over the Hill to the Poor House.'' The cover art illustrating many pieces of sheet music shows an exaggerated view of age,'' the study said. In ``Happy Family Polka,'' written in 1851, grandchildren of no more than 8 or 9 years old are shown. The parents appear to be in their early 30s, but the grandparents, who logically would be in their 50s, are shown as they would appear in their 70s or 80s. The study was published in the June issue of The Gerontologist.

As President Bush welcomes leaders of the world's seven richest industrial democracies for their annual economic summit, the United States is adjusting to a new role in an era where economic power counts more than military might. While the Western allies were once willing to let the United States set the agenda, the summit countries seem willing, even eager, to chart their own courses now that America's nuclear umbrella no longer seems crucial. ``1990 is the first year after the end of the Cold War,'' said Michael Mandelbaum of the Council on Foreign Relations. ``The American nuclear surplus will be less and less important and the American fiscal deficit will be more important.''

The nation's unemployment rate edged downward to 5.2 percent last month despite an ongoing slide in manufacturing and overall weakness in job growth, the government reported. Fewer Americans looking for work _ not any rebound in sluggish economic activity _ accounted for the improvement over May's jobless rate of 5.3 percent, analysts said Friday. The economy added just 40,000 jobs to non-farm payrolls in June, the Labor Department said. __ NEW YORK (AP) _ Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. has agreed to pay the New York Stock Exchange a record $500,000 fine to settle allegations that it violated exchange rules in buying E.F. Hutton & Co. stock in 1986, the NYSE said. Shearson agreed to pay the fine without admitting or denying wrongdoing, the NYSE said Friday. According to the NYSE, Shearson violated exchange rules in 1986 by failing to announce on the exchange floor as it bought a 4.9 percent stake in Hutton that the shares were intended for Shearson's own account, as opposed to a customer's account.

The Acura luxury car division of Japan's Honda Motor Co. Ltd. has topped the J.D. Power and Associates list of cars most satisfying to their owners for the fourth year in a row, the marketing company said. The organization said in a news release received Friday its overall customer-satisfaction index rose about 3 percent to 122 points this year from last year.

A Delaware court paved the way for an investor group to proceed in its takeover attempt of National Intergroup Inc., a Pittsburgh-based holding company of metals and pharmaceuticals. Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett of the Delaware Chancery Court ruled Friday that Centaur Partners Group may proceed with its appeal to the Delaware Supreme Court. The New York investor group is asking the court to decide whether a simple majority of shareholders can vote to expand the firm's board of directors from 12 to 15 members. National Intergroup contends 80 percent of shareholder approval is necessary.

The Bush administration said it is planning to enhance current seafood inspections with a voluntary program financed by companies whose products could earn an official government seal. The new program would use industry controls and government inspections ``to provide additional assurances to consumers that fish and fish products are safe, wholesome and properly labeled,'' officials said Friday.

The government ordered Hawaii-based Discovery Airways closed down in one week, accusing the 3-month-old carrier of violating U.S. laws on foreign ownership. The Transportation Department on Friday ordered the airline to cancel its flights and inform passengers how to obtain refunds or alternate transportation.

A federal judge rejected a request from jurors in the fraud and racketeering trial of three commodities traders that they be allowed to go to the scene of the alleged crimes _ the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The jury said, ``We believe this could be instrumental to reaching a unanimous verdict, if we were to view the pit for approximately 15 to 30 minutes prior to the close of trading.'' But U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams denied the request on Friday.

East Germany gave communities control of former state-run grocery stores after consumers found eye-popping food prices in their first foray into the free market. Stung by the soaring prices that followed the merger of the German economies on Sunday, Parliament passed a law Friday to break up the state grocery chains that suddenly had become unregulated monopolies.

Stock prices gained ground Friday in the slowest trading of the year, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 25.74 to 2,904.95 and finished the week with a net gain of 24.26 points. The dollar finished mixed on domestic currency markets after closing higher overseas. Bond prices dropped sharply. Grain and soybean futures prices plunged for the second straight day; pork futures fell sharply; copper futures climbed; precious metals slipped; and energy futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: EC Jobless Rate Steady At 8.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The unemployment rate in the European Community has remained steady at 8.6 percent for the first five months of the year, The EC statistical office reported Monday. Unemployment ranged from 1.7 percent in Luxembourg to 16.6 percent in Ireland, the report said. The figures given were seasonally adjusted. The latest unseasonally adjusted total of officially registered jobless people in the EC was 13.9 million in April.

Gainers held a slight edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 370 up, 350 down and 489 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Iran's Oil Output Slips
DOC.TEXT: Iran's oil output fell below 3 million barrels a day during June, the Middle East Economic Survey reported Monday. The Nicosia-based weekly, quoting unidentified sources, estimated Iran's crude oil production at 2.93 million barrels a day in June, compared with 3.43 million barrels a day in May. The newsletter said the daily output of Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries members was about 23.26 million barrels last month, compared to 23.68 million the month before. It said the drop was largely explained by the 500,000-barrel-a-day fall in Iranian production. The cartel's oil ministers are scheduled to meet in Geneva on July 25. The United Arab Emirates and Kuwait are seeking higher output quotas but some other members, with Iraq in the lead, insist that quotas cannot be increased until prices are restored to the $18-a-barrel benchmark level. The newsletter said the price of a basket of seven OPEC crude oil types fell to $14.05 a barrel in June, down from $15.45 in May. The average price for the first half of this year has been $17.03 a barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Corn, Soybean Futures Slip On Mild Weather Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Corn and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting forecasts for good growing conditions in the Midwest. Wheat and oat futures were narrowly mixed. Mild temperatures and scattered showers are expected this week in the Midwest, the major corn and soybean production area. A new National Weather Service six-to-10-day outlook was due out later today. Corn and soybean prices also were pressured by perceptions that today's Agriculture Department report on crop conditions will show improvement in those crops. The winter wheat harvest continues to weigh on wheat prices as farmers sell old-crop wheat to make room for the new, said Joel Karlin, a grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.09 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to 2{ cents higher with July at $2.78} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with September at $1.38} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 2 cents higher with July at $6.17 a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly higher while pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .25 cent higher with August at 73.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .50 cent higher with August at 85.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .55 cent lower to .05 cent higher with July at 61.65 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to .97 cent higher with July at 53.20 cents a pound. Cattle settled higher on Friday; pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Some Unlucky Legislators Caught in Political Sniping Over S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, The Fresno ..., to recast criticism of Pashayan. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Rep. James McClure Clarke is being cast by the Republican Party as one of ``the worst violators of the public trust'' in the savings and loan crisis. Why? The North Carolina lawmaker voted last year to let the industry continue investing in junk bonds. So did 113 other House members, none of whom were criticized for that on the GOP hit list. Clarke is one of the politicians caught in the crossfire as Democrats develop the theme they hope to ride to the White House in 1992, and Republicans respond with fusillades of their own. The result is a spotlight on a handful of House members facing the voters this fall. And some of them aren't too happy about the escalating party rhetoric. ``Making a political football of it is not going to solve the problem,'' said Rep. Charles Pashayan, R-Calif. His Democratic challenger consulted with party strategists in Washington and came out swinging on S&Ls. ``Frankly, from my standpoint, there is enough blame to go around to everybody,'' said Rep. Doug Barnard of Georgia, one of the Democrats on the GOP list. ``In all fairness, they ought to take that off the board _ both Democrats and Republicans.'' Both parties acknowledge a few members of Congress are vulnerable on S&Ls. But the Democrats aren't about to soft-pedal a promising national strategy and the Republicans can't take the assault lying down. ``To me this is apples and oranges,'' said Democratic Party Chairman Ronald Brown. ``On the one hand, you have accusations against individuals. On the other, you have the question of whose policies allowed this mess to happen. And there is no doubt in my mind that this happened because of Republican economic policies.'' The Democrats, though taking a broad-brush approach, are not ignoring individual Republicans with S&L problems. Pashayan is one example. The Fresno congressman is under fire for trying to block restrictions on risky thrift investments and taking $26,000 in contributions from former S&L operator Charles Keating and his friends. Pashayan said his actions have not been influenced by S&L-related contribution, but he returned the money. The national GOP strategy has been to defend President Bush's handling of the $300 billion-plus bailout and, when provoked, point fingers at Congress and individual Democrats. The Republican National Committee hastily compiled its list of 10 alleged ``violators of the public trust'' after learning that Brown was launching an S&L offensive at a June 29-30 meeting of state party chairmen. Among those named were the four Democrats among the Keating Five _ senators under investigation for accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars from Keating and his S&L associates, then allegedly lobbying regulators to keep his failing S&L open. None of the five is up for re-election this year. The GOP case against Barnard and Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., both Keating beneficiaries and heads of subcommittees dealing with S&Ls, is that they protected the industry while the crisis was developing. Both deny it. Rep. Steve Neal, D-N.C., made the list for sponsoring a 1987 amendment that Republicans claimed was too nice to S&Ls. He disputes the interpretation and says he's targeted because his re-election races are always tough. ``They're going to try this stuff to confuse the issue and pass the buck, but ultimately they cannot do it, because it was their main philosophy,'' said Neal, another banking subcommittee chairman. ``It was a conscious decision on their part not to supervise this industry.'' Neal's Republican opponent didn't raise the S&L issue until the GOP list appeared. But Neal says the Democrats should stay on the offensive _ even if he gets hit by a stray shot. ``They ought to tell the truth about it and let the chips fall where they may,'' he said. He added: ``I don't feel caught in it myself. Anything they say about me on this, they are saying the same thing about a whole lot of Republicans.'' Clarke, who is not involved with banking policy, appeared to be on the S&L list because he won his last race by just 1,529 votes. ``We were automatically destined for the Republican hit list and always have been. So they fished around for this S&L-related thing,'' said Terry Garren, Clarke's administrative assistant. Garren said they should have fished around for something else. He said the same type of ammunition can be used against Clarke's Republican challenger, Charles Taylor, a banker. ``I guarantee you positively, just like Federal Express, that they're going to hear about it,'' Garren promised.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Lands Major French Retailer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with Trump confirming deal but declining to give its pricetag; give detail; adds that store would be first Galeries Lafayette branch in the United States. No pickup. Version moving on ggeneral news wires.
DOC.TEXT: France's largest retailer, Galeries Lafayette, has signed a lease in Trump Tower reportedly worth millions of dollars to developer Donald Trump. The lease to create the first Galeries Lafayette branch in the United States should increase Trump Tower's value and strengthen the financially troubled developer's credit standing. It was announced by Trump today. The New York Times reported that the lease is for 25 years. Trump and Georges Meyer, chairman of the department store, declined at a news conference to comment on the term or price of the agreement. The newspaper put the value in the tens of millions of dollars. Trump's commercial and residential skyscraper is located on Manhattan's fashionable Fifth Avenue. Meyer said the lease is for 80,000 square feet. The site had been occupied by Bonwit Teller. Trump bought out Bonwit's 12-year lease for about $5 million after the store's parent company, L.J. Hooker Co., filed for bankruptcy. Galeries Lafayette is second only to Harrods of London among Europe's largest department stores. Meyer said its Trump Tower store will concentrate on fashion, cosmetics and accessories. It is to open in fall 1991. ``For French people, America is the place to be. New York is the place to be in America. And Trump Tower is the place to be in New York,'' said Meyer. Trump said the agreement was ``a wonderful thing for New York City. A great department store from Paris is coming to New York _ one of the great stores of the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Thinking Dismally
DOC.TEXT: This is a very important week in economic affairs, not just because of the economic summit in Houston but because the week's dosage of key indicators will be released on Friday the 13th. Sensible people understand that the coincidence doesn't ensure the figures will be bad, but such a degree of uncertainty exists these days that you cannot be complacent. Securities markets have been shaken by less. Uncertainty is the enemy of economic progress. It is a malady made worse in modern times by computers that spit out positive data one day, negative the next. It is the all-purpose explanation for lethargy in securities markets. These days, it reigns over all. It rises just before budget deficit or trade figures are released and it is exacerbated every time a statement is released about the progress of trade talks with Japan. Will the Japanese live up to their agreements? The celebration over political-economic events in Europe is muted by the uncertainty of what might follow. It rises every time another blue chip company reports a decline in earnings, as many of them have been doing lately. Uncertainty received a megashot in recent days when President Bush indicated he might renege on what had been a near-certainty _ that the phrase ``tax increase'' would not escape his lips. Will he? Or won't he? And will Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, allow interest rates to fall, as so many Wall Street analysts have been forecasting? Or, perish the thought, might he allow them to rise, as some analysts fear? There's that savings and loan fiasco to deal with. It might be the ultimate statistical uncertainty; what had been thought to be a $50 billion disaster, then a $500 billion catastrophe might become a trillion-dollar tragedy. Hearing this, an unnerved financial analyst was thought to say something to the effect that you haven't heard anything yet. Some banks and insurers, he said, are in bad shape. They might survive, he said, but you can't be certain. All these concerns must be viewed in the context of the all-encompassing macro uncertainty, which is whether the economy will fall into recession or instead grow slightly or perhaps even embark on a boom. Who really knows? What is known is that you can never be certain that interest rates and prices will fall in a recession, no matter what economic theory states. And, you are warned almost every day, if the economy expands instead, then higher prices and higher interest rates are a real threat. If weather reports were issued this way everyone would run for cover. But most people hear the bad news forecasts of storms to come and simply take an umbrella with them. Some just smile, and sometimes the weather smiles back. It is different with economic forecasts. You must think ``dismal.'' There's a statistical threat a day, and even the brightest indicators carry caveat asterisks, as if every fair-weather cumulus was a developing tornado. Well, said an analyst, you can't be 100 percent certain it isn't.

DOC.HEAD: Record-Labeling Bill Sent to Louisiana Governor, Who Is Cool To It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Roemer said ..., to CORRECT spelling of labels. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana's abortion bill isn't the only piece of restrictive legislation facing Gov. Buddy Roemer, who also must decide whether to sign a bill to require warning labels on records. Roemer said today that he favors warning labels for recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, incest, illegal drug use, child abuse and satanic worship, but would prefer that the industry adopt a voluntary program. The Legislature passed legislation Saturday requiring warning labels on recordings with those themes, and banning sales to minors. At a news conference, Roemer said he had serious legal questions about the constitutionality of the labeling bill. But he said he did not know yet whether he would sign or veto the measure. Roemer said most of the recording industry was acting responsibly, but ``some portions of the industry produce pure trash. Parents don't know that until they are brought home and played,'' he said. Roemer said he preferred a voluntary program, similar to he ratings system adopted by the movie industry. ``We'll all be better off,'' he said. In May, the recording industry unveiled a voluntary labeling system that it hoped would halt campaigns in some states for mandatory labeling. The program became effective this month and labeled recordings already are showing up in stores, said Mike Cutshaw, an attorney representing the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. The House voted 79-9 to concur with Senate amendments to the bill by Rep. Ted Haik, and sent it to Roemer for his signature or veto. Although the bill passed both chambers with more than the two-thirds vote needed to override a veto, the regular session ends tonight and Roemer has 20 days to decide on the bill after it reaches his desk. If he vetoes the bill, that would effectively kill it unless there were a special session called. Karen Knowles, the head of the Louisiana Music Commission, which promotes the state's music industry, said the panel was concerned because of the potential economic effect the bill could have. Knowles said she had discussed the bill with the governor, but he did not say whether he would sign it. Thomas Casey, Roemer's executive counsel, said Sunday that the bill would be studied carefully before the governor makes a decision. Already, the producers of the Grammy Awards show have said such a law would scuttle Louisiana's chances of being host of the event. Also, backers of a proposed Grammy Hall of Fame in New Orleans say the law would end their project, at a cost to the city's depressed economy estimated by some at $100 million. Under the legislation, record manufacturers would be required to label recordings with objectionable lyrics. Retailers would be subject to misdemeanor criminal penalties for selling labeled recordings to those under 17. Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, said most state legislatures considering such bills had backed down since the industry announced its plans for voluntary labeling. Last week, Capitol Records promised to provide legal help to store operators threatened with arrest for selling its recordings that bear labels warning consumers of sexually explicit lyrics. Haik said he pushed the bill to force the recording industry to follow through on long-standing promises to institute a voluntary labeling system. ``This is designed to make the industry put its money where its mouth is,'' said Sen. Mike Foster, a supporter of the labeling bill. The legislation would not take effect until 1992. Haik has said that if the recording industry implements its voluntary program, he would push for repeal of the law. Cutshaw said a labeling law would not keep objectionable recordings out of the hands of youths, since older siblings and friends could make the purchases for them. Instead, the law would be a ``nightmare'' for retailers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Execs Are on Hold 62 Hours a Year
DOC.TEXT: The average business executive spends about 60 hours a year on hold on the telephone, according to a survey. The survey commissioned by the personnel agency Accountemps asked questions of 200 executives of the nation's 1,000 largest corporations. They were questioned by an independent market research firm, which asked how much time the executives spend on hold, as well as on unnecessary meetings and unnecessary memos. According to the results, the average executive spends 15 minutes a day on hold, or 60 hours in a year that includes four weeks' vacation; 32 minutes a day reading and writing unnecessary memos, or 128 hours a year; and an hour and 12 minutes a day at unnecessary meetings, or 288 hours a year. The executives were not asked how much time other people spend on hold waiting for them.

DOC.HEAD: Cars Powered by Sunshine Begin 11-Day Race
DOC.TEXT: Under a bright, sunny sky, 29 solar-powered cars designed and built by college students today began a 1,600-mile race from Florida to Detroit, Mich., in efforts to prove a future technology. The start of the 11-day race sponsored by the Department of Energy, the Society of Automative Engineers and General Motors was led by the first three qualifiers _ from the univerities of Maryland, Michigan and Mankato State in Minnesota. ``We hope young people will get excited about this race'' and that it serves as an incentive for future technology, said GM President Bob Stemple in ceremonies before the start. Thirty-two cars entered the competition, but Arizona State had problems with its brakes and gears and was scratched from the first day's start, organizers said. That car will start up on the second leg of the race and be penalized for the lost time. Winners will be determined by adding up the times it takes to complete each day's leg of the race. Two other cars had trouble getting away immediately but were expected to leave later in the day. They were the entries from the Unversity of North Texas and Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Indiana. The cars, powered only by the sun and storage batteries, will travel over secondary roads in Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, Kentucky, Indiana, Ohio and Michigan. They are headed for a July 19 finish at the General Motors technical center in Warren, Mich., a suburb outside the motor city. The combination of direct sunlight and stored energy can propel some of the vehicles at high speeds for limited distances, but the cars must abide by posted speed limits. Nevertheless, the students want to win. The top two finishers and a third selected for technological innovations will be sent by GM to compete in the 1990 World Solar Challenge race in Australia later this year. ``Each car was conceived, designed and built from the ground up'' by some of North America's top engineering and science students, said GM vice president Donald L. Runkle. Some of the cars cost more than $250,000 and took more than a year to build. Entries come from schools including MIT, Stanford, the University of Michigan, Florida Institute of Technology, Viginia Polytechnic Institute, the University of Pennsylvania, Waterloo-Ontario and Puerto Rico-Mayaguez. GM selected the 32 entries in April 1989 after considered more than 100 schools and 60 detailed design proposals. Sunlight is the only power source, but battery charging from the car's solar array is allowed daily in the morning and late afternoon. Each of the 32 schools received $5,000 from General Motors and $2,000 from the U.S. Department of Energy as seed money, but each each car cost thousands more to build.

DOC.HEAD: Maritime Agency Reaches Settlement with Ocean Freight Lines
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Maritime Commission said Monday it has reached a settlement with several shipping lines operating in the Pacific that allegedly charged less for cargo than their published rates. The agency said it would not disclose the names of the companies or the amount of money they will pay until Aug. 28. But a statement released by the commission said the companies will make the largest monetary payment to the maritime commission in its 29-year history. ``We realized from the beginning that only a strong deterrent would prevent unlawful practices'' in Pacific trade, acting commission Chairman James J. Carey said in the statement. ``This agreement goes a long way toward assuring future compliance with the Shipping Act of 1984.'' The largest previous settlement with the commission was $4 million, made in the late 1970s, said Seymour Glanzer, director of the agency's Bureau of Hearing Counsel. Glanzer declined in a telephone interview to reveal the identity of the companies, how many are involved, whether they are U.S. or foreign lines and the amount of money in the settlement. Violations of the Shipping Act or commission regulations can result in penalties of up to $25,000 per shipment. A source familiar with the agreement said it involved between four and 10 companies. The companies allegedly charged rates to ship cargo that were less than the official tariffs they had previously filed with the commission, Glanzer said. In addition to paying the penalties, the settlement requires them to fully disclose alleged wrongful or questionable rate practices, including rebates and inaccurate descriptions of cargo. The companies also have agreed to participate in a new compliance accord that involves stronger policing of cargo rates by the shipping industry. A similar settlement covering cargo trade in the Atlantic, for $2 million, took effect in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Modestly Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices ended modestly lower on London's Stock Exchange Monday amid limited buying interest. A string of company profit downgradings by equity analysts added to the growing wariness in the market about British corporate profitability. Some investors were waiting for Britain's June inflation figures to be released Friday, traders said. The strong pound was encouraging for some segments of the market, particularly those stocks with predominantly British earnings, dealers said. But the same equities also were being hit by high interest rates, dealers said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 2.5 points, or 0.1 percent, to close at 2,337.5. The Financial Times 30-share index was quoted at 1,859.3, down 5.7 points at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 2.46 points to close at 1,262.84. Volume was light at 369.8 million shares, compared with 741.3 million shares Friday.

The stock market was mixed in a drifting session today, bogging down after Friday's rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 25.74 points on Friday, rose 0.50 to 2,905.45 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers held a slight edge on gainers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 651 up, 666 down and 559 unchanged. Analysts said traders found little inspiration in the news to prompt them to make big commitments either way. Interest rates have been moving up since late last week as hopes have faded for any action soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Economists generally believe that business activity, while showing anemic growth at best, is not weak enough to spur the central bank into any stimulative measures. At the same time, traders seem to be bracing for a good many disappointments in forthcoming corporate earnings reports for the second quarter of the year. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric rose ] to 71; International Business Machines added | to 118|; Exxon dropped | to 47[, and Philip Morris was down { at 48}. Nike class B shares, traded in the over-the-counter market, climbed 5 to 85. DOC.HEAD: OFF! Maker Sues Small Mosquito Repellent Company
DOC.TEXT: The company that makes OFF! insect repellent is taking a swat at a small St. Augustine company that also manufactures a bug repellant. Johnson Wax, which introduced OFF! in 1956, alleges trademark infringement in a lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Jacksonville. The suit also alleges SKEETER OFF, an herbal lotion mixed with citronella, is taking a bite out of its profits. Wayne Ellison, president of EcoSafe, which makes SKEETER OFF, said his product is available only in health food stores and has sold only 3,000 bottles since the product was introduced last fall. ``They're just too big and powerful. We would be like a flea on the back on an elephant,'' Ellison said of the suit, filed last week. Daniel Frohling, an attorney representing Johnson, refused to discuss the lawsuit, which asks the court to order EcoSafe to stop making SKEETER OFF, transfer all profits from the product and pay damages and attorney fees. Johnson Wax, also known as S.C. Johnson & Son Inc., is based in Racine, Wis., and employs more than 12,500 workers worldwide. It also makes Raid roach killer, Pledge furniture polish and Future floor wax. Ellison and two employees run EcoSafe. All but two of its products are pet-oriented; the company has sales of less than $500,000. SKEETER OFF was originally marketed as SKEETER SHOOO, but the name was changed because customers became confused with one of his pet products, INSECT SHOOO, Ellison said. Ellison said he will probably quit marketing SKEETER OFF and return to SKEETER SHOOO, although it means a loss of $5,000 in packaging materials.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Claims to Pass Adidas to Become World's Largest Sports Shoe Company
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc. vaulted ahead of all worldwide competitors last year, the company said Monday in reporting an 84 percent leap in its fourth-quarter profit. Chairman Philip H. Knight said at a meeting with securities analysts in New York that Nike intends to enhance its position by working to boost its already strong business outside the United States. He announced that the company earned $67.2 million, or $1.77 a share, in the three months ended May 31, up from $36.5 million, or 97 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 47 percent to $609 million from $413.4 million. Profit for Nike's entire 1990 fiscal year rose 45 percent to $242.96 million, or $6.42 a share, from $167.05 million, or $4.45 a share, in 1989. Annual revenue rose 31 percent to $2.24 billion from 1989's $1.71 billion. ``In 1990, Nike became the largest sports and fitness footwear and apparel company in the world,'' Knight said. ``We have accomplished this by marketing a wide range of quality in a variety of sport categories built on a foundation of truly innovative performance technology.'' Nike nosed out Adidas AG, the West German manufacturer, for the top spot among athletic shoemakers. The company based its claim to the No. 1 ranking on global sales of the Nike brand and said it also was the leader in terms of profitability. In the United States alone, Nike estimates that it holds about 28 percent of the market. Its closest competitors, Reebok International Inc. and L.A. Gear Inc., hold 22 percent and 12 percent of the U.S. market, respectively. Sales of Nike brand goods worldwide last year surpassed Adidas' sales, excluding sales of non-Adidas brand merchandise owned by the Adidas group and revenue from licensed merchandise. As a privately-held company Adidas doesn't regularly report its results. It has previously been reported that Adidas had revenue last year of about $2.8 billion, including licensing revenue. Thomas Clarke, Nike's vice president of marketing, said the practice of including revenue from licensed merchandise artificially inflates the total. He said Nike calculates that actual sales of the Adidas brand alone were about $1.6 billion last year vs. about $2.1 billion for Nike. Adidas has been losing market share for years and reportedly lost about $90 million last year. It was announced over the weekend that French entrepreneur Bernard Tapie will buy an 80 percent stake in Adidas. Tapie promised to return Adidas to profitability by next year. The change in Adidas' ownership will not upset Nike's strategy to dominate the world sports shoe business, said Richard K. Donahue, Nike president and chief operating officer. ``We see them as not being in our league,'' Donahue said, describing Adidas as a has-been, troubled company. Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., plans to become more aggressive in promoting its products overseas. It will inaugurate its first globally coordinated advertising campaign with the launch next spring of the Air 180, a new model of running shoe incorporating the latest developments in Nike's air-sole cushioning. Clarke said Nike will spend about $20 million on the global launch of the shoe that will sell for about $130. At the securities analysts meeting, Nike also provided a preview of new television commercials. Besides its product-oriented commercials, it showed a public service-type message encouraging youngsters to stay in school, starring basketball David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs, his mother and Georgetown University basketball coach John Thompson.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Introduces New Laser Printers
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. improved its line of printers Monday by introducing two new models it hopes will maintain these machines as a moneymaker. The Cupertino-based personal computer company introduced the laser printers partly in response to stiff competition on several fronts. At $1,999, Apple's new Personal LaserWriter SC cuts the cost of an entry-level Apple printer by $800. It is aimed at individual users who might be tempted to buy one of the several lower-priced printers sold by Apple competitors. But analysts say the other new model, the $3,299 Personal LaserWriter NT, is more important because it is designed to be shared by a network of computers. In addition, unlike the model SC, the NT comes with PostScript, a brand of software from Adobe Systems Inc. that provides Apple's Macintosh computers with one of their most important features, the ability to print elegantly a variety of typefaces and graphics. Analysts say sales of laser printers last year accounted for more than 15 percent of Apple's $5.3 billion in revenues. That showing could be seriously threatened in the future by Hewlett-Packard Co., the market leader in laser printers. H-P recently started making printers that work with Apple's Macintosh computers. In addition, several small printer companies have been challenging Apple for sales to Macintosh users. Apple introduced its first laser printer shortly after it announced the Macintosh in 1984. The combination of these two products and special software resulted in a new computer application called desktop publishing, a way of computerizing the layout process of printing.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Denies Imminent Announcement On Exchange Rate Mechanism
With AM-Economic Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Monday denied it was about to link the pound to the exchange rate mechanism covering other major European currencies. Sterling strengthened in foreign exchange on speculation that such an announcement would be made at the Houston summit. In late New York trading, the pound was quoted at $1.8065, up from late Friday's $1.7865. ``I can assure you that I am not going to announce this morning that Britain is about to join the exchange rate mechanism,'' John Major, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a news conference. Major, speaking shortly before the opening of the summit of the world's seven top industrialized nations, reiterated that Britain's conditions for joining the exchange rate mechanism were unchanged. Britain promised in principle last summer to join the mechanism when its inflation rate _ now nearly 10 percent and among the highest in the European Community _ falls. Other conditions about free capital movements in the community largely have been met. The exchange rate mechanism links nine of the 12 currencies of the European Community. It is designed to prevent wide fluctuations in exchange rates. Earlier, Major met Jacques Delors, president of the community's executive commission, to press Britain's alternative plan to Delors' radical proposals for a single European Community currency. ``President Delors made it clear the commission is seriously examining our proposals,'' said Major. The British proposal is for a new, hard European currency, the European Currency Unit or ECU, to circulate alongside the community's present currencies. At present the ECU is used primarily as an accounting mechanism. Britain announced the plan last month. A special conference is due to open in December and is supposed to make final decisions by the end of 1992, the year internal EC trade barriers are to be dismantled. The Delors program calls for a single central banking system as well as one currency. Britain says it never will agree to the Delors plan because it means surrendering national control over its economy.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Developer Again Tops Billionaires List, But Trump Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs to CORRECT day of week. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-World's Richest-List
LaserPhoto NY13, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese developer again topped a list of the world's richest people, but the annual tally has one conspicuous deletion this year: Donald J. Trump. Despite the financial troubles of the New York developer, the United States continues to contain the world's largest number of billionaires _ 62 _ according to estimates by Forbes magazine. In addition, there are 37 U.S. families with fortunes over $1 billion, Forbes says in its July 23 issue. Forbes, in estimates released Monday, says the world's wealthiest person for the fourth straight year was Yoshiaki Tsutsumi of Japan, whose railroad and real estate empire includes golf courses, ski resorts and hotels. Forbes estimated his net worth at $16 billion, up about $1 billion from last year. That estimate was far greater than that of rival business magazine Fortune, which put Tsutsumi's net worth at $3.1 billion last September. Fortune said the world's richest person is the Sultan of Brunei, at $25 billion. Forbes excludes heads of state from consideration. Following the 56-year-old Tsutsumi on the Forbes list was Japanese developer Taikichiro Mori, a former economics professor who now owns 78 office buildings. Forbes put Mori's net worth at $14.6 billion. Ranked third was the family of Sam Walton, founder of Wal-Mart, the third-largest U.S.retail chain. Forbes estimates that the Waltons, who also were third-ranked last year, are worth $13.3 billion, up from $8.7 billion in 1989. America's du Pont family was fourth, with a net worth estimated at $10 billion. They were followed by Hans and Gad Rausing, two Swedish brothers who control a packaging empire worth $9.6 billion. Kitaro Watanabe, a Japanese real estate owner, was sixth at $9.2 billion. He was followed by Canada's Reichmann brothers, owners of the Olympia & York real estate company, at $9 billion. Kenkichi Nakajima and his family, founder of Japan's largest maker of pachinko machines, a gambling game similar to pinball, were eighth at $8.4 billion. South Korea's Shin Kyuk-ho, who owns a candy and real estate empire, was ninth at $7 billion to $8 billion; and Forrest E. Mars and family of the United States, of Mars candy fame, were 10th at an estimated $6 billion. Other American families with net worth exceeding $3 billion included the Newhouse, Hearst and Cox families, which derive their fortunes from publishing and broadcasting; the Bass family of Texas; the Mellon family of banking fame; the Dorrance family, whose wealth comes from Campbell Soup Co.; and Bill Gates, founder of the computer software company Microsoft Corp. John Werner Kluge remained the richest American individual, according to Forbes. Kluge, founder of the media company Metromedia, has an estimated net worth of $5.2 billion, placing him in a tie for 12th place on the worldwide list with the Newhouses. As for Trump, Forbes put his net worth last year at $1.7 billion, but it dropped sharply this year as the value of his real estate and airline empire plummeted. In April, the magazine said he was worth about a half a billion dollars. Some sources peg it even lower. Forbes says one trend it noticed in compiling this year's list was the number of wealthy Germans. The magazine identified 38 West German billionaire families _ far more per capita than in Japan or the United States. The list includes 40 Japanese and 99 American individuals or families with a net worth over $1 billion. Forbes says it identified 271 billionaire individuals or families worldwide, up from 226 last year. The compilation is based on recent stock valuations, comparable real estate valuations and currency exchange rates, among other factors. The magazine says it excludes from consideration royal families and heads of state because their wealth ``derives more from political heritage than from economic effort.'' But it doesn't exclude drug dealers. Among the billionaires it lists are Colombia's Pablo Escobar Gaviria, the head of the Medellin cocaine cartel, at about $3 billion, and Colombia's Ochoa family, at about $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Three Computer Hackers Plead Guilty to BellSouth Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Three members of an underground group of computer hackers that bilked telecommunications companies of money and credit information pleaded guilty to federal conspiracy charges Monday. The three are members of the ``Legion of Doom,'' a closely knit group of about 15 computer hackers operating in Georgia, Texas, Michigan, Illinois, Florida, New York and other states, said U.S. Attorney Joe Whitley. Whitley said the group disrupted telecommunications, stole computer source codes and information, stole credit information and fraudulently obtained money and property. In May, authorities in Indiana who prosecuted a teen-ager involved with the group called it an elite group of hackers that accepted only the nation's best computer moles. The juvenile, who was not identified, pleaded guilty to 11 counts of fraud and agreed to testify against the Atlanta men in a trial scheduled to begin Monday. Instead, the three pleaded guilty. They were identified as Adam E. Grant, 22, and Robert J. Riggs, 22, both of Atlanta, and Franklin E. Darden Jr., 24, of Norcross. Federal authorities charged that between Sept. 10, 1987, and July 21, 1989, the three men illegally accessed various BellSouth Co. computer systems and obtained valuable information that they distributed to other hackers. Grant and Darden also monitored private telephone conversations, Whitley said in a statement. They were charged with conspiracy to commit computer fraud, wire fraud, access code fraud and interstate transportation of stolen property. Darden and Riggs pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy each and face a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Grant pleaded guilty to possessing 15 or more BellSouth access devices with intent to defraud and faces a possible 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. A spokesman for BellSouth, Scott Ticer, said the operation cost his company about $1.5 million, most of it for investigating and changing access codes.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Increase at Treasury Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level in several weeks. The Treasury Department sold $9.0 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.81 percent, up from 7.73 percent last week. Another $9.0 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.75 percent, up from 7.60 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.91 percent on April 30, and six-month bills averaged 7.79 percent on May 21. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.08 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.60, and 8.18 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,608.20. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.06 percent last week, down from 8.13 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Prestigious French Department Store Comes to Tower
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump announced Monday that Galeries Lafayette, the giant French retailer, will open a branch store in Trump Tower, helping to solidify the value of his 68-story skyscraper on Fifth Avenue. ``We have a fabulous anchor for Trump Tower, it's a fabulous tenant,'' Trump said at a news conference with Galeries Lafayette's chairman, Georges Meyer. Neither Trump nor Meyer disclosed terms of the lease. Published reports said it would be for 25 years and estimated it would be worth tens of millions of dollars to Trump by enhancing the tower's attractiveness as security for loans. Meyer said the new branch would open in the fall of 1991. It will occupy 80,000 square feet fronting on 57th Street in a six-floor section of the tower vacated by Bonwit Teller's flagship store. Trump had made no bones about wanting to be rid of Bonwit, the previous prime tenant that he characterized as a poorly run has-been and unfit to be a neighbor of the other shops in Trump Tower. He paid about $5 million to acquire its lease earlier this year after Bonwit's owner went into reorganization proceedings. A deal with Galeries Lafayette was made several weeks ago and the papers were signed Sunday night, Trump said. ``We took a little bit of a risk when we bought out the lease,'' Trump said. ``It was my intention to get this group into this building and it worked out,'' he said. Asked how his bondholders and investors might feel about it, Trump said, ``I think they're very, very happy.'' The main Galeries Lafayette store in Paris occupies 500,000 square feet, six times the space of the New York branch. After Harrods of London, it is Europe's biggest department store. Meyer said the company has done more than $4 billion a year in business at its 136 stores. Twenty of the stores bear the Galeries Lafayette name and the rest are operated by subsidiaries, he said. Meyer said he was not ready yet to estimate how much business the new branch might do.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Higher as Gas Jumps
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures rose Monday led by a surge in wholesale gasoline prices. The session started with brisk selling on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid speculation that supply will exceed demand for the near future. The end of an oil workers' strike in Norway provided another selling incentive. But an afternoon rally, motivated in part by technical forces, helped energy prices rebound. Wholesale gasoline prices continued to firm in the aftermath of Friday's explosion and fire at an Arco Chemical Co. plant in Texas. Traders bought on the assumption that temporary shortages in a gas additive produced by the plant could disrupt availability of premium gas grades in some areas. Unleaded gasoline for August delivery jumped 1.44 cents to 56.85 cents a gallon after adding 0.46 cent on Friday. Contracts for delivery during September through November also posted gains. The contract for August delivery of the benchmark U.S. crude oil, West Texas Intermediate, advanced 11 cents to $16.58 cents a 42-gallon barrel following Friday's decline of 3 cents. The contracts for delivery through November also settled higher. Among other refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale home heating oil for August delivery settled at 48.90 cents a gallon, up 0.60 cent. The contract lost 0.03 cent on Friday. The September through November contracts finished higher. In natural gas trading, the August contract fell to $1.493 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.498 on Friday. Analyst James Steel at Refco Inc. said crude garnered technical support from the ability of the August contract to remain above $16 a barrel despite heavy selling in the morning. Fresh indications that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is making a concerted effort to cope with a world oil price slump ahead of a general meeting July 25 also encouraged buying, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Leather Goods Maker Charges Retailer With Copying Handbags
DOC.TEXT: Coach Leatherware Co. on Monday said it has charged specialty retailer Ann Taylor Inc. with deliberately copying some of Coach's most popular handbags. A lawsuit seeking damages has been filed by Coach, a subsidiary of Sara Lee Corp., against Ann Taylor and its manufacturer, Laura Leather Goods Ltd., Coach said in a news release. Coach President Lew Frankfort said, ``It is clear from looking at these Ann Taylor products that the intention was to make customers believe they were Coach.'' The Ann Taylor handbags are more than just imitations, ``they are direct knock-offs,'' he said. Joseph Schumm, Ann Taylor's executive vice president and general counsel, who normally would comment on legal matters, was not in the New York headquarters Monday and was unable to be reached, a secretary in his office said. Jan Still-Lindeman, a spokeswoman for Coach, said the Ann Taylor bags alleged to closely resemble Coach styles bear small leather tags, attached with a chain, that are almost identical to ones on Coach bags. She said Coach has estimated the damages at over $500,000. The lawsuit is pending in U.S. District Court in New York.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market crept ahead in a quiet, drifting session Monday, extending the upswing it began late last week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 9.16 to 2,914.11 on top of Friday's 25.74-point gain. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 764 up, 673 down and 545 unchanged. Analysts said traders found little inspiration in the news to prompt them to make big commitments either way. Interest rates have been moving up since late last week as hopes have faded for any action soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. In Monday's activity prices of long-term government bonds dropped nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.54 percent-8.58 percent range. Economists generally believe that business activity, while showing anemic growth at best, is not weak enough to spur the Fed into any stimulative measures. At the same time, traders seem to be bracing for a good many disappointments in forthcoming corporate earnings reports for the second quarter of the year. DOC.HEAD: Investor Settles Insider Trading Charges in Rorer Deal
DOC.TEXT: A French investor accused of insider trading on Rorer Group Inc. securities has settled the charges with federal officials, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Monday. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Robert Rossi agreed to pay nearly $1.45 million in alleged illegal profits plus interest. The settlement was approved by a federal judge in New York on July 3. Rossi, who maintains a mailing address in Geneva, Switzerland, was accused with three foreign companies last January of trading on inside information about merger talks between Rorer, a Fort Washington, Penn., pharmaceutical company, and another company later identified as France's Rhone-Poulenc SA. Daniel A. Pollack, an attorney for Rossi in New York, said his client was pleased with the settlement and ``takes the position that his investment decision was based on his own analyses of Rorer and other drug stocks. The fact that the commission did not penalize him, but only required him to disgorge his profits is some indication that the SEC would have a difficult time proving the charges agasinst him in a courtroom.'' Pollack said Rossi was a French citizen living in Africa, but declined to say where, adding ``for Rossi to have litigated in New York City'' would have been ``expensive, burdensome and time consuming.'' In January, Rorer Group said it had agreed in principle to pursue the sale of a 68 percent stake to Rhone-Poulenc for about $73 per share. The SEC has not disclosed how the defendants allegedly obtained the inside information. Rossi's settlement was the first in the case, said Gary Sundick, an attorney with the SEC in Washington. He said charges have been dismissed against Foundation Hai of Monte Carlo, Monaco.
