DOC.HEAD: Cotton Futures Take Tumble After Long Rally
DOC.TEXT: Cotton futures prices fell sharply Monday on the New York Cotton Exchange, extending a slide that began last week and represents the market's steepest drop this year. On other commodity markets, energy futures rallied; sugar plummeted; precious metals were lower; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Cotton futures fell 0.8 cent to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents with the contract for delivery in October off 2 cents at 76.74 cents a pound. The July contract expired at 90 cents a pound. The retreat followed limit losses in most contracts on Friday. Analysts attributed the selloff to profit-taking after a six-month rally that boosted the price of cotton for near-term delivery from about 66 cents in early January to a high of 93.9 cents a pound on July 5. ``This has been a bull market like we haven't seen in years and years,'' said Ernest Simon, a cotton specialist with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. He said prices had been driven steadily higher over the past six months by strong domestic and international demand for U.S. cotton and, more recently, by poor growing weather in the high plains of Texas, where ``it has been much too dry and much too hot for weeks on end.'' A surge in wholesale gasoline prices led energy futures higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analyst Stephen W. Platt of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said gasoline prices continued to firm in the aftermath of Friday's explosion and fire at an Arco Chemical Co. plant in Texas. Traders bought on the assumption that temporary shortages of a gas additive produced by the plant could disrupt availability of premium gas grades in some areas, Platt said. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 27 cents lower with August at $16.58 a barrel; heating oil was .53 cent to .63 cent higher with August at 48.90 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .20 cent to 1.44 cents higher with August at 56.85 cents a gallon. Sugar futures plummeted on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after the European Commission released a European sugar beet crop forecast of 14.18 million metric tons, up 106,000 from a year earlier. Further support stemmed from the Brazilian government's decision to authorize refiners in Brazil to produce more sugar and less alcohol from sugar cane, said analyst Arthur Stevenson of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Stevenson said trading volume was ``huge'' and dominated by speculative fund selling. Sugar settled .50 cent to .74 cent lower with October at 11.9 cents a pound. In precious metals trading on New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $2.90 to $3 lower with August at $359.90 a troy ounce; silver was 6.6 cents to 6.9 cents lower with July at $4.80 a troy ounce. Wheat and soybean futures ended lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn advanced after some private forecasters predicted drier weather for the Corn Belt later this week. After the close, the National Weather Service issued a new six-to-10-day forecast for mild temperatures and drier-than-normal conditions in the Midwest during the first half of next week. But most meteorologists continued to forecast scattered showers in the region this week, which would be beneficial to the corn and soybean crops. Wheat futures remained under pressure from the winter wheat harvest, which was 71 percent complete as of Sunday, according to the Agriculture Department's weekly crop-conditions report. The report showed slight improvement in the corn crop but no improvement in the soybean crop. Wheat futures settled 1{ cents to 5 cents lower with July at $3.06{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 6} cents higher with July at $2.80} a bushel; oats were 2} cents to 3{ cents lower with July at $1.27{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 4 cents lower with July at $6.16{ a bushel. Hog futures extended Friday's steep losses on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting recent high hog slaughter numbers and slack demand for bacon. Cattle futures rose in line with stronger cash markets. Live cattle settled .25 cent to .50 cent higher with August at 74.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .27 cent to .70 cent higher with August at 85.27 cents a pound; live hogs were .47 cent to 1.08 cents lower with July at 60.97 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to .10 cent higher with July at 52.17 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Executives Name Heinz' O'Reilly `CEO of the Year'
DOC.TEXT: Anthony O'Reilly of H.J. Heinz Co. was named ``Chief Executive of the Year'' on Monday by readers of a business magazine targeted at chief executives. O'Reilly, who is chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Pittsburgh-based food company, was selected for the honor based on responses from readers of Chief Executive, a trade journal set to about 35,000 corporate executives. The magazine asked for nominees whose leadership skills enabled their companies to meet foreign competition, to turn around a troubled enterprise, to reinvigorate a mature company or to best manage technical innovation, among other skills. O'Reilly was chosen from a list of 1,400 names submitted by readers. Actual selection was made by a panel of executives named by the magazine. O'Reilly was presented with the award at a dinner Monday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Announces New Computer Line
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., which is suffering from sluggish earnings, announced a new midrange computer line Monday designed to provide desktop computer users with more flexibility. The computer line, called VAX 4000, is designed to compete directly with computers offered by International Business Machines Corp. Digital unveiled the products at its annual DECWorld sales exposition here. The new line is based on client-server computing, which allows one or more computers to act as control centers for networks of desktop machines. ``In the '90s, people want to use computers in a much more effective way,'' said Kenneth Olsen, Digital's president. Digital says the VAX 4000 delivers more power than IBM's popular AS-400 minicomputer at half the cost. Digital is the world's second-largest computer company behind IBM. ``Users want to sit at the desktop of their choice,'' Olsen said. ``They want the flexibility to quickly access information in any database on the network, use the right application to get their work done, and share the work they do with anyone else who needs it.'' Digital estimates there is a potential client-server market of more than $100 billion over the next five years, as the networked style of computing spreads from the office to the laboratory to the factory. The VAX 4000 announcement follows a fiscal year in which Digital reported sluggish earnings. The company, based in the suburb of Maynard, has offered voluntary severance to thousands of employees to reduce its work force. Digital has not reported its fourth-quarter earnings for the fiscal year ended June 30. But the company said last month that external forecasts of its fourth-quarter earnings were too optimistic. In the quarter that ended March 31, Digital earned $24.9 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $256 million, or $2.05 per share, during the same period a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: New President Named for Computer Consortium
DOC.TEXT: Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corp., a computer industry consortium, said Monday it has named former Pentagon researcher Craig Fields as its new president. Grant Dove, chairman and chief executive officer of the consortium, said the appointment of Fields would begin ``a smooth transition to the next generation of leadership for MCC.'' Dove said Fields would be named to the additional post of CEO next year ``to allow me to transition to a less than full-time role as chairman of the board.'' Fields, who was director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, also will serve as chief technical officer and chief operating officer of the consortium. The consortium, owned by 21 high-tech companies, conducts long-term research on computer technology and microelectronics. ``MCC has proven that competitors in industry can collaborate on high-risk applied research, providing significant competitive advantages to the participating companies,'' Fields said. Dove, who was executive vice president of Texas Instruments Inc., was elected MCC's chairman in 1987. He said Fields' experience is exactly what the 8-year-old research group was looking for. ``Many of our original research programs are starting to mature and bear fruit. Craig will help us to establish and implement our new vision and priorities for the next seven to 10 years,'' Dove said.

DOC.HEAD: Divided or Not, Western Allies Move Toward Help for Gorbachev
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: With West Germany and France in the lead, the prosperous Western democracies are gearing up for a multi-billion-dollar effort to protect Mikhail Gorbachev from the economic morass that threatens his hold on Soviet power. Long lines and restive consumers give ample evidence that Gorbachev's economic reforms need an infusion of imagination and cash. Inability to keep food stores stocked has already forced Moscow to spend an extra 3 billion rubles _ $500 million _ on food imports. The White House says half the Soviet grain crop goes bad before it gets to the marketplace. Gorbachev has asked the West for financial and technical assistance and the subject dominated the first day of this week's economic summit. The summit leaders are split down the middle on how to proceed, and apparently agreed Monday to allow one another to go their own way. West Germany alone hopes to make $3.1 billion in loans available. Along with France and Italy, it is pressing for an overall Western aid package in excess of $15 billion. ``If we don't decide now to help the Soviet Union there is a risk that there will be no progress, no further reform'' of the Soviet political system, France's Francois Mitterrand said in the opening summit session. His remark was relayed by spokesman Hubert Vedrine. President Bush and Margaret Thatcher of Britain lead the go-slow faction. They question the wisdom of pumping in aid without more Soviet reform and the Americans are emphasizing instead their willingness to provide technical assistance to improve Soviet agriculture and transportation. Nonetheless, they have delivered Gorbachev a substantial gift by not trying to block the others. The summit nations are planning to act in concert in dispatching teams of bankers and other experts to assess Soviet needs _ perhaps setting the stage for a more substantial American commitment. ``Every country has its own kind of legitimate interests and concerns,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. ``We do not question them.'' Seventy-three years after the Russian revolution, Soviet officials emphasized on Monday that assistance could not carry Western conditions. ``We aren't taking orders,'' said Gorbachev aide Georgy Shaknazarov. But Bush has three main objections to offering direct aid: the Soviets' heavy military spending, their sending $5 billion a year in aid to Marxist Cuba and their slow pace in adapting to capitalistic ways. It was vaguely possible that summit leaders might attempt to set specific conditions concerning one or more of those problems before approving aid. The Soviets are open about their need for Western help. ``I feel it would be advantageous, for us and the West,'' said Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. He said he disliked the term ``aid,'' preferring ``credit, technical cooperation, personnel training, joint ventures and joint projects'' _ a message welcome to Bush. Only a year ago, the United States, Britain, France, Canada, West Germany, Japan and Italy stepped gingerly into these uncharted waters and decided to help Poland and Hungary. The Soviet Union presents a far more difficult decision. From the French delegation, meanwhile, came a statement of renewed determination to bolster Gorbachev and the Soviet economy with ``all aid that is serious and useful.'' Failure of perestroika could mean Gorbachev's downfall and begin an era of instability across the Soviet Union. Where would the West be, asked Brian Mulroney of Canada, ``if they chuck him out?'' U.S. officials make this kind of case for moving slowly: _ It is impossible to keep tabs on assistance. Many of the billions could be diverted to the Red Army where the generals and Gorbachev do not always see eye to eye. _ It doesn't make sense to send billions to the Soviets while they are sending billions to Cuba, a state whose interests often collide with the United States'. Mulroney agrees with Bush that Soviet aid to Cuba is ``profoundly unacceptable,'' and he said Canada was willing to provide trade credits, not direct assistance. _ The Soviet economy is so messed up that immediate aid will be wasted. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Monday: ``There's no sense in pouring money into a system that isn't ready to receive it.''
Barry Schweid is chief diplomatic correspondent for The Associated Press.

DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed in light domestic trading Monday as currency traders kept a close watch on the economic summit in Houston but had little news to act upon. Gold prices fell. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped $2.90 from late Friday to settle at $358.20 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $357.40, off $2.80. Currency dealers said trading in the British pound was the most active feature of the foreign exchange markets Monday. Sterling was boosted by continued expectation that Great Britain soon will join Europe's exchange rate mechanism. The mechanism limits exchange rate movements, and the markets expect it would strengthen the currency. The pound also was supported by comments from British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major that the recent strength of the pound was no fluke but reflected the currency's true value. Major spoke at the Houston meeting of the leaders of the seven biggest industrial nations. ``Sterling remains extremely strong across the board,'' said Robert Hatcher, a corporate currency dealer for Barclays Bank PLC in New York. In London, a pound was quoted at $1.8055, up strongly from late Friday's $1.7865. The pound had not been above $1.8000 in London since Jan. 4, 1989. Later, in New York trading, a pound cost $1.8080, more expensive than $1.7865 late Friday. The Japanese yen was boosted in domestic trading by comments from a U.S. Treasury official that the currency was considered low in value compared with other currencies, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at PaineWebber International Inc. in New York. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.70 yen, down 0.25 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 151.10 yen. DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Summit Leaders To Remove Farm Subsidies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `The agricultural ... with one new graf of farm issues taken up in the first negotiating session; INSERTS new 20th-21st grafs with comments from Kohl and Canadian official; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: President Bush argued ``very forcefully'' with his summit partners Monday to phase out billions of dollars in farm subsidies but there were few signs that European leaders would heed the arguments. Bush has made reaching a compromise on the farm issue a top priority at this week's seven-nation economic summit, believing that a resolution is critical to breaking a deadlock in a four-year effort to overhaul the global trading system. But officials of the 12-nation European Community, which participates in the annual economic summit gatherings, insisted that Houston was not the place to negotiate on the trade issue, throwing into doubt whether the administration will be able to achieve a hoped-for breakthrough. The United States has much at stake in the global trade talks because they offer the promise of greatly expanding markets for U.S. farmers and businesses. More exports would help reduce America's $100 billion annual trade deficit. The trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they were launched in 1986, have reached a virtual stalemate over the divisive farm issue. Bush brought up the trade negotiations in a string of one-on-one sessions with world leaders before the summit officially got under way Monday. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told reporters that Bush believed resolution of the trade dispute ``is critical. It should and must be done.'' The agricultural question was taken up in the first round of talks between the leaders on Monday afternoon at Rice University. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters the administration fears that the entire global free trade talks will falter without a resolution of the farm issue. Bush is ``making the point very forcefully to his summit partners that this is an enormously important activity,'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told reporters. Yeutter said that so far ``the European Community has not been engaged in the process.'' But the European Community contends that between 2 million and 3 millin European farmers could lose their jobs if the subsidies which support their less-efficient operations were eliminated. The EC, known as the Common Market, is represented at the economic summit by EC President Jacques Delors, who met with Bush before the summit began to discuss their differences. Bush took a tough stance, telling Delors that the political leaders needed to exhibit courage to resolve the issue, an EC official said. ``It was quite hard on agriculture,'' said the official, who spoke on condition that his name not be used. Aides said Bush also discussed agricultural policy in his meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, the two leaders with the strongest opposition to total elimination of farm subsidies. Kohl indicated to Bush that a draft negotiating paper on the agricultural issue unveiled recently by the chairman of the negotiating group, Aart de Zeeuw, a former Dutch agricultural official, could be the basis for breaking the deadlock, Hans Klein, Kohl's spokesman, told reporters. Yeutter said Kohl's stance was ``mildly encouraging.'' But another U.S. official, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said that it was unclear whether Kohl's comments really signified a new willingness to negotiate. Kohl is particularly crucial to resolving the agricultural question because Bush is unlikely to push too hard for concessions if the German leader digs in his heels because of upcoming German unification elections. Those elections will occur around the time negotiators are scheduled to meet in Brussels for the final bargaining session to complete the Uruguay Round of trade talks. The talks are being conducted under the auspices of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In the opening session, Kohl spoke about the need to conclude the global trade talks successfully, telling the other leaders, ``We should give the negotiators ... a positive signal and a political orientation that we all jointly stand for strengthening the GATT.'' Canadian Foreign Minister Joe Clark said he believed after discussions with Common Market officials that ``some ground can be found for forward movement.'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills told reporters that the United States hoped to achieve a commitment from the summit countries to use the de Zeeuw paper as the basis for working out a final agreement but she said it was not certain whether even this position would overcome European resistance. In addition to phasing out farm subsidies, the United States has an ambitious goal of expanding global trade rules to include about $1 trillion in trade not now covered by the GATT, the world body which policies trade disputes. The U.S. proposal would result in the elimination of barriers to trade in the high-growth area of banking and other services, where U.S. companies are extremely competitive. American negotiators are also pushing to extend GATT rules to cover better enforcement of trade and copyright piracy, which is estimated to cost American companies $60 billion in lost sales each year. In all of these issues, agriculture is seen as the key because Third World countries have balked at agreeing to U.S. proposals on expanding GATT coverage unless they win expanded markets for their farm products.

DOC.HEAD: Mitusbishi To Form Joint Venture With Chicago Arbitrage Firm
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corp. said Tuesday it will form a joint venture with Chicago Research & Trading Group Ltd., one of the United States' leading futures and options traders. The joint venture, with $150 million in start-up capital, will enable Mitsubishi Trust to join major European and U.S. option trading exchanges, such as those in Chicago and Philadelphia, Mitsubishi officials said. The deal appears to mark a rare case of a Japanese financial institution taking an active managgement and policy making role in a joint venture with an American financial institution. In addition, Japanese firms in the past have not joined forces with any U.S. firms that deal strictly with futures and options in the United States. Toshihiro Hayashi of Mitsubishi Trust's bond and money market division said the joint venture, as yet unnamed, will be formed later this year. The project is awaiting approval from Japan's Finance Ministry and the U.S. government. He said the joint venture would strengthen the credit standing of the Chicago-based firm, one of the world's largest arbitrage trading firms, a member of 20 exchanges worldwide. Arbitrage trading refers to buying currency, commercial bills or securities in one market and selling them at the same time in another market to reap profits on the price discrepancy. The joint venture is to be based in Chicago and have offices in Tokyo, London, New York and Philadelphia. It will pursue arbitrage trading primarily in currencies and interest rate-related products on major exchanges and on over-the-counter markets. Mitsubishi Trust is contributing most of the start-up capital while Chicago Research is contributing expertise and both companies will contribute personnel, officials said. Other terms of the joint venture were not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Timber Industry Urges U.S. Not to Adopt Strict Protection Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, The Forest, to CORRECT figure to 28,000; PICKS UP 6th graf, Beuter said...; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The timber industry urged the government Monday to reject a spotted-owl protection strategy proposed by government scientists, saying it would cost 102,000 jobs and turn some towns into rural ghettos. Researchers commissioned by the American Forest Resource Alliance said logging communities in Washington, Oregon and Northern California accept the need to reduce timber harvests to protect the environment. But they said the government should consider human as well as environmental needs in developing a plan to protect the endangered owl. ``Yeah, we're going to lose jobs,'' said John Beuter, a forest economics consultant from Portland, Ore. He said the question is, ``How much of this is really necessary and how will it be implemented over time?'' The Forest Service has estimated that 28,000 timber jobs would be lost by the end of the decade under owl-protection policies recommended in an April report written by team of government scientists headed by Jack Ward Thomas. Beuter said his research shows the figure would be twice that, plus thousands more jobs lost outside the timber industry. The direct and indirect job loss would come to 102,000 by the end of the decade if the report's strategy is applied to public and private lands, he said. A federal timber task force is scheduled to come up with an extensive owl-protection plan by Sept. 1. Estimates of the remaining spotted owl population range from 3,000 to 5,000 pairs. Each nesting pair needs a large tract of undisturbed old-growth forest, biologists say. Robert Lee, a natural resource sociologist at the University of Washington, said a bitter class war already has developed between urban environmentalists who want to save old-growth forests and loggers who are ``portrayed as Neanderthals of the woods.'' Lee, part of the timber industry's research team, predicted rural communities would find it difficult to adapt to a changing economy. ``People are so isolated,'' he said. ``They have non-transferable skills. They have a sense of identity. ... They may not be able to sell their homes. They're immobilized.'' The stress on timber workers could lead to increased suicides, drug abuse and family violence, Lee said. ``The real issue is how to humanize the transition to another way of life,'' he said, adding that one way would be to let Northwest communities participate in the decision-making process. Last month the Bush administration announced partial plans to reduce timber harvests on land controlled by the Bureau of Land Management. The estimated impact of those plans would be about 1,000 logging jobs lost over two years. The administration also formed the task force, which is working on a plan for the millions of acres controlled by the Forest Service. Environmentalists have indicated they will go to court if the eventual plan is less than the Thomas report strategy. The Fish and Wildlife Service last month announced it will classify the spotted owl as threatened and entitled to protection under the Endangered Species Act. The act requires federal agencies to secure permission from the service before harming a species or its habitat. The study team for the American Forest Resource Alliance reports included private consultants as well as economists, social scientists and foresters from the universities of Washington, California, Montana and Minnesota.
